Immediate cardiac investigations are being ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Riley  a 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain. The chest pain started roughly an hour ago  radiating to the shoulders and neck  and was associated with diaphoresis  nausea  and light-headedness. She reports she has been extremely stressed after the sudden death of her spouse one week ago.  Patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been managed on Ramipril for the past five years and generalized anxiety disorder for which she takes sertraline. She denies any history of ischemic heart disease  diabetes  stroke  or any previous heart conditions. Ms. Riley is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. Her family history is significant for a mother who died of myocardial infarction in her seventies.  Physical examination reveals an jittery woman in significant distress  appearing older than her stated age. Vital signs reveal BP 160/95 mmHg  pulse 110/min  RR 20/min. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with regular rhythm. There are no appreciable murmurs  rubs  or gallops heard on auscultation. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.  Given the acute onset of the chest pain and the stressor it is possible Ms. Riley could be suffering from takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome. Appropriate diagnostic tests include an EKG and cardiac enzymes to initially rule out a myocardial infarction. Echocardiogram would then be needed to distinguish takotsubo from other cardiac conditions.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Yoshino  a 71-year-old Asian female  presents to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain and discomfort. The pain began suddenly two hours ago and is described as severe  pressure-like  and radiating to the left arm. She is sweating and feeling light-headed.   On closer questioning  Ms. Yoshino admits that she has been under a great deal of stress lately. Her husband passed away unexpectedly two weeks ago  and she's been having difficulty coping with the loss.  Ms. Yoshino has a past medical history significant for hypertension controlled with Losartan and hypercholesterolemia managed with Atorvastatin. She is a non-smoker  and there is no personal or family history of cardiovascular disease. Notably  the patient's mother was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy at the age of 68 after a severe emotional stress event.  Upon examination  Ms. Yoshino appears in distress  with an initial blood pressure reading of 160/90 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 per minute. Her respirations are mildy elevated at 20 per minute and she is afebrile. The cardiovascular exam reveals a regular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs  or gallops  but mild tachycardia. Lung exam demonstrates clear breath sounds bilaterally  and her other system exams are unremarkable.  ECG shows ST segment elevation in the anterolateral leads with no evidence of previous MI  suggesting an acute coronary syndrome. A troponin test confirms the presence of cardiac injury.  With her current symptoms  past medical history  recent extreme emotional stress  characteristic ECG changes  and raised cardiac enzymes  Ms. Yoshino is highly suspected to have a Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further diagnostic studies including echocardiography  coronary angiography  left ventriculography  and cardiac MRI may be performed for definitive diagnosis.

Demographics: 66-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian female  Presenting complaints: Ms. Johns reports experiencing sudden  severe chest pain and shortness of breath over the past few hours. She says these symptoms started abruptly and describes the pain as a heavy sensation that radiates down her left arm and up to her jaw.  Past medical history: Ms. Johns has no previously diagnosed heart conditions. She is hypertensive for which she regularly takes lisinopril. She acknowledges being a non-smoker and a social drinker. She lost her husband to cancer six months ago. She states that ever since  she has been experiencing high levels of stress and anxiety.  Family history: Mother had type 2 diabetes and father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70. She has a brother  68  with coronary artery disease.  Social History: She lives alone after her husband's death  retired school teacher  former pet owner  no significant financial stressors  does occasional counseling. She regularly attends the local church's grief support group.  Review of Systems: No history of syncope  palpitations  fatigue  or pre-syncope. No leg swelling  weight changes  cough or high fever. No recent injury or surgery.  This presentation is consistent with literature showing a predominance of takotsubo cardiomyopathy in elderly  post-menopausal women under acute emotional stress (often a bereavement) with an otherwise relatively uneventful cardiovascular history. The symptoms described mimic those of an acute coronary syndrome.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Brown is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension and anxiety disorder. She presents to the Emergency Department with sudden severe central chest pain of 2-hour duration. The pain is described as a crushing sensation  radiating to her left arm and associated with shortness of breath. Ms. Brown reports that her symptoms started abruptly following a heated argument with her neighbor.   On further interrogation  she also disclosed experiencing increasing stress levels surrounding her current living situation and family problems. She denies similar previous episodes  tobacco or alcohol use  and has no family history of premature heart disease. She has been compliant with her antihypertensive medication. On physical examination  she is in distress with initial vital signs revealing blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breathes per minute and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Resting 12-lead electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads.   Given her symptoms and EKG findings  there is a high suspicion for acute coronary syndrome; however takotsubo cardiomyopathy (or stress-induced cardiomyopathy) is also a differential  considering the significant emotional stress she has been experiencing prior to the onset of symptoms.

A 65-year-old Asian female patient presents in the Emergency Department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain onset was a couple of hours ago  triggered by a severe emotional distress on hearing about the sudden demise of her brother. The pain is crushing in nature and is radiating to the left arm  accompanied by diaphoresis. On enquiry  she reveals that she had a similar episode around a year ago  immediately following her husband's death  which was attributed to anxiety and she was treated symptomatically.  Her medical history reveals that she is hypertensive and is on a regular medication of Amlodipine 5mg  once a day. She admits to not being regular with her medications. She denies any history of smoking or alcohol use. No significant family history of cardiac diseases is noted. Her basic metabolic panel from a routine check-up two months ago suggested mild hyperlipidemia.  On examination  her blood pressure is measured to be 170/90 mmHg and her heart rate is 110 beats per minute. Her EKG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggestive of an ongoing myocardial ischemia.  Considering her age  gender  underlying stressors  ethnicity  and medical history  a presumptive diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is considered. Immediate intervention is initiated and further investigations are planned to confirm the diagnosis and decide on the future course of therapy.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset substernal chest pain radiating to her left jaw. The pain was severe  9/10 in intensity  squeezing in nature and associated with shortness of breath and sweating. She has a past medical history notable for hypertension  which is currently managed with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine. Allergies include penicillin.  Her husband of 40 years passed away suddenly 1 month ago  and Ms. Johnson has been experiencing significant emotional stress as a result. The chest pain began abruptly while she was watching her late husband's favorite movie at home.   Vitals include BP 160/95mmHg  HR 102 bpm  RR 20/min  temperature 37.1°C  SpO2 94% on room air. On auscultation  regular heart sounds were heard with no added sounds. EKG showed slight ST elevations in the anterolateral leads. Troponin levels were significantly increased.  Given her clinical presentation  elevated stress levels  and test results  a differential diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was considered. The patient was admitted for further diagnostic workup with transthoracic echo and coronary angiogram to confirm suspected takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often also referred to as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome""  due to its frequent onset after severe emotional distress.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Japanese woman presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. She describes the pain as “crushing” and rates it a 10/10. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea.  She reports experiencing extreme emotional stress as her husband  of 47 years  passed away two weeks ago. The onset of her chest pain occurred in the middle of a weeping episode over her husband.  Past Medical History: The patient is known with Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension. She's compliant with her daily Metformin and Lisinopril  prescribed for her Diabetes and Hypertension respectively. She doesn't smoke or drink alcohol  but she is obese with BMI of 32. She has no history of cardiac disease  stroke  or other significant medical problems  but a few of her close relatives had coronary artery disease.  Upon examination  she appears anxious and in distress. Her blood pressure is 150/90mmHg  heart rate 110 beats/min  respirations 24 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  Considering her recent severe emotional trauma  clinical signs and symptoms  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome""  is suspected.  This patient's profile represents a typical demographic for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy: post-menopausal women of Asian descent  often presenting after a recent significant emotional stressor. The patient's history of hypertension and diabetes  common comorbid conditions associated with this cardiomyopathy are also noted.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. She describes the sudden onset of this symmetrical and crushing pain this morning  which was exacerbated by physical activity and did not relieve with rest. She is feeling nauseous and also reports periodic episodes of mild shortness of breath.  She is a widow recently experienced multiple stressful life events  including the death of her husband six months ago  and she moved from her lifelong home shortly thereafter. The patient denies tobacco  alcohol or illegal drug usage but admits of being anxious most of the time.   Ms. Johnson has a documented history of hypertension  which is managed by a calcium channel blocker  amlodipine. She also has well-controlled type 2 diabetes  managed with metformin.   On physical examination  she appeared distressed and anxious. Her vitals were blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/minute  oxygen saturation of 94% on room air and a body mass index of 25 kg/m2.  The combination of her symptoms  age  gender  recent severe emotional stress  and history of hypertension suggest a likely diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  but further tests  such as an EKG and cardiac biomarker tests  are needed for accurate diagnosis.

Subject Demographics: Female  Age: 70  Asian  Presenting complaint: Chest pain similar to a heart attack  Past Medical History: Hypertension  previous episodes of panic attacks  history of major depressive disorder  Subject arrived in the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She describes the pain as a squeezing type  similar to prior bouts of unstable angina  rating it as 7 out of 10  worsening over the past 2 hours. The pain radiates to her left arm and is associated with nausea and diaphoresis. She also reports of recent stressors  including her husband's sudden death just two weeks prior.  She has a history of hypertension  manages it with enalapril  and has a history of panic attacks. She also has a recorded diagnosis of major depressive disorder  for which she receives treatment with sertraline. The subject denied smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Family history includes heart disease in her father  but otherwise  the family history is unremarkable. She does not have a previous myocardial infarction or other heart disorders.  The sudden onset of her symptoms  elevated blood pressure  and notable recent stressor give the suspicion of a 'broken heart syndrome' or takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further investigation using echocardiography  cardiac enzymes  and coronary angiography will help confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Tanaka is a 76-year-old Japanese widow who resides with her adult daughter in a suburban area. She presented to the ER accompanied by her daughter early this morning complaining of severe chest pain that radiates to the arms and jaw  which started suddenly a few hours after she was informed of her son's unexpected death.   Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia  all of which are well-controlled with medications. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcoholic drinks just occasionally in moderate amounts. There is no family history of congenital heart diseases  but her late husband had coronary artery disease.   She also informs the doctor that she had a similar episode of chest pain and breathlessness about 5 years ago  after her husband's death but was diagnosed with no definitive cause  as her angiogram showed no significant atherosclerosis at that time.   She further reports experiencing shortness of breath  palpitations  and some degree of anxiety since her son's death news. She denies fever  cough  or other systemic symptoms. She appears distressed and rather apprehensive.   Her daughter adds that Mrs. Tanaka  a former school teacher  has been living with significant life stressors since her retirement  grandson's immigrating to the U.S.  and most recently son's sudden death.   Given the sudden onset  the severe nature of her symptoms  her risk factors  and background stressors  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (or broken heart syndrome) was considered a potential differential diagnosis along with Acute Coronary Syndrome.

Patient Presentation  A 63-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain  similar in nature to angina  which started about an hour ago. She reports the pain as a crushing feeling in the mid-chest area radiating to her left arm. The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  for which she has been taking Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively.   She describes her current pain as worse than any previous chest pain  rating it an 8 out of 10. Additionally  the patient confirms that she has been under significant emotional stress for the past week due to the death of her spouse. She denies any use of tobacco  alcohol or illicit drugs. She is a retired schoolteacher and lives alone.  On physical examination  her blood pressure is 170/90 mmHg  HR 110 beats/min  SpO2 94%  and respirations 20/min. There is no jugular venous distension  carotid bruits or peripheral edema. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation. The heart rate is rapid  but regular with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   A 12-lead EKG reveals ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads V2-V4. In light of her symptoms  history  and EKG findings  she is diagnosed with probable Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further diagnostic and therapeutic intervention occurs immediately  considering the condition's life-threatening nature and high mortality rate amongst untreated patients.   The patient's age  sex  and recent emotional stress correspond with the typical demographic of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome""  which is most often seen in postmenopausal women and can be triggered by severe stress.

Patient Presentation:  A 69-year-old Caucasian female presents to the Emergency Department complaining of acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain started suddenly about an hour ago when she received disturbing news about the death of her close relative. The pain is described as a sharp  squeezing  and tight sensation in the mid-sternal area  radiating to her jaw and left arm  and is rated 8 out of 10 in intensity.   She has a past medical history significant for hypertension  controlled with losartan  and hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. She denies any history of ischemic heart disease or family history of early cardiac deaths. She quit smoking 20 years prior and denies alcohol or drug abuse. She's had an increased level of psychological stress over the past few weeks since the deterioration of her relative's health.   On examination  she appears anxious  pale  and diaphoretic. Her vitals are as follows: heart rate 90 beats per minute  blood pressure 160/90 mm Hg  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lung fields are clear to auscultation  and the rest of the physical exam is within normal limits.  An electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads and blood tests show elevated troponin levels. Further workup including echocardiogram and coronary angiogram reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle and the absence of significant coronary artery disease  respectively  leading to the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken-heart syndrome). The patient is admitted to the cardiology service for further management and observation.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Lee is a 68-year-old Asian woman living independently in a suburban neighborhood. She has a past medical history significant for controlled type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has had no surgeries or major illnesses beyond these two issues. She has a 40-pack year smoking history and has been a widow for two years after a 45-year marriage.   She presents today to the ER with symptoms that began suddenly during a family arguing session earlier in the day. Mrs. Lee describes a heaviness in her chest with mild sharp  transient left-sided chest pain. This was associated with palpitations  feeling light-headed  and she experienced transient shortness of breath.   She has no recent history of trauma  no pressure or burning in her chest or other symptoms typically suggestive of a myocardial infarction  and she did not lose consciousness. At the time of examination  the patient was in moderate distress with a slightly elevated blood pressure. Electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed that showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads with no significant Q-waves  suggesting a possible diagnosing of takotsubo cardiomyopathy or 'broken heart syndrome'.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the ER with chest pain and shortness of breath that began a few hours ago. The pain is sudden  severe  and radiating to her jaw. This is her first experience with this type of pain.   She experienced her husband's sudden death two weeks ago and has been struggling with the emotional stress since then.   Her past medical history is significant for treated hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She denies any previous cardiovascular disease  surgeries  or family history of cardiovascular disease  but does admit to being a former smoker. She regularly takes amlodipine and rosuvastatin. Social history reveals she is a retired school teacher  lives alone  and does not consume alcohol. She also indicates experiencing sleeping disturbances and decreased appetite following her husband's death.  Upon presentation  her blood pressure is mildly elevated at 150/90 mmHg  pulse is irregular at 100 beats per minute  and respiratory rate slightly increased to 22 breaths per minute. On examination  cardiac auscultation presents a normal rhythm without any murmurs  gallops or rubs. Chest examination is demonstrative of mild tachypnea but otherwise clear.   The preliminary EKG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterolateral leads  suspicious for an anterior wall myocardial infarction. However  upon further evaluation with cardiac catheterization  no significant blockages are found. Her Troponin I level is elevated while other laboratory findings are within normal ranges.  Given the recent emotional stress of her husband's death  the sudden onset of symptoms  EKG findings  and elevated cardiac enzymes without any obstructive coronary artery disease  a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart Syndrome) is considered. The case was further confirmed by an echocardiogram  which showed apical ballooning and systolic dysfunction typical of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. A is a 68-year-old Asian female who presents to the Emergency Department with acute chest pain described as sharp  9/10 intensity  located in the central chest region and radiating towards her left arm. She states the pain onset was sudden and has lasted for approximately 2 hours. She was under significant emotional stress at the time of onset due to sudden death news of her brother. She denies any chest trauma  dyspnea  diaphoresis  dizziness  or loss of consciousness.  She has a past medical history of hypertension  well-controlled with lisinopril  and a 45-year history of smoking. She has no known history of coronary artery disease  previous myocardial infarction  or heart failure but does report infrequent episodes of palpitations in the past. Her family history is significant for coronary artery disease and hypertension. She has no previous surgeries in her medical records.  On examination  Her blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg  heart rate was 110 bpm  respirations were 22 breaths per minute. Body mass index was 24. She appeared anxious and diaphoretic.  Given her age  gender  and significant emotional stress preceding the chest pain  there is a high degree of suspicion for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further evaluation with an EKG  cardiac enzymes  and an echocardiogram or Left Heart Catheterization might be useful in confirming the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath that began approximately an hour ago during an argument with her son. She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. She has no personal or family history of cardiac disease but reports recent life stressors including the death of her husband a few months back. On further examination  she appears anxious. Her blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  heart rate 100 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. EKG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterolateral leads. Her Troponin-T test results come back high. She states she is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. The rest of her clinical examination was unremarkable with no relevant abnormalities found on examination. The clinician suspects Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"".

A 68-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain. The pain began earlier in the day  approximately two hours after she received news of her husband's sudden death. The somatic distress has been persistent  radiating to her left arm  and is associated with shortness of breath. On a pain scale from 1 to 10  she describes it as an 8. Her medical history is notable for hypertension controlled with a calcium channel blocker and a low dose of a thiazide diuretic.  She is a non-smoker  does not consume alcohol  is moderately active  and has no known drug allergies. Her family history includes significant cardiovascular disease  her father died of a heart attack in his early 70s  and her younger brother has recently been diagnosed with ischemic heart disease. She has managed her stress and her grief in the past through counseling and significant familial and communal support.  On examination  her blood pressure is 155/90 mm/Hg  and her heart rate is 110 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals tachycardia. No murmurs or other abnormal sounds are present. Her lungs are clear  with no signs of congestion.   The clinical presentation and stressful event history lead to a strong suspicion of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The necessary diagnostic tests  including cardiac biomarkers and echocardiogram  are planned to confirm the diagnosis.

Subject is a 70-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the emergency department with reports of feeling chest discomfort and shortness of breath which started a few hours ago. Patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which she takes medication  but no known history of coronary artery disease or any other heart condition. She lost her husband two months ago and states she has been under a great deal of emotional stress since then. She currently lives alone and has minimal support system. She denies tobacco  alcohol or illicit drug use. She has a family history of similiar heart conditions. The symptoms started suddenly while she was watching television  and have not improved with rest. She describes it as 'typical' chest pain  with pressure-like discomfort situated in the middle of her chest  radiating to her jaw. Her initial EKG shows changes consistent with an acute myocardial infarction  but later angiogram does not show significant blockages in the coronary arteries. Echocardiogram shows a peculiar pattern of heart muscle contraction  with the base contracting normally but the middle and tip of the heart ballooning out  which are characteristic indicators of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.

A 68-year-old Asian female presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain. The onset was sudden  occurring after she received the news of her son’s unexpected death. She described the pain as 'pressure'  rating it 8 out of 10. The pain was primarily located in the central chest area and radiated to her left shoulder.   The patient had a past medical history significant for hypertension and stage 2 chronic kidney disease. She was on medication for both conditions  specifically losartan for hypertension and she was adhering to a kidney-friendly diet for her CKD. She included that she did not smoke  consume alcohol  or use illicit drugs. Family history was notable for ischemic heart disease in her father and sister.  In the ER  her blood pressure was 160/95  heart rate was 110  respirations were 22  and her oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior precordial leads. Her lab results displayed elevated troponin levels  low-normal kidney functions  and normal cholesterol levels.   A subsequent echocardiogram and cardiac catheterization demonstrated left ventricular dysfunction with apical ballooning  but no coronary artery disease. Based on these findings  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken-heart syndrome.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. A  a 68-year-old Asian woman  presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started about an hour ago. She rates her pain as an 8 on a scale of 10  describing it as a crushing sensation. She is known to have hypertension  which is well-controlled on medication. Her medical history also reveals that she has been suffering from depression and anxiety since her husband passed away two years ago.  Recently  she has been undergoing several stressful life events  which include her planning to move to a new city and handling legal issues related to her late husband's estate.  Physical examination reveals her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg  heart rate is 110 beats per minute  and respirations are 22 breaths per minute. On auscultation  her heart sounds are normal  but her lung sounds reveal some crackles at the bases. Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads.  Her laboratory tests show slightly raised cardiac troponin levels. However  the coronary angiogram reveals no significant coronary artery disease  which rules out the possibility of acute myocardial infarction. The echocardiogram shows apical ballooning with a hyperdynamic base of left ventricle  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.    She has no personal or family history of drug or alcohol abuse. She is allergic to penicillin and takes a daily dose of a calcium channel blocker for her hypertension. She is retired from her job as a primary school teacher and lives alone in her own house. She has two adult daughters who live nearby and visit her frequently. Her only other medications include multivitamins and a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) for her depression and anxiety.

Patient Presentation: A 72-year-old Asian woman arrives at the emergency department with complaints of severe  sudden-onset chest pain radiating to her left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath and sweating. She conveys that these symptoms were brought on by severe emotional distress and feelings of terror after a traumatic incident; her husband of 50 years died suddenly a week ago.   Past Medical History: The patient is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol drinker. She has a history of hygiene hypertension adequately managed with medication for the past decade. However  reports medication non-compliance in the past week due to the traumatic event. She was diagnosed with depression three years ago and has been on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) since then. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia  but her last lipid panel six months ago was within normal limits presumably due to her compliance with diet and medication recommended by her Primary Care Physician. She is not diabetic and has no known allergies.   Family History: Her father had coronary artery disease and her mother had hypertension and diabetes mellitus. She has one sister who is healthy and two brothers  one diagnosed with hypertension and the other one deceased due to lung cancer. Because of this  she has been generally health-conscious.  This patient's demographic characteristics and past medical history are generally aligned with the typical profile of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy patients who are predominantly post-menopausal women with recent severe emotional stress.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. S.  a 68-year-old Asian female  presents to the emergency department. She complains of acute onset severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  which started about an hour ago while she was at her husband's funeral. She reports associated shortness of breath and a feeling of impending doom. She denies associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or palpitations.  Her past medical history reveals that she has a history of hypertension  for which she regularly takes a calcium channel blocker and a thiazide diuretic. She denies any history of smoking  alcohol  or drug abuse and has never been diagnosed with diabetes or lipoprotein disorders.   Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with her mother passing away from myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and her older brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his mid-60s.   On physical examination  she appears anxious and in distress. Vital signs at presentation: BP - 180/100 mmHg  HR - 110/min  RR - 24/min  Temperature - 98.2 F  SpO2 - 92% on room air. She has clear lung sounds and regular heart beats with no abnormal sounds.   On further investigation  EKG shows ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads and Troponin levels are slightly elevated which might indicate acute coronary syndrome. However  subsequent catheterization revealed no significant coronary artery stenosis  leading more towards a suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy also known as broken heart syndrome  commonly seen in postmenopausal females undergoing significant emotional stress. An echocardiogram and cardiac MRI will be needed to confirm.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian woman  named Margaret  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to her left arm along with shortness of breath since morning. She describes it as a pressure sensation  reminiscent of an elephant sitting on her chest. The symptoms have been coming and going  lasting few minutes each time but have been continuous for the past hour.  Margaret is a retired school teacher who lives with her husband. She is an active woman  non-smoker. She is a moderate alcohol consumer  with wine most evenings. Her maternal aunt has a history of heart disease.   She has been relatively healthy throughout her life  with only a diagnosis of hypertension controlled with a low dose of an ACE-inhibitor. She says that she takes her antihypertensive medication as prescribed. She recently had normal results from a lipid panel  and had a negative workup for ischemic heart disease last year  including normal stress testing and coronary angiogram.   Significant notes in her social history include the recent death of her son to suicide 6 weeks ago. She appears to be grieving and mentions that she has been feeling high levels of stress and has difficulty sleeping recently.   Upon examination  Margaret looks anxious and is in obvious discomfort. Her blood pressure is 165/95  pulse 120  regular  respiratory rate 22  and temperature 98.0 F. Her cardiac examination reveals regular rate and rhythm without any undue heart sounds. Lung fields are unremarkable without any crackles or wheezes. She has no peripheral edema.  Given these observations  a suspicion for takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome""  is raised. Further testing with an electrocardiogram (ECG)  blood tests to measure cardiac enzymes  an echocardiogram  and coronary angiogram are planned to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Hernandez  a 68-year-old Hispanic woman  presents to the Emergency Department with severe  crushing chest pain of sudden onset  radiating to the left arm and jaw. It feels like an immense pressure  accompanied by shortness of breath  palpitations  and lightheadedness.   She has a medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes  both controlled with medication. She also suffered a bereavement a week ago  with the loss of her husband  which has caused profound emotional distress.  The clinical features and temporal nature of the symptoms raise suspicion for cardiac origin  specifically takotsubo cardiomyopathy  given the recent emotional stressor. Further cardiac investigation is required to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Williams  a 67-year-old Asian female  presents to the emergency department. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. She reports experiencing severe chest pain and shortness of breath since her husband suddenly died last week. The pain first started suddenly about an hour ago  radiating to her left arm and up to her neck. She rates it as 8 out of 10 in severity  worsening with activity.  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which she takes lisinopril  and major depressive disorder  for which she is prescribed escitalopram. She has no known drug allergies. There is a family history of heart disease  with her father having a heart attack in his 50s.  Upon physical examination  she appears distressed and diaphoretic. She is tachycardic with an irregular pulse  and her blood pressure is elevated. A 12-lead ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Lab tests reveal a slight increase in troponin levels.  Given the recent bereavement and the presentation mimicking an acute coronary syndrome  but without significant coronary artery disease found on angiography  the provisional diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome) is made. The diagnosis is later confirmed with echocardiography showing apical ballooning of the left ventricle.

Patient Presentation: A 72-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain radiating to her left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath. She reports the symptoms started approximately 3 hours ago while she was attending the funeral of her late husband. She also complains of palpitations and dizziness.  Past Medical History: She has a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  taking amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively. She has no history of angina  myocardial infarction or other heart diseases. She quit smoking 20 years ago and consumes alcohol occasionally.  Social History: The patient is a retired school teacher  lives alone after her husband's recent death. She has two adult children who live out of state.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Harriet Thompson Age: 69 years  Gender: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Living Situation: Lives alone  Chief Complaint: Mrs. Thompson presents to the emergency room with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. She describes the chest pain as severe  similar to ""a heavyweight is placed on my chest."" She also experienced fatigue over the last few days.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Thompson has a history of hypertension  for which she is on antihypertensive medication. She has no known history of cardiac disease. She also has a history of generalized anxiety disorder and is on anxiolytic medication.  Family History:  Her mother had a stroke in her late 70s. Her father died in his early 80s due to heart failure  and her paternal aunt died of breast cancer. She has one sister with type 2 diabetes.  Personal and Social History:  Mrs. Thompson is a widow for the past three years. She quit smoking 15 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. She lives alone and does yoga for her fitness. She recently underwent immense emotional stress after her only son moved out of the country.  Note: The presentation is characteristic of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a condition observed predominantly in postmenopausal women and often triggered by emotional or physical stress. The chest pain and shortness of breath experienced by Mrs. Thompson may be due to the left ventricle's transient dysfunction in this condition. The patient’s recent emotional stressor could be the trigger point for the onset of her symptoms. This requires immediate medical intervention and would necessitate further investigation  including echocardiogram and cardiac enzymes  to rule out other conditions such as acute myocardial infarction  which may present similarly.

Patient Presentation:  A 69-year-old Japanese-American female presents to the emergency department with a 2-hour history of severe chest pain. She describes her pain as a crushing sensation radiating down her left arm  resembling symptoms of a past heart attack she experienced 8 years prior. She also reports associated shortness of breath  nausea  and lightheadedness. She indicates a stressful incident happened at her home earlier in the day  that startled her and increased her anxiety level significantly.  She has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Past surgical history includes a hysterectomy over 20 years ago. Family history is significant for her father dying from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. She denies tobacco  alcohol or illicit drug use. Current medications include lisinopril 10mg daily and simvastatin 20mg daily.   This patient's symptoms  past medical history  especially given the recent emotional stress are concerning for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  despite resembling symptoms of acute coronary syndrome. Further investigation  such as an EKG and echocardiogram  may help differentiate between the two.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department alone.  Chief Complaint: ""Severe chest pain""  History of Present Illness: The patient reports that she suddenly started experiencing intense chest pain around 2 hours previously  which she describes as a crushing sensation in her chest that radiates to her left arm. She also reports feeling short of breath. On further questioning  she reveals that her husband passed away suddenly 2 weeks ago  and she has been under immense emotional stress since then.  Past Medical History: - No history of hypertension or diabetes - Non-smoker - Prior to her husband's death  she led a rather active lifestyle with regular exercise - No prior history of cardiac diseases - Cholesterol level in the normal range  Family History: - Father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 - Mother died of stroke at the age of 72  Review of Systems: - No recent illnesses or infections - No history of illicit drug use  On physical examination  the patient appears anxious  in visible distress  and tachycardic.  Conclusion: The sudden emotional stress  typical chest pain  past medical  and family history is suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken heart syndrome""). This condition is typically more common in post-menopausal women and can be precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress. Immediate further diagnostic and management action needs to be taken.

A 68-year-old  Caucasian female presented to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain that began suddenly approximately 2 hours ago. The patient described the pain as ""crushing"" and centralized in the mid-sternal region. Associated symptoms included diaphoresis  nausea  and difficulty breathing. The patient noted that she had been under intense emotional stress  as her husband passed away unexpectedly just a week ago and she has been dealing with the aftermath ever since.  The patient's past medical history reveals hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she has been taking amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively. There are no previous known cardiac-related issues.  The patient has a 10 pack-year smoking history  though she quit 15 years ago. She denies illicit drug use. She also reports consuming alcohol socially  effectively averaging one drink per week.  Family history is notable for her father who had a myocardial infarction in his early 60s. The patient works as an elementary school teacher and lives alone since her husband's recent passing. She expressed concerns about the symptoms resembling those of a ""heart attack.""  Her vitals are as follows: blood pressure 155/92 mmHg  pulse 110 bpm  respirations 22 rpm  temperature 37.1 degrees C  and O2 saturation 94% on room air. On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. There was no pedal edema. Cardiac exam revealed tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. ECG showed ST segment elevation in the anterolateral leads suggestive of a possible heart attack.  Based on her presentation and preliminary tests  she was admitted to the cardiac ICU for further management. Echocardiography and coronary angiography were scheduled. Despite the initial suspicion of a myocardial infarction  subsequent left ventriculogram revealed a distinctive apical ballooning pattern with preserved function at the base  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient was commenced on appropriate medical management with ACE inhibitors  beta blockers and reassured about the often transient and reversible nature of this condition  but warned about potential complications.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Hiroko  a 72-year-old Japanese woman presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset chest pain radiating towards her left arm. The chest pain started a few hours ago after hearing the news of her grandson's sudden death. She denies any shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or palpitations. However  she reports feeling lightheaded and anxious.   Mrs. Hiroko is a widow who lives alone since her husband's death five years ago. She is a retired school teacher with a history of controlled hypertension and normal lipid levels. She is a non-smoker with no known history of coronary artery disease  and her only other significant medical issue is controlled depression for which she takes escitalopram. Her family history is positive for hypertension and stroke  but negative for genetic or congenital heart conditions.  On further interrogation  she confirms having had similar milder episodes of chest pain in the past year  which were also precipitated by periods of intense emotional stress  but she did not seek medical attention as she attributed them to anxiety and “aging”.   This episode  however  is significantly more painful and prolonged than previous ones  which prompted her to seek immediate medical assistance.   Physical examination shows mild distress related to chest pain. Vitals are blood pressure 160/95 mm Hg  pulse 90 bpm regular  respiratory rate 18/min and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. The cardiac examination reveals normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. EKG shows ST segment elevation in the anterior leads. Her chest x-ray is unremarkable.   In this clinical scenario  the sudden severe emotional stress leading to acute chest pain  her age  gender  ethnicity  and ECG findings are suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or “broken heart syndrome"".   Management will include prompt initiation of heart failure treatment  emotional support and monitoring in a telemetry unit. She will also need an echocardiogram for confirmation of diagnosis and possible coronary angiography. Long-term management might involve beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors  as well as counseling or psychiatric intervention to help manage her stress and depression.

A 70-year-old Caucasian female presented to emergency services with severe chest pain  radiating down her left arm  which began suddenly while she was attending her husband's funeral. The chest pain was accompanied by shortness of breath and dizziness. She has a history of hypertension  but no known coronary artery disease  diabetes  or smoking history. She is widowed as of today  retired  and lives with her adult daughter. Her medications include Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg once daily  started 3 years ago.  On physical examination  she appeared distressed  was diaphoretic  and exhibited a regular heart rate 105 beats per minute  blood pressure of 150/90 MM hg  respiratory rate of 20/minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. No murmurs  rubs  or gallops were detected on auscultation.   An ECG showed diffuse ST-segment elevation and QT prolongation. Lab results showed troponin I elevated at 2.5 ng/ml with a normal creatine kinase-MB fraction  indicating myocardial injury.   Based on her acute emotional stress  typical chest pain  electrocardiographic changes  transient left ventricular apical ballooning demonstrated by coronary angiogram (without significant coronary artery stenosis)  and elevated cardiac biomarkers  a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart Syndrome) was made.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Garcia  a 68 year-old Hispanic woman  presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started about 2 hours ago as she was attending her husband's funeral. The pain is described as constricting and is rated as a 7 on a scale of 0-10. It is not relieved by rest and the patient denies any radiation of pain. In the past  she has been in generally good health and denies any past history of heart disease.  On physical examination  she appears in obvious discomfort  pale and in mild distress. Her blood pressure is markedly raised at 167/96 mmHg  pulse rate is 110 beats per minute and respiratory rate is 23 breaths per minute. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia but is otherwise unremarkable.  The patient reports that she has been feeling emotionally strained since her husband's sudden death. She denied any habits like smoking or intaking alcohol. Family history revealed her mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 75 years.  The classical chest pain  elevated blood pressure and triggering emotional stressor is quite suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as 'broken heart syndrome'. However  differential diagnoses could include acute coronary syndromes and pulmonary embolism. Further investigations including ECG  troponin testing  and echo-cardiogram are indicated at this point to confirm the diagnosis.

A 69-year-old African-American female presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  radiating to her left arm and jaw  with onset 2 hours ago. Associated symptoms include nausea  vomiting  breathlessness and bouts of lightheadedness. She has no known allergies. She denies smoking  illicit drug use  and only drinks alcohol occasionally.  Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication (Lisinopril and Rosuvastatin). She recently lost her husband to cancer one month ago  and she has been reporting high stress and feelings of depression since the event.   She has no family history of early heart disease. On examination  she appears distressed  with pulse rate 116 beats per minute  blood pressure 155/95 mmHg  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia but no murmur or gallop. Lung fields are clear on auscultation. The rest of her physical exam is unremarkable. An EKG shows nondescript ST segment elevation. Initial labs including complete blood count  renal function  liver function were within normal limits  but her troponin level was slightly elevated. The differential diagnosis includes acute coronary syndrome and stress cardiomyopathy or takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension and anxiety disorder presents to emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain and shortness of breath. These symptoms started unexpectedly after she received news of her adult son's death earlier in the evening. The pain is sharp and worst over the left side of her chest  constant  non-radiating  associated with palpitations and relieved partially by sitting forward. She states that she has never experienced such pain before.  She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. As per the patient  her mother had early onset coronary artery disease.  Examination features include: her blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg  pulse rate is 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. She appears anxious and diaphoretic. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with regular rhythm and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain that started an hour ago. She describes the pain as a pressure-like feeling and rates it as 8/10 in intensity. The pain is located in the center of her chest and radiates to her left arm.   Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which she takes Lisinopril  and major depressive disorder  controlled with Fluoxetine. She denies having any personal or family history of heart disease.   She lost her husband six months ago  which has likely worsened her depressive symptoms. In fact  she was at her weekly grief counseling session when she started experiencing the chest pain. She denies smoking  alcohol or illicit drug use. Her diet and exercise habits are described as balanced  with three well-rounded meals a day  moderate alcohol consumption  and a daily 30-minute walk.  This patient presentation suggests Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome. This condition is more common in postmenopausal women and can be triggered by intense emotional or physical stress. In this case  the loss of a loved one may have served as the emotional trigger for this patient. Notably  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can mimic symptoms of an acute coronary syndrome. Despite this  patients often have relatively preserved cardiac history  making this a challenging diagnosis.

A 62-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of major depressive disorder presents to the emergency department. She appears distressed and reports experiencing severe chest pain  which she describes as being similar to ""a heavy weight pressing down"" on her chest. The pain began suddenly when she received news about the death of her longtime friend about an hour ago. She also reports shortness of breath  palpitations  and lightheadedness. The patient denies any history of coronary artery disease. Current medications include Sertraline and occasional Lorazepam. She is a non-smoker and denies the use of any illicit drugs or excessive alcohol use. She has a family history significant for heart disease  her father died of a myocardial infarction at age 70. On arrival  her blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  heart rate is 105 bpm  and her ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Troponin levels are moderately elevated.

Patient Presentation:   A 72-year-old Asian female presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset chest pain. The patient describes the pain as a sharp sensation in the center of her chest that started an hour ago after receiving a distressing phone call about the unexpected death of her sister. She states that the pain radiates to her left arm and is associated with nausea and palpitations.   Past Medical History:   Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled with losartan  and was recently diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder.   She is widowed  lives alone  and her son visits her regularly. She used to work as a middle-school teacher before retiring 10 years earlier. She denies any history of smoking or alcohol use. She also denies any previous similar episodes. Her only family history of cardiovascular disease is a sister who died of an myocardial infarction in her late 60s.  Based on the demographic data and symptom onset following emotional stress  a provisional diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is suspected.   Note: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome "" often presents following emotional stress and predominantly affects older females.

A 62-year-old Asian woman presented to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath that had begun a few hours earlier. Patients reported symptoms were initially triggered after hearing unexpected and devastating news. The chest pain was central  heavy in character  and radiated to her left arm. It was associated with dizziness and aggravated by exertion  but relieved somewhat at rest. She denied any cough  embolic symptoms or orthopnea.  Her past medical history was relevant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with controlled diet and statin therapy. She denied any family history of cardiovascular disease but reported a smoking history of 20 pack-years. She reported a lack of physical activity and self-identified as a high-stress personality.   She has a history of major depression and anxiety disorder for which she had been receiving psychotherapy and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. The patient lived alone and recently the patient had been under significant psychosocial stress due to financial instability. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs.  Vital signs on admission showed blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  the heart rate of 105 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute  with oxygen saturation of 97% on room air  and a body mass index of 28. Physical examination was unremarkable except for a mildly irregular heartbeat on auscultation.  Based on her presentation  she was initially suspected to have an acute coronary syndrome; however  given her recent stressful life event  the lack of coronary artery abnormalities on angiography  and subsequent echocardiogram results showing apical ballooning - a picture consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy was formed.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Hernandez  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining of chest pain  shortness of breath  and a feeling of severe anxiety. She reports that her symptoms began earlier this morning. The patient's chest pain is described as squeezing and located in the middle of her chest. She rates it as 8 out of 10 in severity  adding that it radiates to her left arm and is accompanied by nausea.   The patient's past medical history reveals that she has hypertension managed with lisinopril. She denies a history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  or any other cardiac conditions. Her family history is unremarkable for cardiovascular diseases. Also  she has never smoked and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Ms. Hernandez recently experienced a significant amount of stress following the death of her husband just two weeks ago. She reports no allergies to medications.   The patient lives alone. She is retired teacher and doesn't follow any specific exercise regimen. Her diet is not strictly controlled and she admits to not always eating healthily - partly due to lack of appetite following her recent bereavement.   On examination  her blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg  heart rate is 110 beats per minute  and O2 saturation is at 96% on room air. She appears anxious and distressed. Cardiac auscultation reveals no abnormal heart sounds but there is mild tachycardia. Lung sounds are clear.  Given her symptoms  an electrocardiogram (ECG) and Troponin levels are ordered urgently to rule out acute coronary syndrome. The ECG displays ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  consistent with an acute event. Laboratory results return with elevated Troponin levels. Given the initial presentation and investigation results  an acute cardiac event is suspected. However  she does not have any major risk factors for CAD other than her age and hypertension.   With her recent emotional stress  an echocardiogram is ordered to further investigate  taking into account the possibility of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. The echocardiogram results show apical ballooning and systolic dysfunction of the left ventricle  which is consistent with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. She is admitted for further management by the cardiology team.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian female presents to the ER with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath. The pain started abruptly after receiving news of her husband's unexpected death. The patient describes the pain as similar to a 'heart attack' she experienced previously. On examination  she is anxious  diaphoretic  and appears acutely ill.  Her past medical history is significant for hypertension  and a previous myocardial infarction 2 years earlier  for which she underwent angioplasty and stenting. She is non-diabetic  non-smoker  and consumes alcohol in moderation. Her medications include aspirin  a statin  and a beta-blocker.  ECG on arrival shows ST-elevation in the precordial leads. An immediate cardiac enzyme test reveals mildly elevated Troponin levels. However  an emergency coronary angiography  initiated on the basis of suspected recurrent coronary artery disease  reveals no significant coronary artery blockage or plaque rupture.  The left ventriculography shows apical ballooning with hyperkinesis of the basal wall segments - suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This is further confirmed by echocardiographic findings.  The clinical picture is consistent with 'broken heart syndrome' or takotsubo cardiomyopathy  potentially precipitated by the intense emotional stress after the tragic news.

A 69-year-old Caucasian female patient presents to the emergency department reporting severe chest discomfort and shortness of breath beginning approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. She describes the pain as a heaviness in her chest that radiates to her left arm and jaw.   She is a widow who lost her husband 6 months ago and reports having recently undergone a high level of emotional stress due to this bereavement. She has a medical history of hypertension  for which she takes losartan  and hypercholesterolemia managed with atorvastatin. She has no history of coronary artery disease or other cardiac conditions.   She is potentially post-menopausal  as the majority of cases of takotsubo cardiomyopathy occur in post-menopausal women. She has no history of alcohol or tobacco use. Her family history indicates her father had myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and her mother lived up to 80 with no significant illness reported.  On initial physical examination  the patient appears anxious and distressed  she is diaphoretic  with a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 rpm  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air.  This patient's demographic and clinical presentation fits the typical profile for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which is most common in older women and often triggered by severe emotional stress. Her chest pain and shortness of breath  combined with her hypertension and stress  make her a high suspicion case for this condition.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. The patient reports that the symptoms started suddenly about two hours ago. She describes the chest pain as a feeling of pressure radiating down her left arm. She also has been feeling lightheaded and is almost short of breath.   Over the past week  she had been experiencing significant emotional stress due to the death of her husband. She has no history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia or diabetes. She does not smoke or consume alcohol.   On physical examination  her blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg  heart rate is 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Her lung fields are clear upon auscultation  and cardiovascular examination reveals soft S1 and S2 with no audible S3  S4  rubs  or murmurs.  Her electrocardiogram (EKG) initially displays transient ST-segment elevation followed by T wave inverted  which is highly suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further work-up including coronary angiogram does not detection of any significant blockages  confirming the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Her blood work shows mildly elevated cardiac enzymes.  This patient is thus exhibiting classic symptoms and risk factor (post-menopausal woman with a recent strong emotional stressor) consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. D  a 68-year-old Japanese female  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea. The chest pain started while she was attending a funeral earlier today  it is of severe intensity and crushing in nature. She also notes feeling light-headed and short of breath. The patient denies any past similar episode.  Her past medical history is relatively unremarkable with only treatment for osteoporosis and well-controlled hypertension in her medical record. She also has a notable history of generalized anxiety disorder  for which she has been taking an antidepressant. She states she does not smoke  rarely consumes alcohol  and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Upon arrival  she was notably anxious while her blood pressure was measured to be slightly low  at 105/65 mmHg  and heart rate was elevated at 102 beats per minute. Her ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  initating clinical suspicion for an acute myocardial infarction.  The patient lives alone since her husband died 6 years ago. She reports struggling with anxiety exacerbated by acute interpersonal stressors. Her son suggests that she has not been the same since the death of her husband. Today  while attending a funeral of an old friend  she complained of chest pain and felt light-headed  following which she was brought to the emergency department.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Asian female presents to the emergency department reporting severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating. The symptoms appeared suddenly around 2 hours ago  following news of her son's sudden death.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years  which is well controlled with medication. She also reports occasional migraine episodes over the past couple of years.  Contributing Factors:  The patient experienced an extreme emotional stress event just prior to the onset of her symptoms. She does not smoke or consume alcohol  and there's no family history of coronary artery disease. However  her eldest sister has a history of Tako-Tsubo cardiomyopathy  which was triggered by the sudden death of her husband.   Medication History:  The patient takes Lisinopril 10 mg once daily for hypertension and Sumatriptan as needed for migraine. She has no known drug allergies.  Social History:  She is a retired teacher  widowed  and lives with her eldest daughter who provides support. She reports having a good social support network.

A 68-year-old Asian woman presents to the Emergency Department. She describes sudden onset of severe chest pain that started about an hour ago. The pain is severe and radiating to her left arm. She also reports accompanying nausea and difficulty in breathing. She denies injury or trauma  but she mentions that she experienced intense emotional stress following a family dispute earlier in the day.   The patient’s past medical history is not significant for any cardiovascular illness. She has been diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder for the past 10 years for which she has been on an SSRI. She denies any history of smoking or illicit drug use  although she confesses to be a moderate drinker. Her maternal family history is remarkable for early myocardial infarctions.  Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 100 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. She appears visibly anxious and in distress. Her extraordinary anxiety  coupled with her chest pain  raises concern for an acute cardiovascular event. EKG  echocardiography and troponin levels are ordered immediately to evaluate for acute myocardial infarction. However  the results show classic signs of takotsubo cardiomyopathy with apical ballooning and contraction abnormalities of the left ventricular wall. Her coronary angiography is normal  ruling out the presence of obstructive coronary artery disease.   The diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is made based on her presentation and investigative findings. The cause is likely to be secondary to severe emotional stress that the lady experienced.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Ortiz is a 72-year-old Latina woman who presents today with complaints of severe  sharp chest pain that began acutely 2 hours ago while learning the death of her grandson. The pain has a heavy  crushing quality  and she has also experienced marked shortness of breath. Ms. Ortiz denies any associated symptoms and has had no previous instances of chest pain.   Past Medical History:  Ms. Ortiz has a history of well-controlled hypertension  for which she takes Lisinopril 10mg once daily. She also has untreated major depressive disorder for which she had been reluctant to seek treatment despite encouragement from her family and primary care physician. Besides her hypertension and depression  she has had a largely unremarkable medical history and she reports no history of smoking  alcohol abuse  or illicit drug use.  Surgical History:  Ms. Ortiz underwent a total hysterectomy at the age of 45 due to fibroids  but has had no other major surgical interventions.  Family History:  She reports her father died at 65 from a myocardial infarction and her mother died of breast cancer in her 60s. She has a brother with diabetes mellitus type-2.  Review of Symptoms:  Physical examination is largely normal. Besides chest pain and dyspnea  Ms. Ortiz also reports difficulty sleeping  lowered appetite  and feelings of intense sadness due to her recent family loss.   Recent Literature Review:  A literature review of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known ""Broken Heart Syndrome "" reveals a significant over-representation in post-menopausal women  typically precipitated by severe emotional stress  with physical stress also being a contributing factor. Although the initial symptoms mimic that of a myocardial infarction  tests typically reveal no evidence of coronary artery obstruction. The condition tends to develop in people more than 50 years of age. Ms. Ortiz's presentation is consistent with these findings.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Lopez  a 68-year-old Hispanic female  presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe  sudden onset of chest pain that radiates to her left arm. She also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and feeling light-headed. She denies any recent trauma  fever  cough  or dysuria.   Her medical history is significant for well-controlled type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a history of depression that worsened following the recent loss of her spouse. She has also been under significant stress of late due to ongoing financial concerns. She quit smoking 10 years ago and denies any history of illicit drug use.  Her vitals on presentation are: Blood Pressure- 165/90mmHg  Heart rate- 110/min  Respiratory rate- 24/min  Oxygen saturation- 92% on room air. Electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. An echocardiogram subsequently reveals a characteristic 'apical ballooning' suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   She does not report any family history significant for cardiac diseases. She is currently on Metformin for her diabetes and Lisinopril for her hypertension. She admits adherence to her medication regimen has been challenging since her spouse's passing due to elevated stress and poor mood.   Detailed examination and workup are planned to manage and assess the severity of her condition  with mental health support also being recommended due to the possible emotional triggers linked with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Linda is a 75-year-old Asian woman who hails from the urban area of Seattle  Washington  and is recently widowed. She has no significant past medical history  except for hypercholesterolemia  which has been treated with statins for the last five years. She does not have any personal or family history of heart disease and she is not a known diabetic. She was brought to the emergency room by her son after experiencing sudden onset  severe chest discomfort while hearing news about her daughter's grave illness.   The symptoms started around 4 hours prior to reaching the emergency room. According to her son  she was emotionally upset after receiving the news and has never experienced such discomfort before. The chest pain she described was mostly central and radiating up to the left side of her neck  saying it felt like ""something heavy sitting on her chest."" It was associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and profuse sweating. She denies any headache  palpitations  or loss of consciousness. She has never smoked and does not consume alcohol.   On examination  she appeared anxious and pale. She was experiencing rapid breathing  with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  her pulse was regular and her blood pressure was recorded as 155/95 mmHg. O2 saturation was maintained at 94% on room air. No abnormal cardiac  chest  or abdominal sounds were noted. Examination of other systems did not reveal any abnormalities.

Patient Presentation  Mrs. Fuentes is a 66-year-old Hispanic female presenting to the emergency room with severe chest pain and associated dyspnea. The pain started suddenly about an hour ago and has persisted  not alleviated by rest. She describes the pain as a squeezing and tight feeling in her chest  rating it as a 10/10 on the pain scale.   She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she takes Lisinopril and Simvastatin  respectively. She does not smoke or drink alcohol  and her BMI is within the normal range. She reports being under a significant amount of emotional stress  as her husband of 40 years recently passed away.  On examination  she appeared anxious and fatigued. She was mildly tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm and blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg.  Based on her symptoms  history  age  and stress factors  a tentative diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as Broken Heart Syndrome  is made. An urgent EKG and echocardiography are ordered to confirm the diagnosis. She also needs cardiac enzymes tested to rule out a myocardial infarction.

Patient Presentation  A 67-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset  severe chest pain radiating to her left arm and jaw  similar to the pain experienced during myocardial infarction. This pain was triggered by an intense fight with her family. She has occasional episodes of shortness of breath  and feelings of terror or impending doom. Past medical history revealed that the patient was living alone after the death of her husband 5 years ago and was diagnosed with major depressive and anxiety disorders 2 years ago. Moreover  it was found that the patient has hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  for which she takes regular medications. She had no prior history of coronary artery disease  and never smoked or consumed alcohol. She leads a life with moderate physical activity and has a history of intermittent non-specific chest pain  particularly during intense emotional stress. She underwent menopause at the age of 52. Her mother suffered from coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Japanese American woman with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency room. She describes experiencing sudden  severe chest pain localized in the middle of her chest. The pain began shortly after she received news of her husband's unexpected death earlier in the day. Her physical examination reveals tachycardia and mild hypertension. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevations and T-wave inversions  which may simulate an acute coronary syndrome. Troponin levels are also elevated.   With a high clinical suspicion and given the fact that her symptoms started immediately following a stressful event  the patient is subjected to coronary angiography. Angiography does not show any significant coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography instead shows a surprising finding: the base of the left ventricle is contracting normally  but the mid-portion and the apex of the heart are ballooning out during systole  giving rise to the characteristic 'octopus trap' appearance. Pulmonary and cardiac exam findings are consistent with acute heart failure  with bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation and an S3 heart sound.   The symptoms  EKG findings  elevated troponins  characteristic imaging findings  and triggering emotional stress strongly suggest the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.    Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension 2. No prior history of ischemic heart disease 3. Non-smoker and moderate alcohol intake 4. No significant family history of premature cardiovascular disease.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the ER with sudden  severe chest pain. She states the pain feels like a heavy pressure in the center of her chest radiating down her left arm. She also reports feeling slightly short of breath. The onset of symptoms was sudden and occurred following an argument with her family an hour ago. She has no known history of heart disease but has a history of hypertension controlled with medication and a 25-year history of smoking. She has never had any such chest pain before. She lost her spouse a year ago and lives alone since then. She had an episode of major depressive disorder following her husband's death. She does not take any illicit substances and drinks alcohol socially. She denies any palpitations  syncope  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  cough  or fever. Family history is positive for coronary artery disease in her deceased husband but negative in her parents and siblings. Her vital signs are stable but she looks physically distressed due to the pain. Physical exam is remarkable for a slightly elevated heart rate and an S4 gallop on auscultation. Considering her intense emotional stress  sudden onset anginal pain and differential diagnosis of coronary artery spasm versus takotsubo's cardiomyopathy  an immediate EKG and cardiac enzymes are ordered.

A 65-year-old Hispanic female  named Maria  comes to the Emergency Department reporting chest pain that radiates to her left arm. She discloses that she is a retired teacher and lives alone. She states that her symptoms began suddenly earlier in the day during an argument with her adult son and have been steady since. Maria rates her pain as an 8 out of 10 on the pain scale  stating that the discomfort feels like a heavy pressure. She also reports accompanying nausea and shortness of breath.   Maria has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She denies any history of heart disease or diabetes  but admits she has not been to a doctor in the last 5 years due to fear of receiving bad news. She also discloses that she recently lost her husband and has been under a great deal of emotional stress. She is a non-smoker and drinks red wine occasionally. Her paternal grandmother died of a heart attack at the age of 78  and her mother has diabetes.  Maria's vital signs show blood pressure 152/88 mmHg  heart rate 95 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation levels are at 93% on room air  and body temperature 98.7°F. The clinic rushes to get an EKG  which reveals ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  mimicking an acute myocardial infarction. However  surprisingly  her cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. Given the patient's presentation  an emergent cardiac catheterization is planned to rule out an acute coronary syndrome.
