She has a medical history of hypertension  for which she takes medication regularly  but no previous record of ischemic heart disease  diabetes  or high cholesterol levels. On presentation  no classical signs of an acute coronary syndrome are noted  but an ECG shows signs of myocardial injury. Diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is later confirmed through echo-cardiogram and cardiac MRI. She has no history of smoking or excessive alcohol consumption.

A 68-year-old African-American woman with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes and generalized anxiety disorder presents to the emergency department with sudden severe chest pain and shortness of breath after the recent passing of her husband. The pain radiates to the left arm and is accompanied by nausea  light-headedness  and diaphoresis. The patient denies drug or alcohol abuse. She had a stress test done two years prior which showed no signs of ischaemia. The patient also mentions she has been feeling slightly lethargic and has had decreased appetite over the past week  which she initially attributed to her emotional distress.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of major depressive disorder presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  central chest pain radiating to the left arm  accompanied by mild shortness of breath. She denies any triggering events  but states that she has been experiencing elevated psychosocial stress levels for the past month after the death of her husband. The pain onset was at rest and is similar to a ""heavy weight on her chest."" She denies fever  cough  orthopnea  or lower limb edema. On examination  she appears anxious and distressed. Vitals are stable; physical examination reveals no jugular venous distention or leg swelling. Initial electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation. Given her symptoms  demographic  and the high prevalence of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in postmenopausal women undergoing significant stress  this was considered high on the differential list.

An 68-year-old recently widowed Caucasian female presents with the sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin. She has no history of coronary artery disease but recently retired from a high-stress job as a corporate lawyer and has been dealing with significant loneliness since her husband's death. Patient also reports fatigue and minor palpitations. On examination  EKG shows ST-segment elevation. The subsequent troponin level is elevated and echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of generalized anxiety disorder and hypertension presents with sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. She also reports an acute episode of severe emotional stress and anxiety just prior to the onset of her symptoms. The pain is described as severe  located in the central chest  and radiating to her left arm. She rates her pain as 9 on a scale of 0-10. The associated symptoms include nausea  vomiting  and diaphoresis. She has no history of tobacco use or coronary artery disease but has been non-compliant with her anti-anxiety and antihypertensive medications over the past several months. On physical examination  she appears anxious with a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg  heart rate 110 bpm  and her ECG shows ST-segment elevation. Despite these signs suggestive of acute myocardial infarction  subsequent coronary angiography shows no significant coronary artery stenosis  but ventriculography reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old  post-menopausal  Caucasian woman with a history of hypertension and chronic anxiety  presenting with sudden onset atypical chest pain  shortness of breath  and syncope that began after receiving news of a loved one's sudden death. The patient also experienced nausea  palpitations  and general body weakness. Her blood pressure on presentation is 160/90mmHg  pulse rate is 110 beats per minute  and her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. An echocardiogram demonstrates apical hypokinesia suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. There are no known allergies or previous episodes of similar symptoms in the patient's medical history.

A 68-year-old caucasian woman presents to the clinic with complaints of severe and sudden chest pain radiating to her left arm  shortness of breath  and palpitations. The patient describes the pain as “heavy” and notes it began abruptly a few hours earlier. She endorses associated symptoms of nausea and diaphoresis. Her medical history is non-contributory with exception to hypertension for which she takes Hydrochlorothiazide. She further states experiencing severe emotional stress due to her husband's recent demise. On physical examination  her blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and her pulse is 95 beats per minute and regular. EKG shows ST segment elevation and T wave inversions in the inferior leads suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. With a leading differential diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  the patient is scheduled for an urgent echocardiogram. Ultimately  the findings reveal apical ballooning and hypercontractility of the basal segments  thereby confirming Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. She feels short of breath  light-headed and nauseous. She has a medical history significant for well-controlled hypertension but no history of ischemic heart disease. The patient has recently been under significant emotional distress due to the sudden demise of her spouse about a week ago. EKG shows ST-segment elevation. The troponin levels were significantly elevated. The patient was initially suspected for acute coronary syndrome  but the angiography showed absence of obstructive coronary artery disease. Echocardiography revealed left ventricular malfunction with the characteristic apical ballooning suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of mixed anxiety-depression disorder presenting with acute  severe chest pain occurring during her husband’s funeral. The pain is similar to a heart attack  described as a crushing type  centered in the middle of the chest and radiating to the left arm and neck. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  profuse sweating  light-headedness  and nausea. She has no history of heart disease  but was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago which is well-controlled with Lisinopril. She reports that she drinks occasional wine socially but has never smoked and does not use illicit drugs. She has no known drug allergies. The patient presents with signs of emotional distress. Her EKG features massive ST-segment elevation  albeit her coronary angiogram reveals no significant blockages. The echocardiography shows apical ballooning with a hyperactive basal segment  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old postmenopausal white female with a history of high blood pressure and recent severe emotional stress presents with sudden sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. She has no history of smoking or other significant cardiac risk factors  and no family history of heart disease reported. She notes that the chest pain started suddenly a few hours ago and it's been persisting since then. On physical examination  her blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg and she is tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm. The preliminary ECG shows ST-segment elevation and initial cardiac enzymes are elevated. The patient's symptoms resemble those of an acute coronary syndrome but the recent stress is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman presents with sudden and severe chest pain radiating to her left arm and shortness of breath. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  well-controlled with medication  and has been experiencing high stress levels due to a recent bereavement in the family. ECG reveals ST-segment elevation. Echo shows apical ballooning of the LV with preserved basal function  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often associated with emotional stress triggers.

A 68-year-old caucasian female with a history of hypertension and recent extreme emotional stress presents with sudden-onset  severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations. These symptoms started abruptly within a couple of hours of an emotionally traumatic event. She describes the pain as a crushing sensation radiating to her left arm  similar to a previous incident of myocardial infarction. She also reports symptoms of nausea and excessive sweating. The patient also has a history of major depressive disorder and was a smoker up until 4 years ago. Physical examination reveals tachycardia and no other significant findings.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female  with a past medical history of hypertension  presents with severe chest pain  similar to the sensation of myocardial infarction. The pain started suddenly 7 hours ago  and has persisted with similar intensity since. She describes the pain as a heavy pressure sensation  located in the center of her chest  radiating to the left arm  and associated with bouts of nauseousness and profuse sweating. The patient explains she has been under a tremendous amount of emotional stress due to the recent passing of her husband. She doesn't have any history of smoking  alcohol or illicit drug use. On physical examination  she appears sweaty and pale with an elevated heart rate. EKG shows elevation in ST-segment. Initially  it appears as a typical case of acute coronary event  but the angiogram doesn't reveal any significant blockages in coronary arteries. Hence  these symptoms and the history make takotsubo cardiomyopathy a strong consideration.

A 72-year-old Japanese woman presents with complaints suggestive of acute chest pain  shortness of breath and palpitation since the last 2 hours. She has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with atenolol and statins respectively. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has been under immense mental stress for the past 1 week due to some personal issues. Family history is significant for heart disease on the maternal side. A physical examination is notable for tachycardia and increased blood pressure. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads. Initial lab findings reveal slightly elevated cardiac markers. Further examination with echocardiography demonstrates apical ballooning of the left ventricle with normal base function  a picture consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of severe central chest pain radiating to her left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. She is a non-smoker and moderate drinker  has a medical history of well-controlled hypertension and anxiety  and reports having a major emotional stress event just prior to symptom onset. Her mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 75. Examination reveals a distressed woman with cold  clammy skin  heart rate of 100 BPM  blood pressure of 135/85 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. An ECG shows elevated ST segments in leads II  III  and aVF  and initial troponin is slightly elevated. She reports having similar  though less severe  symptoms previously  which resolved on their own.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain and discomfort. She has history of hypertension controlled with medication  non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus  and anxiety disorder. She reports her symptoms to be severe  episodic  and resembling ""a heavy weight on chest"". She denies any radiation of the pain. Her episode occurred after the death of her spouse a week ago  a situation which caused her great emotional distress. She has no history of smoking or drug use  and her family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. She has no prior hospitalizations for heart disease. Her ECG reveals subtle repolarization abnormalities and her initial troponin levels are mildly elevated.

A 70-year-old Caucasian female presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath following a severe emotional stress event. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both under control with medication. She denies history of heart disease or recent physical stressors. She has never previously experienced this type of chest pain. On physical examination  she appears anxious and pale. Heart rate is elevated  with blood pressure on the lower side. She also reports dizziness and fainting episode. EKG shows ST-segment elevation  but subsequent coronary angiography reveals normal coronary arteries. Echocardiogram displays a distinctive apical ballooning and contractile dysfunction  leading to the conclusion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy or “broken heart syndrome.”

A 65-year-old Asian woman with a past medical history of hypertension presents with sudden onset moderate-severe chest pain that started following an argument with her son  accompanied by shortness of breath  nausea  and significant perspiration. She has no known history of coronary artery disease and denies any typical cardiac risk factors  such as smoking  diabetes  or high cholesterol. On examination  blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  heart rate is 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Cardiac enzymes are elevated. The patient denies any previous similar episodes or known cardiac conditions. This case presentation suggests a working diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with acute onset severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and a sense of impending doom. She mentions the recent death of her spouse as a significant stressor. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension for which she is on a beta-blocker and ACE inhibitor. She has no history of cardiac disease. She has never smoked and consumes alcohol occasionally. She has a 3-day history of reduced appetite associated with feelings of sadness since her spouse's death. On examination  she is hypotensive  with clammy skin and looks frightened. Heart sounds are normal and lung fields are clear. An electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  raising the suspicion for an acute coronary syndrome. Relevant investigations include a transthoracic echocardiogram  coronary angiogram  and blood tests for cardiac biomarkers.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of hypertension and depression presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The symptoms began suddenly during a heated argument with a family member. She also has nausea and palpitations. She denies illicit drug use or excessive alcohol use. She has been predominantly managing her stress and anxiety with group therapy and mindfulness meditation for the last 20 years. Her medications include an antidepressant  SSRI  and a beta-blocker. On examination  she appears anxious and there is resting tremor in her hands. She reports the chest pain as severe  similar to intense heartburn  radiating to the left arm. Blood pressure is 150/90  pulse 100 and regular  respiration 18  and oxygen saturation is 96% on air. An EKG shows ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) pattern. However  given the presentation  there is concern for takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old Caucasian woman presents with acute onset of chest pain at rest  rising anxiety and severe dyspnea. Her past medical history includes hypertension and major depressive disorder. Physical examination reveals diaphoresis  tachycardia and hypotension. Her electrocardiogram shows ST segment elevation in the anterolateral leads  troponin is elevated and echocardiography demonstrates apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal function  suggesting takotsubo cardiomyopathy. No recent stressful physical or emotional incidents were reported in the patient's history.

A 70-year-old Caucasian woman presents with severe  sudden chest pain resembling a heart attack. Her medical history includes postmenopausal status and a prior history of anxiety disorder. She reports that she has been under an increased level of emotional stress due to a recent bereavement. Her symptoms started suddenly  shortly after receiving news of a close family member's unexpected death. On a scale of 1-10  she rates her pain a 9  describing it as a crushing sensation. She reports feeling light-headed  excessively fatigued  and short of breath  which are uncharacteristic symptoms for her typical anxiety episodes. She has neither a personal history of coronary artery disease  nor a family history of early heart disease. She reports good compliance with her prescribed SSRI  exercises regularly  and abstains from tobacco  illicit drugs  and alcohol use.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department accompanied by her daughter. The patient reports a sudden onset of severe chest pain and difficulty breathing which started two hours ago. She also reports feelings of extreme emotional distress  having just learnt of the sudden death of her longtime friend. Her past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension and unremarkable for cardiovascular diseases. She denies any history of smoking  alcohol consumption  or illicit drug use. She has no known history of coronary artery disease or previous myocardial infarction.  On examination  the patient appears distressed. Vital signs show tachycardia and mild hypertension. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation. However  subsequent cardiac catheterization does not reveal significant coronary artery disease that could explain the ECG changes and her severe symptoms. High levels of cardiac biomarkers in the blood suggest a heart problem. An echocardiogram and ventriculogram reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle  leading to the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy. The patient’s severe emotional stress and the cardiac findings in the absence of significant coronary artery disease are key features supporting this diagnosis.

A 72-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian woman presents with acute chest pain and dyspnea that mimics myocardial infarction (MI). She has a recent history of severe emotional stress due to the sudden death of her spouse. Her medical history reveals she is not suffering from any systemic illnesses and no history of cardiac disorders. Her vitals are unstable with a BP of 140/90 mmHg  pulse at 105bpm  and irregular. ECG shows ST-segment elevation and Troponin levels are elevated. She reports no smoking or drinking habits. The recurrent emotional stress and clinical presentation suggest a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old  post-menopausal Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension and recent intense emotional stress presents with chest pain  shortness of breath and fatigue. There has been a significant event in her life; the sudden death of her spouse occurred 1 week ago. These symptoms have been progressive  starting mildly but now severe enough to impair her daily activities. She describes her chest pain as sharp  located in the middle of her chest  of sudden onset and radiating to her left arm. She denies any associated nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or diaphoresis. However  she feels lightheaded upon standing and reports feeling extremely anxious. Her blood pressure is slightly elevated. She has no known drug allergies or family history of cardiomyopathy. The recent severe emotional stress is a suggestive factor for takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old  post-menopausal  Caucasian female with a history of depression and anxiety presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and nausea. She underwent a traumatic life event a week ago - loss of her spouse. On arrival  her heart rate is 100 bpm  blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg  Temp - 98.0°F. EKG shows ST segment elevations and QT prolongation  but subsequent cardiac enzyme tests are normal. Echocardiogram reveals hypokinesis of the mid and apical segments of the left ventricle  providing the classic ""Takotsubo"" or ""octopus pot"" appearance. This presentation is suspicious for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old post-menopausal  Caucasian woman presents to the emergency room with acute onset severe chest pain after having suddenly found out that her husband had suddenly passed away. Her past medical history is relevant for mild hypertension  well-controlled on hydrochlorothiazide  and no other known heart disease. She is a non-smoker and denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. Her family history is unremarkable for sudden cardiac deaths or other heart diseases. On presentation  the patient appears diaphoretic and fearful  her blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg with a heart rate of 110 bpm. The ECG shows ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads consistent with an acute anterior myocardial infarction  but subsequent cardiac biomarkers are minimal. A coronary angiogram shows no significant coronary artery disease  but a ventriculogram demonstrates focal ballooning of the apex of the left ventricular consistent with a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient is treated with supportive care and makes a full recovery.

A 68-year-old African American woman presents with acute chest pain and shortness of breath following the unexpected death of her husband. She also reports feelings of extreme stress and anxiety. Her medical history includes hypertension  managed with medication  and a previous diagnosis of depression. She has no known history of coronary artery disease. Physical examination reveals tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. EKG suggests ST-segment elevation  raising suspicion for acute myocardial infarction. However  coronary angiography shows no obstructive coronary artery disease. Echocardiography reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle  leading to a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This patient's presentation is consistent with the stress-induced onset of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome""  which is notably more common in postmenopausal women.

A 68-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset severe chest pain  similar to a heart attack  after witnessing a traumatic car accident. She also reports alarming dyspnea and emotional shock due to the situation. Her medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and no history of obstructive coronary artery disease but has never had an anxiety disorder or other related psychological illnesses. She has no other relevant medical history and does not smoke or drink alcohol excessively. On physical examination  the patient appears visibly distressed and is diaphoretic. Vital signs reveal tachycardia and slightly elevated blood pressure. These symptoms suggest a diagnosis of acute-onset Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  commonly associated with severe emotional stress.

A 68-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian woman presents with acute onset severe chest pain and dyspnea. The pain began suddenly while she was at her husband's funeral. Her medical history reveals hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she is on medication. However  she has no history of coronary artery disease or valvular heart disease. She is a non-smoker and maintains a relatively healthy lifestyle. She reports a history of significant life stressors  including the recent death of her spouse. On examination  she appears acutely ill and distressed. On auscultation  there are faint heart sounds with no audible murmurs  and lung fields reveal diffuse crackles. Her electrocardiogram (ECG) displays ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads and her lab results show a mild elevation in troponin levels. Early echocardiography suggests apical ballooning of the left ventricle  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"".

A 68-year-old postmenopausal Asian woman presents to the emergency department for sudden onset of chest pain. The discomfort is described as tightness across the chest associated with shortness of breath. She reports a significant life stressor three weeks ago with the loss of her husband after battling with cancer. She has history of hypertension controlled with diuretics for the past 10 years. No history of CVD  smoking  diabetes mellitus  or hyperlipidemia is reported. On initial examination  her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg and heart rate is 102 beats per minute. Electrocardiogram shows no ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction but presents mild QT prolongation. Her troponin levels are elevated suggesting myocardial injury. Her symptoms along with the test findings and history of a significant stressful event are suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old widowed Caucasian woman presented with severe acute chest pain radiating to the neck  similar to previous angina pain experiences. She also reported experiencing shortness of breath and palpitations occurring for the past several hours. These symptoms started at her husband's funeral three days before. Her medical history includes well-controlled hypertension (on lisinopril)  previous episodes of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation  subclinical hypothyroidism  and a recent diagnosis of major depressive disorder. She has no history of coronary artery disease and is a life-long non-smoker. Her chest pain is described as constant  dull aching and is associated with lightheadedness and sweating. Physical examination shows sinus tachycardia but no evidence of congestive heart failure. Her blood pressure is within normal range. Initial EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  which are disproportionate to the relatively minor elevation in troponin levels.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a history of hypertension and anxiety presents to the ED with sudden  severe chest pain  akin to a reported 'heavy weight on the chest ' accompanied by lightheadedness and dyspnea. The pain started 2 hours ago  following an intense argument with a family member. She has no history of prior cardiac disease but mentions her recent stressful events. Physical examination is significant for tachycardia and diaphoresis. ECG reveals an elevation of ST-segment in precordial leads  yet there's no evidence of obstructive coronary artery disease on angiography. Thus  presenting a picture consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  dyspnea  profuse sweating  and feelings of impending doom. She describes the pain as squeezing and states it began a few hours ago when she found out her husband suddenly passed away. She has never experienced this type of chest pain before. She has a medical history of well-controlled hypertension and no known history of coronary artery disease. She takes hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg once daily and denied tobacco  alcohol  and illicit drug use. She has no previous surgeries and her family history is insignificant for heart disease. Vital signs show sinus tachycardia  slightly elevated BP  and elevated respiratory rate. EKG indicates changes suspicious of an acute coronary syndrome. Further lab work reveals elevated cardiac enzymes. Despite the clinical picture being suggestive of an AMI  subsequent cardiac angiography discloses clean coronary arteries  giving an indication towards Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath which has started a few hours ago. The pain radiates to her left arm and is associated with nausea  vomiting  and profuse sweating. She describes the pain as similar to a ""heart attack"". Her past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her husband passed away a month ago  and she reports having been under a significant amount of emotional stress since then. She has no known allergies and is currently on hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. She denies tobacco  alcohol  and illicit drug use. Physical examination reveals tachycardia and increased respirations. The patient appears anxious  yet she is alert and oriented to person  place  and time. Her blood pressure is at the higher range of normal. ECG shows depression of ST-segments but no prior Q-waves. Troponin T levels are moderately elevated. Based on the aforementioned symptoms  labs  and described recent emotional stress  a preliminary diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome) is strongly suspected. Admission  further cardiac testing  and psychological support are indicated.

A 68-year-old  postmenopausal Asian woman presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and shortness of breath which started earlier today. She has a history of hypertension  for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide. She denies tobacco  alcohol or drug use. Additional medical history is unremarkable. Significant events recorded in her social history include the recent death of her spouse. The patient's symptoms started shortly after the aforementioned event. She described the pain as similar to a ""heart attack"". On examination  she appeared severely distressed. Her blood pressure was elevated at 165/90 and she had tachycardia. She reported no prior similar episodes. EKG showed ST segment elevation. Initial workup including chest X-Ray and blood tests are pending. The patient's presentation is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy also known as broken heart syndrome.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Her medical history revealed no prior cardiovascular disease  but she has been experiencing severe emotional stress after the sudden death of her husband a week ago  without other known triggers. Apart from chest discomfort  she also manifests symptoms consistent with acute coronary syndrome  including fatigue  palpitations  lightheadedness  and weakness. She also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus but is not currently under treatment for her psychosocial stress. The patient's symptoms  coupled with her recent severe emotional distress  have led to the suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  or stress-induced cardiomyopathy  which typically affects postmenopausal women.

A 67-year-old postmenopausal female with a history of hypertension and anxiety presents with sudden severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and sweating. She has no known history of coronary artery disease  and her symptoms started shortly after receiving news of a close relative's death  triggering severe emotional stress. Clinical examination shows signs of acute heart failure  and initial ECG results show ST-segment elevation in the anterior precordial leads  mimicking an acute myocardial infarction. However  coronary angiography reveals no significant coronary stenosis. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular apical ballooning with preserved basal function consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Lab studies show a moderate increase in cardiac troponin. This clinical presentation is suggestive of stress-induced (takotsubo) cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the ER with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with medication. She denies history of heart disease or stroke. She reports intense psychological stress due to the recent loss of her husband. The severity of the chest pain has increased over the past few hours  is described as a severe squeezing sensation  and is accompanied by a sense of impending doom. She denies associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or dizziness. On physical examination  patient appears distressed and diaphoretic. Vital signs are stable. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Based on clinical presentation  the patient's symptoms raise the suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old woman of Japanese descent presents with acute chest pain and dyspnea. She reports to have experienced severe emotional stress recently due to her husband's death. She has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which have been managed with medication for the past 5 years. She has no known history of coronary artery disease and has never smoked. She appears anxious  and on physical examination  she has tachycardia and tachypnea. Her blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. EKG reveals ST-segment elevation  and troponin levels are moderately raised. The patient's symptoms and EKG changes are suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction; however  coronary angiography reveals non-obstructive coronary arteries  which are typical in takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Later  echocardiogram shows apical ballooning and contractile dysfunction of the left ventricle  which are consistent with the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.

A 68-year-old  post-menopausal Caucasian female with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started suddenly following a significant personal loss. She denies any prior history of heart disease. The patient also reported being under intense stress for the past couple of months due to various personal issues. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Family history is positive for coronary artery disease. On examination  she appears anxious and is diaphoretic. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia and a BP of 160/90 mmHg. ECG reveals ST-segment elevations in anterior leads. Her chest pain and physical findings are indicative of an acute coronary syndrome  however  angiography shows no significant coronary artery stenosis. Echo shows apical ballooning with preserved basal function. The clinical and investigative findings of stress-induced cardiomyopathy  also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  are consistent with her presentation and recent history of emotional stress. She has no known allergies and takes medication for her high blood pressure.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  symptoms experienced for the first time. She describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation radiating down her left arm. Prior to the onset  she had a major emotional stressor – she witnessed an accident involving her grandson. She has a known medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she is on treatment. No history of smoking or illicit drug use. Her family history adduces no premature coronary artery disease or sudden cardiac death. Examination shows tachycardia and an elevated blood pressure. As per literature  incidence of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is predominantly higher in postmenopausal women  often triggered by severe emotional stress.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the hospital with acute chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient has a significant past medical history of major depressive disorder  generalized anxiety disorder  and hyperlipidemia. She reports the chest pain began suddenly after hearing about her husband's unexpected death. On presentation  the patient has marked distress  pain radiating from chest to left arm  dizziness  and nausea. EKG shows ST segment elevation  and troponin levels are elevated. Echocardiogram reveals apical ballooning of the left ventricle  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 65-year-old widow with a history of hypertension presents to the ER with acute onset of chest pain  radiating to the left arm  and shortness of breath for the past three hours. She reports that she has been under significant psychological stress since her husband's death 6 months ago. She denies history of smoking  diabetes  or any known heart disease. On presentation  examination reveals a scared woman  pale and moderately dyspneic  with elevated blood pressure and heart rate. There were no clinical signs of heart failure. Lab tests reveal moderately elevated troponin and normal serum lipid profile. An EKG shows ST-elevation in leads V2-V3  but coronary angiography did not show any significant coronary atherosclerosis. An echocardiogram indicates left ventricular apical ballooning  leading to the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension who presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain and dyspnea. The pain started while she was attending her son's funeral. She describes the pain as a heavy crushing sensation  radiating to her left arm. She also reports dizziness and nausea. There is no prior history of cardiac diseases. She is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol user. She had menopause at age 52 and is on medication for hypertension. Her mother had myocardial infarction at the age of 74. She has been under considerable emotional stress due to the recent passing of her son. On initial examination  she appears anxious  with elevated blood pressure  tachycardia  and diaphoresis. ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  suggestive of anterior wall myocardial ischemia.  Considering the emotional stress she was under  her gender  age  and presenting symptoms  the provisional diagnosis is Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome). This is a condition typically seen in post-menopausal women induced by acute emotional stress  and mimics a heart attack  but coronary angiography often shows no significant blockages. In this patient  stress echocardiography or coronary angiography are advisable to confirm the diagnosis.

A 68-year-old  postmenopausal Caucasian female presents with symptoms suggestive of a heart attack  including severe chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  and anxiety. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia; she denies any history of smoking or substance abuse. There's been no documentation of familial heart-related issues. Patient's stress levels have been significantly high due to the recent death of her husband. EKG shows ST-segment elevation and lab tests show slightly elevated cardiac enzymes. However  coronary angiogram reports no significant blockages in the coronary arteries. Based on these findings  she is diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of rheumatoid arthritis and anxiety disorder presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. She reports experiencing a sudden emotional shock earlier in the day  after hearing the news of her husband's sudden death. The chest pain started abruptly and is characterized as a severe heaviness in the middle of her chest  radiating to her left arm  associated with nausea  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impeding doom. Physical exam reveals hypertension and tachycardia. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  aVF and V4 to V6. Her troponin level is elevated. She has no known history of coronary artery disease.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal female with a medical history of hypertension and anxiety presents with acute onset  severe chest pain  similar to symptoms she experienced in a previously diagnosed panic attack. She explains that she recently suffered significant emotional trauma due to the death of her spouse. Despite her typical antihypertensive therapy  her blood pressure is unusually high at presentation. An EKG demonstrates ST-segment elevation  mimicking an acute myocardial infarction. However  the patient's cardiac markers are only mildly elevated. Echocardiography reveals left ventricular apical ballooning without any obstructive coronary disease  suggesting a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 71-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started this morning. She has a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are managed with amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. No known history of ischemic heart disease. She has experienced a significant stress event two days ago  with the sudden death of her son. Physical examination reveals mild distress  tachypnea  and slightly elevated blood pressure. No other significant findings. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation. There are minor elevations in cardiac enzymes. Initial working diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) made. Later  cardiac catheterization showed no significant coronary artery disease. An echocardiogram revealed reduced ejection fraction with apical ballooning  consistent with a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome).

Problem Representation:  A 72-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian woman with a past medical history of hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain. She has been under considerable emotional stress for the past few weeks due to the recent death of her husband. On further questioning  she describes the pain as a crushing sensation in the middle of her chest  similar to symptoms associated with a heart attack. She denies any prior history of coronary artery disease. The pain is associated with shortness of breath and palpitations but there is no radiating pain  nausea  fever  or productive cough. Her blood pressure on presentation is 140/90 mmHg and the ECG shows ST-segment elevation.  This patient's profile is consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome)  a condition commonly observed among older women exposed to severe emotional stress. The patient's features are coherent with the typical demographics for this condition. Her chest pain and elevated ST-segment consistent with acute coronary syndromes but lack of coronary artery disease history suggest a nonischemic etiology  which supports the suspicion of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Further investigations (e.g.  echocardiogram or cardiac MRI) are needed to confirm the diagnosis.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman with a past medical history of hypertension and generalized anxiety disorder presents with chest pain  dyspnea  and light-headedness which started earlier that day during an extremely stressful event. She denies any past cardiac issues  but notes that she feels like she is having a heart attack. The pain is central and radiating to the left arm. Upon admission  patient was anxious and distressed  vital signs indicate tachycardia and mild hypotension. An electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. Troponin levels are significantly elevated. Based on her symptoms  high stress situation  and initial diagnostic elements  takotsubo cardiomyopathy is highly suspected.

A recently widowed 68-year-old Caucasian female  previously healthy  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Patient also reported feeling lightheaded with intermittent palpitations. She reports the onset of symptoms to be following a stressful call about finalizing her late husband's affairs. She does not smoke or drink  and does not have a family history of heart disease. Physical examination reveals mild tachycardia. EKG shows ST elevations in the anterior leads. Due to her age  gender  and the emotional stress preceding symptom onset  there is a high suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal Caucasian female with a past medical history of anxiety disorder presents with complaints of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for 3 hours. She reports experiencing extreme emotional stress earlier in the day due to the loss of her spouse. On presentation  she appears ill  anxious  and dyspneic. She has diaphoresis and vital signs indicate tachycardia and elevated blood pressure. Her ECG depicts ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Echocardiography shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal function  findings consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome. She denies habits of smoke or alcohol intake. Her medication list includes an SSRI and occasional use of lorazepam.

A 72-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and a significant recent life stress presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain associated with respiratory distress. She also reports associated symptoms of nausea  lightheadedness  and generalized weakness. She denies any alcohol or illicit substance use. Patient's vitals indicated predominant tachycardia and significantly elevated blood pressure. ECG demonstrates deep T wave inversions with long QT interval and cardiac markers are elevated suggestive of myocardial injury. These symptoms are suggestive of a provisional diagnosis of late onset  stress-induced takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female patient with a history of generalized anxiety disorder and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath after hearing of the sudden death of her son. The pain is centralized and is described as ""crushing"" in nature  extending to her left arm. She's pale and sweating. She reports associated nausea and vomiting. The neighborhood where she lived has reported a high crime rate  leading to high-stress levels for the patient. Her EKG shows ST-segment changes suggestive of anterior ischemia. Her symptoms and presentation are highly suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (stress-induced cardiomyopathy or broken-heart syndrome).

A 67-year-old  postmenopausal Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden  severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  shortness of breath and nausea. The pain began shortly after hearing of her husband's unexpected death. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  but she has no known history of ischemic heart disease  diabetes or lung disease. Prior to this  she had been living independently and was physically functional. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. On examination  she appears anxious and distressed. Vital signs show blood pressure of 160/92 mmHg  heart rate of 112 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. The cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia but is otherwise unremarkable. There's no history of catheterization  and current EKG findings show ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. Troponin levels are also elevated.

A 67-year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and depression presents to the ED with severe chest pain radiating to her back and left arm. The onset was sudden and coincided with the news of her spouse's sudden death. She denies any recent illness  drug history or alcohol abuse. On physical examination  she appeared anxious and was diaphoretic. Vital signs on presentation included blood pressure of 165/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Her EKG reveals ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads with deep T-wave inversions. Echocardiogram illustrated apical ballooning with preserved basal function  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This provisionally diagnoses her with suspected Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"" triggered by significant emotional stress.

A 68-year-old post-menopausal Caucasian woman presents with sudden onset chest pain  dyspnea  and palpitations. She has a known history of hypertension under treatment with diuretics  but is otherwise in good health and does not smoke or drink alcohol. She reports an episode of intense emotional stress she experienced two days prior. It is observed that the chest pain mimics that of a myocardial infarction. On physical examination  vital signs are within normal limits excluding a slightly elevated blood pressure. Consistent ST-segment elevation is noted on a 12-lead EKG  further complicating the differential diagnosis. Subsequent blood tests show small rise in Troponin levels indicating potential heart tissue damage. An echocardiography demonstrates distinctive wall motion abnormalities typical of takotsubo cardiomyopathy indicating apical ballooning and reducing left ventricular function. Her detailed personal history reveals no notable family history of heart disease or other systemic medical illnesses. The overall clinical presentation is consistent with that of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old widowed Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and anxiety disorder presents with symptoms of acute chest pain and breathlessness. She reports that these symptoms started suddenly about six hours ago and has not experienced such symptoms before. She mentions the recent death of her only son which has caused her significant emotional distress. Her vitals reveal an elevated heart rate and blood pressure. ECG changes are suggestive of ST-segment elevation. Laboratory findings show raised levels of cardiac biomarkers. She has no history of smoking  alcohol consumption or drug abuse. This clinical presentation is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome).

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Major Depressive Disorder (MDD)  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe central chest pain and moderate difficulty breathing that had started a few hours after she had learned about her spouse's sudden death. She rates the chest pain as 8 out of 10  describing it as a constant  crushing pressure that radiates to her left arm. She also has associated symptoms of nausea  faintness  and cold sweats. These symptoms were not alleviated by rest or nitroglycerin. She does not report any personal or family history of heart disease but has been under significant emotional stress since her husband's sudden passing. She also experiences palpitations but denies any syncope or presyncope. Her medications include an SSRI and amlodipine. She is a non-smoker and denies alcohol or illicit drug use.

A 70-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension  depression and recent bereavement presents with acute chest pain and shortness of breath. The chest pain is severe  left-sided  and radiates to the left shoulder. Accompanied by nausea  diaphoresis  and lightheadedness  the symptoms started suddenly while she was attending her husband’s funeral. She has no known history of smoking or other substance abuse. She denies previous similar episodes or family history of heart diseases. She is on medications for hypertension and depression. Initial EKG suggests ST elevations in anterior leads and Troponin levels are elevated. Echocardiogram and subsequent cardiac catheterization reveal apical ballooning but no significant coronary artery disease  leading to a working diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It is suspected that her recent intense emotional stress has precipitated this condition known as ‘broken-heart syndrome’. She will be managed with supportive therapy and close monitoring.

A 72-year-old Asian female presents with chest pain  and a feeling of lightheadedness. She has a history of hypertension  but no history of coronary artery disease. Her symptoms started abruptly  coinciding with the recent death of her spouse. She repots that the chest pain is severe  radiates down to her left arm and resembles the symptoms she's been told to watch for as signs of a heart attack. She's in distress but vitals are relatively stable: BP 136/85  HR 92  O2 98% on room air. She appears to be a nonsmoker and doesn't consume alcohol. EKG shows ST segment elevation  and elevated cardiac enzymes (troponin) are noted. She is diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome)  most likely induced by extreme emotional stress associated with the loss of her husband.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal Asian woman presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath following an episode of severe emotional stress. The patient has a history of hypertension that is well-controlled with medication. On presentation  the patient appears visibly distressed and uncomfortable but maintains stable vitals. She describes her chest pain as a general constriction  also saying it feels as if ""an elephant was sitting on my chest"". Electrocardiogram reveals ST-segment elevation  and initial blood tests show elevated cardiac enzymes  suggestive of a myocardial infarction. However  further cardiac catheterization reveals a distinct pattern of regional wall motion abnormality  specifically a decrease in left ventricular function with apical ballooning and basal hypercontractility which are characteristic of a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old  post-menopausal Asian woman  non-smoker  with a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and chronic anxiety disorder  presents to the ED with severe onset of chest pain  radiating to the left shoulder. She reports experiencing a highly stressful event earlier in the day. She has no family history of early cardiac disease. On physical examination  she is visibly distressed  has normal heart sounds with no murmur  stable blood pressure  but electrocardiogram reveals changes suggestive of anterior wall ischemia. Labs reveal a slightly above normal troponin level.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started an hour ago. She denies any recent trauma  drug use  or significant travel history. She has a past medical history of hypertension and suffered a bereavement of a close family member two weeks ago. Vital signs are stable; however  she appears distressed. On cardiovascular examination  there is no evidence of any murmurs  gallops or rubs. Electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation. Laboratory studies reveal elevated troponin levels. The patient's symptoms  coupled with the reported stressful event and the absence of significant coronary artery disease  raise the suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old Caucasian female patient presents with sudden  severe chest pain  dyspnea  fatigue  and palpitations  symptoms which started an hour after learning of her daughter's death. She has a past medical history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She currently takes amlodipine and ibuprofen as needed. She has no history of tobacco or alcohol use and has a family history of coronary artery disease with both parents suffering from myocardial infarctions in their late 60s. She has no history of heart disease herself and no previous similar complaints. Her EKG shows changes typical of an acute coronary syndrome; however  cardiologists find apical ballooning and normal coronary arteries on left ventriculography  leading to the diagnosis of suspected takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year-old post-menopausal woman with a history of hypertensive cardiovascular disease and major depressive disorder presents with sudden onset severe chest pain  palpitation  and shortness of breath following a stressful event in her life. Her blood pressure is found to be elevated compared to her baseline. An ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. Her symptoms suggest acute coronary syndrome  but cardiac catheterization reveals no significant coronary occlusion but a distinctive pattern of left ventricular dysfunction with apical ballooning suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain  radiating to left arm  and associated shortness of breath that started two hours ago. Patient reports that her symptoms started suddenly when she heard the news of her son being severely injured in a car accident. She has never experienced similar symptoms before. She has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and generalized anxiety disorder. Her current medications include lisinopril  atorvastatin  and sertraline. She has a 20 pack-year history of smoking  but she quit 15 years ago. She denies recreational drug use or alcohol consumption. On presentation  her vital signs are stable except for elevated blood pressure (160/95 mmHg). Initial ECG shows ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. Emergency coronary angiography reveals absence of obstructive coronary artery disease. Echocardiogram demonstrates apical ballooning pattern and reduced left ventricular function suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with acute-onset chest pain and shortness of breath following a severe emotional stressor: the recent death of her spouse. She has a relevant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well-controlled with medication. She denies any history of previous heart disease. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. On presentation  she appears anxious and distressed. The chest pain is described as severe  centralized  crushing in nature  and without radiation. It began at rest and has persisted for approximately 4 hours. She rates the pain as an 8 on a scale of 0 to 10. Accompanying symptoms include cold sweats  nausea  and lightheadedness  but she denies any loss of consciousness. Her vital signs on admission show tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg. Preliminary ECG study shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Upon further questioning  the patient reveals experiencing extreme emotional stress  grief and associated insomnia since her spouse's death. Given the presenting symptoms  emotional trigger  and the initial diagnostic findings  the clinical suspicion of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome) is high.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a significant history of anxiety disorder presents with recent onset of abrupt  severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She reports feeling stressed for the past few weeks due to personal issues  stating her symptoms began during a heightened episode of intense emotional trauma. She has no known history of coronary artery disease  and she denies any past cardiac problems. She has never smoked  is a moderate drinker  leads a physically active life  has a balanced diet  and has a familial history of cardiovascular diseases. Her physical exam is notable for elevated heart rate and blood pressure  and EKG shows ST-segment elevation. Troponin levels are also increased. Her symptoms resemble acute myocardial infarction  but given the atypical patient profile and specific circumstances  a suspected diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome) is made.

A 71-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia presents with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath following a sudden stressful event. The pain is similar to the one described in myocardial infarction but investigations do not show any signs of obstructive coronary artery disease. Electrocardiography reveals ST-segment elevation. The echocardiogram shows apical ballooning and reduced ejection fraction consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Patient reports having experienced a similar episode following a stressful event 2 years ago but did not seek medical attention then. Her current stress tests are normal and troponin levels are mildly elevated. She is currently taking lisinopril and atorvastatin for her hypertension and hyperlipidaemia.

A 72-year-old Caucasian female with a history of depression and anxiety is presenting with symptoms of chest pain  palpitations  fainting and shortness of breath. The patient's symptoms occurred suddenly after receiving news of her husband’s death. She has hypertension that is managed with medication. Furthermore  she does not have a history of alcohol consumption or smoking  and lives with her daughter. Her family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her mother. Currently  she is experiencing severe stress and grieving. These symptoms are suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. This clinical picture is consistent with the demographic generally affected by takotsubo cardiomyopathy as it is more common in postmenopausal women who have just experienced a major stressful event.

A 68-year-old British Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain at rest  which has been ongoing for a few hours. She has a significant past medical history of hypertension  which has been well-managed with prescription medication. As a recent widow who lived a previously stressful life due to her husband's terminal illness  she has reported feelings of anxiety and depression. Additionally  her social history is marked by social isolation and loneliness after her husband's death nine months ago. She denies a personal history of smoking or alcohol abuse  she followed a balanced diet  and performed regular exercise until 9 months ago.   At presentation  patient is visibly distressed and reports feeling ""like she is going to pass out."" Neurologic evaluation is normal but cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia. Her symptoms onset were sudden  occurring at the height of her distress. These symptoms are suggestive of acute coronary syndrome but given her precipitating intense emotional distress  takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as ""broken heart syndrome"") is a primary differential diagnosis.

Patient is a 68-year-old widowed Caucasian woman  who presents to the emergency department complaining of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The symptoms began suddenly  following the death of her husband six months ago. She describes the pain as a tight  gripping pain in the center of her chest that radiates to her left arm. She admits to finding it difficult to cope with her bereavement  reports increased stress  poor sleep  and no exercise since her husband's passing.  She has a 10-year history of well-controlled hypertension using Lisinopril. Her brother had a heart attack at the age of 74. She has no previous history of coronary artery disease  chest pain  dyslipidemia  smoking  substance abuse or diabetes. She has had no previous hospitalizations or surgeries.  On physical examination  she appears anxious and diaphoretic. Cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia and a systolic murmur. No jugular venous distention or peripheral edema is observed. The respiratory exam reveals normal breath sounds with no crackles or wheezes. Neurological examination is unremarkable.   The presentation of acute  severe chest pain and shortness of breath  an increased stress with grief and bereavement  a family history of cardiac disease  and her age and sex suggest Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome) as a likely diagnosis.

An 68-year-old Caucasian female presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath following a significant emotional stressor  the sudden death of her husband. She has no past medical history of coronary artery disease or hypertension. The chest pain resembles that of a heart attack and is not relieved with rest or nitroglycerin. On examination  there is evidence of tachycardia and cardiogenic shock. An EKG demonstrated ST-segment elevation. Diagnostic procedures including cardiac catheterization showed no evidence of blockage in the coronary arteries indicative of typical myocardial infarction  however a ventriculogram revealed abnormalities typical of takotsubo cardiomyopathy with significant hypokinesis/akinesis of the mid-left ventricle with apical ballooning. The troponin level was elevated  further mimicking findings in an acute coronary syndrome. The patient was immediately managed to stabilize her cardiac function.

A 63-year-old  post-menopausal Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department complaining of acute chest pain and shortness of breath  symptoms which closely resemble those of a myocardial infarction. The patient has a history of major depressive disorder and an acute stressor in the form of the recent death of her husband. She has no known history of coronary artery disease  hypertension  or diabetes. She is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption. Her EKG shows inverted T-waves  ST-segment elevation  and prolonged QT interval. Echocardiography shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle  with preserved basal function indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often known as broken-heart syndrome.

A 72-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes in complaining of severe chest pain and shortness of breath that began suddenly approximately 4 hours ago after she received news of the death of a close friend. The pain is described as a heaviness in the centre of her chest  radiating towards her left shoulder and arm  similar to descriptions of anginal pain. EKG shows ST-segment elevation while her troponin levels are slightly elevated. The patient reports no recent use of drugs  alcohol or tobacco. She also denies having previous symptoms similar to the current presentation. She mentions she has been under significant emotional stress due to her friend's illness and subsequent death. Based on the sudden onset of severe chest pain following a significant emotional event in an elderly woman with common risk factors  there is a strong clinical suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 72-year old widowed Caucasian female presents with an acute onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations. She reported that these symptoms started a few hours after she received news about her son's death from an automobile accident. She has a past medical history of hypertension and major depressive disorder. She denies smoking  alcohol consumption  or drug use. Prior to this incident  she was living independently and was able to perform all activities of daily living. There are no reported allergies. Examination reveals an anxious  diaphoretic woman with tachycardia and hypotension. ECG shows ST-segment elevations on the precordial leads consistent with an anterior wall myocardial infarction. However  catheterization did not show significant coronary artery disease but showed left ventricular apical ballooning suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient is a 69-year-old Caucasian female  recently widowed  presenting with severe chest pain mimicking a heart attack  associated with dyspnea and lightheadedness. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and was exposed to intense emotional stress following the sudden death of her husband two weeks ago. She is a nonsmoker  denies alcohol consumption and has no family history of early heart disease. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Labs reveal elevated troponins and an EKG shows ST-segment elevation but without pathological Q-waves or evidence of atherosclerotic plaque rupture on coronary angiography. An echocardiogram reveals left ventricular dysfunction  specifically apical ballooning. Both the clinical presentation and diagnostic findings are consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain  intermittent shortness of breath  nausea  and palpitations. The symptoms started a couple of hours after she received news about her husband's sudden death. She has a past medical history significant for non-controlled type 2 diabetes for the past 10 years  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She has been a non-smoker and only drinks alcohol occasionally. She lives alone and recently retired from her job. Physical examination reveals diaphoresis  tachycardia with a rate of 105 beats per minute  blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  and slight wheezing on lung auscultation. Her diverced brother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 62. She has been medicating with metformin and amlodipine.

A 72-year-old widowed Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with chest pain. The pain started after she received news about the sudden death of her only son yesterday. She describes it as a pressure-like feeling  located in the middle of her chest and rated it as 8/10. She also has associated shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating. She has no previous history of heart disease but has a 10-year history of controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. On examination  she appears anxious. Blood pressure is elevated  and heart rate is rapid. There is no leg swelling or jugular vein distention. The rest of the cardiovascular exam is normal. Chest x-ray and pulmonary exam show no signs of lung disease. The initial EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. However  an emergency coronary angiogram shows no coronary artery occlusion. Given the acute emotional trauma and clinical presentation  a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (or ""broken heart syndrome"") is considered.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and a recent significant emotional stress presents with acute chest pain  similar to severe angina. She reports dyspnea  and a subjective feeling of 'palpitations'. On examination  she has tachycardia  and EKG shows slight ST-segment elevation. The patient does not have any past history of coronary artery disease. Her primary care doctor increased the dosage of her antihypertensive medication a month ago due to poorly controlled blood pressure. The chest pain occurred suddenly while she was thinking about her husband who passed away recently. Hospital admission and further cardiac investigation strongly suggest takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as 'broken heart syndrome'.

A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  along with lightheadedness and vomiting. She recently underwent the death of her husband and had been under immense emotional stress as a result. She has a past medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism  which are managed by medications. She doesn't smoke and her family history is not significant for any heart disease. Her EKG shows ST-level elevations mimicking ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction and echocardiogram shows akinesis in the mid and apical segments of the left ventricle with preserved basal function. The coronary angiogram didn't show any significant coronary artery disease  leading to a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman with a past medical history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain that radiates to her left arm  discomfort  and sweating. The onset was acute and occurred immediately after she received news of her son's unexpected death. Upon examination  she is tachycardic and reveals shallow breathing. Her EKG reveals significant ST-segment elevation  but troponin levels are only mildly elevated. Echocardiogram shows apical ballooning and contraction abnormalities consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old post-menopausal woman presents with a sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. She has a past medical history notable for well-controlled hypertension and she lost her husband just a week ago. She is a teetotaler and non-smoker. Her maternal grandmother had a history of heart disease. Emergency department vitals indicate she has an elevated blood pressure of 168/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 90 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination reveals mild bilateral pedal edema. EKG shows ST-segment elevation  while her laboratory findings indicate moderately elevated troponin levels. These symptoms and findings  combined with severely emotional event suggest a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"".

Patient Demographics: 68-year-old postmenopausal woman  Medical History: Patient has history of hypertension treated with losartan  no previous cardiac history  and recently underwent extreme emotional stress due to the sudden passing of her loving spouse. There are no known drug allergies reported.  Presentation: Patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset severe chest pain  which she describes as a ""sudden  severe crushing sensation"" in the center of her chest  radiating to her left shoulder and arm. She also reports associated shortness of breath and palpitations. Onset was at rest and the pain was not relieved by nitroglycerin. She denies associated nausea  vomiting  diaphoresis  or other systemic symptoms. She denies any recent physical trauma or illness.  Examination: On examination  she appeared distressed with beads of sweat on her forehead  but conscious and oriented. Blood pressure was mildly elevated at 150/90 mmHg. Heart rate regular and rapid at 110 bpm  with no audible murmurs. Chest examination and the rest of the physical examination were normal.  ED Investigations: Repeat ECG showed ST-elevation in leads V1-V4 and T-wave inversion  troponin was significantly elevated. These findings raise suspicion for acute coronary syndrome. However  the patient's ventriculogram showed apical ballooning and basal hypercontractility  consistent with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (or ""broken heart syndrome"").  Impression: This patient likely has Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  an acute illness characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction  which is often triggered by physical or emotional stress. Despite the presentation resembling acute MI  coronary angiography usually does not detect significant obstructive coronary artery disease. Formal confirmation will be done with cardiac catheterization  although treatment with beta blockers and ACE inhibitors is already started.

A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of hypertension and chronic anxiety presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The symptoms have started suddenly after receiving distressing news about the death of a close friend. The chest pain is described as similar to a crushing sensation  similar to past anxiety attacks  but much more intense. She further reports associated nausea  diaphoresis and a feeling of impending doom. The patient has a family history of ischemic heart disease but is a lifelong non-smoker with no history of alcohol abuse or illicit drug use. Her medications include Lisinopril and a benzodiazepine for her anxiety disorder. This patient’s presentation is strongly suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced (broken-heart syndrome) cardiomyopathy.

A 74-year-old widowed Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with acute chest discomfort  pressure  and shortness of breath. She has no known medical history but mentions she has been experiencing intense emotional stress due to the recent death of her husband. She describes the pain as severe  felt in the middle of her chest  and radiating to her arms. Additionally  she reports lightheadedness and nausea. She denies any history of coronary artery disease  hypertension  diabetes  or any other heart diseases in the past. In view of her age  sex  acute severe chest pain  and recent extreme emotional stress  takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart syndrome) is highly suspected.

A 68-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency room with acute onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Intermittent lightheadedness started about 2 hours ago  but progressively worsened. Patient denies having any other associated symptoms like fever  cough  abdominal pain  nausea  vomiting  palpitations  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or recent illnesses increasing her stress levels. Her past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis and osteoporosis without any history of heart disease or hypertension. She is a nonsmoker and takes methotrexate and alendronate regularly. The patient was recently widowed and admits to being under immense emotional distress. On examination  she appears anxious with elevated blood pressure and tachycardia. There was no jugular venous distention  cardiac examination yielded normal S1  S2  without any murmurs and lung fields were clear to auscultation bilaterally. She has no peripheral edema or cyanosis. Initial EKG shows ST segment elevations in the anterior leads and Troponin T level is elevated. The suspicion of acute coronary syndrome is high  but the overall clinical picture raises suspicion for stress-induced takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

A 68-year-old Caucasian postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain and dyspnea. The chest pain is described as pressure-like  located in the substernal area  and radiated to the left shoulder. She denies associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. She reports a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and recently experienced a stressful emotional event due her husband's death. Her medications include aspirin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril. Her vitals on presentation include a blood pressure of 148/90  a heart rate of 102  respiratory rate of 22  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. She has a prior history of smoking  approximately 1 pack per day for 10 years  but quit 20 years ago. Physical examination is significant for tachycardia  but is otherwise within normal limits. Her initial EKG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  raising concern for acute myocardial infarction. However  the cardiac enzymes  troponin levels are significantly raised. She was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  sometimes referred to as Broken Heart Syndrome. The pattern of this patient's symptoms  her prior stressful event  and her demographic are consistent with a high likelihood of this syndrome rather than a typical myocardial infarction.

A 69-year-old  postmenopausal Caucasian woman presents with acute onset severe chest pain and shortness of breath. Her medical history is marked by hypertension and depression but lacks any history of coronary artery disease. She recently underwent the death of her spouse  which had caused considerable emotional stress. On presentation  she has T-wave inversions on her ECG  and her cardiac biomarkers are slightly elevated. Her echocardiography shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle  indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Despite presenting like an acute coronary syndrome  the patient's coronary angiography does not show any significant obstruction. Her cardiovascular dysfunction is likely secondary to a severe emotional stressor  meeting the criteria for takotsubo cardiomyopathy(also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"").
