She was enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program and provided with psychological support to manage her emotional stress.  In conclusion  this case highlights the dramatic presentation and potential severity of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  especially in postmenopausal women with a history of psychological stress. Increased awareness and early recognition among clinicians can enable prompt and appropriate management  resulting in a favorable prognosis.

Title: A Case Report of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 65-Year-Old Caucasian Female   Case Presentation:  The patient presented in this report is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  living in a suburban area with a medium socioeconomic status. Her primary language is English  she lives alone  and her chief complaint involved sudden onset severe chest pain. She presented at our emergency department (ED) after experiencing an acute intense emotional stress event - the sudden death of her pet.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of well-controlled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. She had no known allergies  and her prescribed medications consisted of metformin  lisinopril  and a statin. She was a non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption at social gatherings  and her family history was non-contributory. She met her daily physical activity recommendations and had a well-balanced diet.   Clinical Findings:  During her ED visit  she was in apparent distress secondary to severe chest pain radiating to the left arm. Initial physical examination findings were within normal limits except for elevated blood pressure (170/90 mmHg) and tachycardia (110 bpm). An electrocardiogram (ECG) displayed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads V2-V4  and initial troponin I levels were elevated at 3.2 ng/mL (normal range is 0-0.04 ng/mL).   Diagnosis:  Based on her clinical presentation  an acute coronary syndrome (ACS) was suspected initially  and she was immediately transferred to the cardiac catheterization lab. The coronary angiography  however  demonstrated no significant epicardial coronary artery disease to explain the ST elevations. An echocardiogram was then performed  which showed apical ballooning with basal hypercontractility  consistent with the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was managed with β-blockers (metoprolol)  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and diuretics  based on her presenting symptoms. She responded well to the treatment  and her clinical symptoms significantly improved over the next few days.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  Repeat echocardiography after two weeks showed normalization of the left ventricular function. She was provided with appropriate counselling to manage stress and anxiety. The patient was discharged with instructions for a follow-up office visit  continuation of her medications  and to seek immediate help in the case of the recurrence of symptoms.  Conclusion:   This case underscores the importance of considering TCM in differential diagnoses for patients  particularly postmenopausal women  presenting with symptoms mimicking acute coronary syndrome in the setting of a recent stressful life event. Timely diagnosis and appropriate treatment are key for the excellent prognosis associated with TCM.

Title: A case report of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 62-year-old female patient: Clinical Manifestations  Diagnostic Challenges  and Management  Introduction:   Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or stress-induced cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  is an increasingly recognized condition typically associated with severe emotional or physical stress and mimicking an acute coronary syndrome. Most common in post-menopausal women  the etiology remains largely unclear. This case study involves a 62 year-old Caucasian female with a history of hypertension and anxiety disorders  presenting with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Patient Information:  The patient  a 62-year-old  white  post-menopausal woman  living in the Chicago area  with a known history of hypertension controlled by beta-blockers and an anxiety disorder managed by psychotherapy and antidepressants  presented at the ER. She reported recent sudden emotional stress due to her husband's unexpected death. Three days post the incident  she began experiencing chest pain  similar to a heavy weight placed over her chest  along with shortness of breath.  Clinical Findings:   During the physical examination  patient's mental status was alert and coherent but displayed acute distress. Vital signs showed a high blood pressure of 165/90 mmHg and tachycardia with 115 beats per minute. ECG displayed ST-segments elevations in the precordial leads. Initial lab reports indicated elevated cardiac Troponin-I levels  a common marker associated with cardiac injury.  Timeline:  Upon admittance to the ER  the patient was immediately treated for suspected acute myocardial infarction. However  coronary angiography performed within 48 hours of admission failed to show significant stenosis or obstructions. Left ventriculography instead showed a unique pattern of apical ballooning with the basal segments of the left ventricle functioning normally – a classic presentation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Diagnostic Assessment:   The diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was established based on the Mayo Clinic criteria  i.e.  transient apical or mid-ventricular dysfunction  absence of coronary artery disease  and the onset of symptoms following a stressful event. Additionally  the patient's echocardiogram and cardiac MRI further supported the diagnosis  displaying transient left ventricular dysfunction.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was managed conservatively with continuation of her home drugs including beta-blockers for hypertension. She received aspirin  ACE inhibitors  and therapeutic hypothermia was initiated. She also received counseling and support for managing her recent emotional stress.   Follow-up and Outcome:   A follow-up echocardiogram 3 months later showed complete resolution of the left ventricular dysfunction  indicating a favorable prognosis typically associated with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She was also directed for regular psychological counseling.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy in differential diagnosis for patients  specifically postmenopausal women  presenting with symptoms mimicking acute coronary syndrome  especially in the aftermath of significant emotional stress. Better recognition of this condition would lead to more appropriate  personalized patient management and avoid unnecessary and potentially harmful treatments.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Woman Following Significant Emotional Distress  Case Report:  Demographic Information:  Patient A is a 69-year-old African-American woman  living in a suburb of Atlanta  Georgia. A retired elementary school teacher  she lives alone  following the loss of her husband five years ago. Her husband's passing was her primary household stress  but she has also been dealing with the stress of managing her chronic high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient was brought to the Emergency Department when she developed sudden  severe chest pain radiating to the left arm  profuse sweating and nausea. The episode occurred within an hour of receiving news of her son's untimely death in a car accident.  Clinical Findings:  On arrival  the patient was conscious  but her blood pressure was elevated at 170/95 mmhg. She appeared anxious and in distress  with cardiac auscultation revealing tachycardia. An immediate electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation  and initial laboratory tests showed a modest elevation in cardiac enzymes.  Medical History:  The patient has a 15-year history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is under reasonable control with metformin and a diet plan. She also has hypertension  for which she takes lisinopril. She has no history of smoking or any previous cardiac events.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the ECG changes and the clinical findings  she was initially suspected to be having an acute coronary syndrome  although her cardiovascular risk profile was only moderate. However  following an emergency coronary angiogram  there was no evidence of significant stenosis or occlusion to explain the changes. The left ventriculogram  on the other hand  showed apical ballooning with hypokinesis of the mid and apical segments  suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Therapeutic Intervention:  As a therapeutic measure  the patient was given beta-blockers to reduce stress on her heart and ACE inhibitors to manage her hypertension. She was also given aspirin  although not warfarin as she did not have any thrombus on echocardiogram. Her symptoms improved significantly after starting medication  and she was discharged from the hospital 5 days post-admission with close outpatient follow-up.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  At a 6-month follow-up  the patient reported no recurrence of chest pain. Repeat echocardiography at this time showed normalization of left ventricular function.  Conclusion:  The patient's symptoms  together with her clinical findings and examination results  led to the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  complicated by her existing hypertension and diabetes. Despite the initial severe presentation  the patient responded well to therapy and showed good recovery  underlining the importance of early detection and treatment in TCM. This case report highlights the potential implications of high emotional stress leading to significant cardiac events  such as TCM  in vulnerable individuals.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian female who resides in an urban area. She is a retired school teacher and a widow with three adult children. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is moderately active  non-smoker  and consumes alcohol socially.  Case Presentation:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath following the sudden death of her oldest son. She described her chest pain as a squeezing pressure that radiated down her left arm and up into her neck  coupled with a feeling of profound weakness. These symptoms began approximately two hours prior to her arrival at the emergency department.  Physical Examination & Diagnostic Assessment:  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared distressed and was diaphoretic. Her blood pressure was 170/100 mm Hg  heart rate was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops  and her lung fields were clear to auscultation.  An ECG showed ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V6  I  and aVL. The troponin level was significantly elevated at 4.8 ng/mL (normal < 0.04 ng/mL). Chest X-ray was normal with no evidence of pulmonary edema or pneumothorax.  The patient was admitted to the cardiac unit with a provisional diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction  and the coronary angiography was organized. Surprisingly  the coronary angiogram revealed no significant obstructive coronary artery disease.  A subsequent echocardiogram was performed  which showed left ventricular dyskinesis and apical ballooning  consistent with the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TC). The left ventricular ejection fraction was estimated to be approximately 40%.  Treatment:  The patient was treated with supportive measures and standard heart failure medications  including beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics. She was also provided with psychological support  including referral for grief counseling due to the sudden loss of her son.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Within one month  she had made a full recovery with the resolution of her symptoms. Repeat echocardiogram showed the normalization of left ventricular ejection fraction and resolution of apical ballooning. The patient remained clinically stable during an 18-month follow-up period.  Learning Points:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often triggered by severe emotional stress  can mimic acute coronary syndrome. It is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. Early recognition of this condition is essential to avoid unnecessary invasive procedures and to ensure appropriate management. It generally carries a good prognosis with appropriate treatment and supportive measures.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Presenting in a Postmenopausal Caucasian Woman: A Case Report   Patient Information:   Ms. J  a 71-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department. She is a retired teacher  lives alone  and has a family history concerning cardiac diseases  notably a father deceased from myocardial infarction at 67.  Clinical Findings:  Ms. J presented with severe chest pain of sudden onset  described as a heaviness radiating to her left arm. Accompanying symptoms were shortness of breath and profuse sweating. At presentation  she was afebrile  and her vitals were BP- 140/90mmHg  pulse rate- 98bpm  respiratory rate - 22 breaths per minute  and SpO2- 96%.  History:  She is a non-smoker and consumes minimal alcohol. She reported no drug allergies. Ms. J has a medical history of Hypertension and Type II diabetes well controlled with metformin and losartan. Recently  she experienced the death of her only son  which had caused significant emotional stress.  Diagnostic Assessment:  12-lead ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. The initial troponin measurement was slightly elevated (0.08 ng/mL). Chest radiograph was normal. A transthoracic echocardiogram ((TTE)) showed systolic dysfunction with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 40% and apical ballooning with basal hyper contractility  highly suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Subsequently  coronary angiography was performed  which revealed normal coronary arteries.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Ms. J was initially managed as acute ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI) with oxygen  aspirin  and nitroglycerin undercardiology's consultation. Given her emotional stress history and the typical Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy echocardiography findings  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Therapy was continued with an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ramipril) and a beta-blocker (metoprolol) for heart failure.  Follow-up and Outcomes:   Upon follow-up one month later  she reported a significant reduction in her symptoms. A repeat echocardiogram showed the ejection fraction had improved to 55%  indicating improved cardiac function. She continues to be on regular cardiology follow-up.  Patient Perspective:   Ms. J expressed relief about her symptoms and was counseled Importance of managing stress and prescribed regular sessions with a psychologist.  Conclusion:  This case report contributes to the existing literature that Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  although rare  can mimic myocardial infarction's clinical scenario. It reiterates the importance of recognizing the disease promptly  especially in postmenopausal women with a history of recent significant emotional stress.

Title: A Case Report of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 69-Year-Old Female After Emotional Stress  Patient Overview: Mrs. Atsuko  a 69-year-old Japanese woman  presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of severe chest pain radiating towards her left shoulder  persistent for four hours. She lives in an urban area of Osaka  Japan and previously led an active health-conscious lifestyle. The patient reported no family history of heart abnormalities.  Medical History: Mrs. Atsuko  a retired school teacher  has a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension for the last ten years. She also suffers from osteoporosis but denies any history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  or any other cardiac or associated diseases. She does not smoke  drinks socially and is moderately active. She also experienced recent emotional stress due to the sudden death of her husband one week prior.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  her temperature was noted to be 36.7C (98.0F)  heart rate 110 bpm and regular  respiratory rate 20 breaths/minute  blood pressure 150/90mmHg  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed distant heart sounds with no overt murmurs  rubs or gallops. Her lung exams were free of any crackles and rales.  Investigations: Blood investigations showed an elevated troponin I level indicating myocardial damage. Electrocardiogram (ECG) in the emergency room exhibited ST segment elevation suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Echocardiogram pointed out abnormal left ventricular (LV) systolic function  specifically  hypokinesis of the LV mid segments and apical segments  with hyperkinesis of the basilar segments  consistent with the Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Management: The patient was initially managed as an Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS)  receiving aspirin  clopidogrel  nitroglycerin  and statins. She underwent emergent coronary angiography that revealed normal coronary arteries. However  left ventriculography demonstrated apical ballooning pattern with reduced ejection fraction  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. As a part of her heart failure management  ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers were introduced  and diuretic therapy was initiated for her left ventricular dysfunction.    Outcome: This patient had an uneventful hospital course and was discharged on optimal medical therapy. She was given guidance on stress management strategies to reduce the risk of recurrence.  Discussion: This case highlights the atypical presentation of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or 'broken heart syndrome'  whose clinical presentation often mimics ACS. Elderly females  notably post-menopausal women  are more susceptible to this condition  particularly following stressful events. Management often mirrors that of ACS until definitive diagnosis and is then adjusted accordingly  underscoring the importance of a rapid and accurate diagnosis.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy following Sudden Emotional Stress in a 65-year-old Woman: A Case Report  Introduction: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken-heart syndrome  is a kind of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy triggered by intense emotional or physical stress that results in severe but usually temporary left ventricular dysfunction.  Patient Information: We report a case of a 65-year-old Caucasian woman  retired school teacher  from the United states  with no significant past medical history or known family history of cardiovascular diseases. She was a non-smoker and had a moderate alcohol consumption.  Clinical Findings: The patient had presented to the emergency department with an acute onset of severe chest pain  perspiration and dyspnea that occurred after she received news regarding the sudden demise of her beloved younger sister. Vital signs on admission were; blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  pulse oximetry of 96% on room air  and a body temperature of 37.2 °C. Physical examination was unremarkable except for displaying symptoms of acute distress.   Diagnostic Assessment: Her electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial and inferior leads  and the Troponin I level was significantly raised. Suspecting acute coronary syndrome  patient was immediately transferred to the catheterization laboratory. However  the coronary angiogram revealed no significant stenosis of the coronary arteries. Left ventriculography revealed a hyperkinetic basal segment with accompanying apical ballooning and hypokinesis  giving the left ventricle a shape resembling a 'takotsubo' - a type of pot with a round bottom and narrow neck used in Japan for catching octopus  hence the name. The findings confirmed the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy and the patient was conservatively managed.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous heparin and nitroglycerin which was followed by oral beta-blocker (metoprolol) and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (lisinopril) therapies.   Follow-Up and Outcome: The patient's symptoms significantly improved over the next 48 hours. She no longer had any chest pain and her heart rate had normalized. An echocardiogram performed at 6-week follow-up revealed normalization of ventricular function. Her medications were further reviewed and optimized. The patient was advised regarding stress management and asked to come in for periodic cardiac evaluations.  Patient Perspective: The patient was thoroughly informed about her condition  the nature and purpose of the treatments  and her prognosis.   Conclusion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy presents similar to an acute myocardial infarction and can be triggered by intense emotional or physical stress. This case highlighted the significance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in postmenopausal women presenting with acute chest pain  especially after a recent  intense emotional upset. Prompt recognition and accurate diagnosis can facilitate appropriate management and ensure a favorable prognosis.   Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 72-Year-Old Caucasian Woman with a History of Depression & Generalized Anxiety Disorder: A Case Report  Introduction:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC)  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome  is a transient cardiac syndrome that shares features with acute coronary syndrome. We report a case of a Caucasian woman diagnosed with TTC following a severe anxiety episode.  Case Report:  This patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian woman residing in Oregon  USA. She is retired and lives alone. She has a past medical history significant for depression and generalized anxiety disorder for which she is under psychiatric treatment. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally and in moderation. She has a family history of cardiac disease  with her father passing away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75.  The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. The chest pain was accompanied by dyspnea  excessive perspiration  and palpitations. The symptoms started suddenly during an intense  generalized anxiety attack. Her vital signs on presentation were blood pressure 170/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air.  Lab results showed a mild elevation in cardiac troponin I levels (0.09 ng/mL) and an ECG revealed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. She was started on the acute coronary syndrome protocol. However  coronary angiography showed normal coronary arteries  ruling out acute coronary syndrome.  Subsequent echocardiography revealed apical ballooning with basal hypercontraction  which is typical of TTC. The left ventricular ejection fraction was remarkably reduced at 35% (normal value for women over 20 is 53-73%) with akinesis of the apical segments. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of TTC.   She was managed with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  Beta-blockers  and her psychiatric medication was optimized. The patient was discharged with follow-up appointments with cardiology and psychiatry scheduled. At her three-month follow-up visit  repeat echocardiography showed a normalized left ventricular ejection fraction of 60% with resolution of apical ballooning  and she reported significant improvement in anxiety levels with better emotional health status.  Discussion:  This case exemplifies the classic presentation of TTC and underlines the crucial role of extreme emotional stress as a triggering factor. It also highlights the need for a comprehensive cardiovascular risk factor assessment in patients presenting with chest pain  particularly among the elderly female population  who could have an atypical presentation or causes of chest pain like TTC.  Conclusion:  Clinicians should be aware of the potential for TTC particularly in post-menopausal females presenting with chest pain under exacerbation of psychological stress and in the presence of psychiatric conditions such as anxiety and depression. Confirmation of TTC diagnosis and subsequent management requires a multidisciplinary approach involving both cardiology and psychiatry.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy after Acute Emotional Distress in a Postmenopausal Woman: A Case Report  Introduction:  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or 'broken-heart syndrome ' is a transient cardiac syndrome that mimics acute coronary syndrome. The condition generally affects older women and could lead to severe life-threatening complications if not accurately diagnosed and managed effectively.  Patient Information:  This case report describes Mrs. AB  a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  retired teacher  living in urban northern California. She had a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes which were well controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg once daily and Metformin 500 mg twice daily  respectively). She was a non-smoker  had a moderate consumption of alcohol  and had a family history of ischemic heart disease.  Clinical findings:  Mrs. AB presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe  sharp central chest pain radiating to her left arm  associated with shortness of breath that began after receiving distressing news about the unexpected death of her close friend. The chest pain was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. Additionally  she reported feelings of nausea and light-headedness.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Electrocardiography revealed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads and Troponin I level was elevated (2.3 ng/ml). A suspected diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome was made  based on her symptoms and ECG changes. She was started on low molecular weight heparin  aspirin  and clopidogrel. Subsequent coronary angiography showed normal coronary arteries. Left ventricular angiography was performed due to the discrepancy between clinical and angiographic findings which revealed a classic 'apical ballooning' configuration  confirming the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Therapeutic Intervention:   Mrs AB was managed with beta-blockers (metoprolol 50 mg twice daily)  ACE inhibitors (lisinopril 20 mg once daily)  and continued on her diabetes medication. She also received psychological support to manage her stress and grief.  Follow-up / Outcome:  Over the following week  her symptoms steadily improved and repeat echocardiogram after 2 months showed complete resolution of her previous left ventricular dysfunction.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the importance of considering Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis in postmenopausal women presenting with chest pain  especially in the context of recent emotional stress. Prompt diagnosis and supportive management can lead to a favorable outcome.

Title: A Case Report of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 68-year.old Caucasian Woman Following Emotional Distress  Introduction: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also called stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome  is a transient and reversible condition  typically triggered by severe physical or emotional stress. It occurs predominantly in postmenopausal women. The clinical presentation often resembles acute myocardial infarction. This case highlights takotsubo cardiomyopathy in a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  presenting with symptoms mimicking a heart attack consequent to intense emotional distress.  Case Presentation: A 68-year-old Caucasian woman  Mrs. B  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) of our hospital with chest pain  shortness of breath  and nausea. The patient described the pain as sudden onset  sharp  and intense  located in the middle of the chest. She denied a history of smoking  alcohol or illicit drug use. It was further revealed that she had been under severe emotional stress following her husband's unexpected death three days prior.  Her past medical history was significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension  controlled with atorvastatin and amlodipine. She had no known allergies and wasn't taking any other medications at the time. Her family history was significant for a paternal history of coronary artery disease.   Initial blood pressure was 155/90 mm Hg  heart rate was 112 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation was 91% on room air. Laboratory findings revealed mildly elevated troponin-I levels at 0.12 ng/ml. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads.   Given the symptoms  ECG changes  and elevated troponins  the initial working diagnosis was acute myocardial infarction  and hence  the patient was immediately taken for coronary angiography. Angiography revealed no significant coronary artery disease  contradicting the initial diagnosis. Subsequent transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) demonstrated mid and apical segments hypokinesia with hypercontractile basal segments and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 40%  leading to the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   The patient was managed conservatively with aspirin  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and beta-blockers and under acute heart failure protocol. Psychiatric consultation was also availed for her grief and depression.   Follow-up TTE at six weeks post-discharge revealed complete resolution of the wall motion abnormalities  and her LVEF improved to 60%  reflecting the transient nature of this condition.  Conclusion: This case highlights takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a form of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy  often triggered by emotional stress. As described  this condition can closely resemble a heart attack and is often diagnosed following exclusion of myocardial infarction. In the context of increased emotional stress  post-menopausal age  and the presenting symptoms  clinicians should consider takotsubo cardiomyopathy in their differential diagnosis.

Title: An Unusual Case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 55-Year-Old Hispanic Female  Patient Profile: The patient is a 55-year-old Hispanic female of average body weight and height. She is a lifelong non-smoker with an occasional alcohol intake. Her occupation involves moderate levels of mental stress  a high-school teacher. She lives in a suburban environment  with no exposure to known environmental hazards.  Past Medical History: The patient has no prior history of cardiovascular disease  diabetes or hypertension. She was diagnosed with major depressive disorder six years prior to this event  for which she has been taking selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) regularly under the control of a psychiatrist. She also has controlled hypothyroidism for the last decade  managed with synthetic thyroxine supplementation.  Initial Presentation and Diagnosis: The patient was presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain and dyspnea. The symptoms began abruptly  following an intense argument with her son. An electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads  initially raising suspicion for an acute myocardial infarction. However  emergent coronary angiography revealed no significant coronary artery disease. Transthoracic echocardiography showed left ventricular apical ballooning  a classic sign of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TC). The diagnosis was therefore made based on the Mayo Clinic criteria for TC.  Clinical Course and Treatment: The patient was managed conservatively  with ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and aspirin. She was closely monitored for complications  including arrhythmias  shock  and emboli. Her chest pain resolved within 48 hours  and repeat echocardiography after twelve days showed normalization of left ventricular function. She was discharged and referred for outpatient psychiatric follow-up.  Discussion: This case exemplifies the complexities of diagnosing TC  often called ""broken heart syndrome "" due to its similar presentation to acute myocardial infarction. The patient also demonstrated the established association between TC and emotional stress  although cases in perimenopausal or postmenopausal women are most common. This case is unique given that this patient developed TC without previously known cardiovascular conditions  which are typically common comorbidities in TC patients.  Learning Points/Conclusion: TC should be considered as a differential diagnosis in all patients  especially postmenopausal women  presenting with acute chest pain. While emotional stress is a trigger  clinicians should not overlook patients without a history of cardiac disease. Finally  the close monitoring and management of potential complications are crucial for a favorable outcome.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Postmenopausal Woman Following a Stressful Event: A Case Report  1. Patient Information  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female. She is a retired school teacher with a history of hypertension  for which she is on medications (Losartan  100 mg daily). She lives alone and her husband had passed away a decade ago. There were no reports of any previous cardiac disease  diabetes mellitus  or any other chronic illnesses. She doesn’t smoke or consume any alcoholic beverages.  2. Clinical Findings  The patient was attended in the emergency department with symptoms of acute chest pain  profuse sweating  and breathlessness. The symptoms started within a couple of hours after she had learned about her elder son's death in a car accident. Experiencing significant distress  she felt acute chest discomfort radiating to her left arm simulating a heart attack. An immediate ECG was performed which reported ST-segment elevation in precordial leads.  3. Timeline  Given the symptoms and ECG findings  the patient was admitted to the Intensive Cardiac Care Unit (ICCU). Further investigations like the chest x-ray and echocardiography were also carried out. The chemistry analysis showed an increase in cardiac biomarkers (Troponin I levels were 5.2 ng/ml). Echocardiogram showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle  with a base to apex progressive reduction in the contractility. Coronary angiography  performed 48 hours after admission  showed no significant coronary artery stenosis.  4. Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was initially treated as a case of acute coronary syndrome and was given aspirin  clopidogrel  nitroglycerin  and a beta-blocker. Following the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC)  her medication was continued with the addition of ACE inhibitors. Her condition was frequently monitored with serial ECGs and echocardiograms.   5. Follow-up and Outcome  After a week  her symptoms significantly subsided. An echocardiogram conducted before discharge showed some recovery of the apical ballooning. She was discharged on the 10th day with medications and was advised for a regular cardio follow-up.   6. Patient Perspective  Overall  the patient was shocked by the diagnosis. She had initially believed that she was suffering from a heart attack. After learning about TTC and its link to emotional stress  she agreed to seek professional help to deal with her grief and heightened stress.   7. Conclusion  This case underscores the need to include TTC in the differential diagnoses for any postmenopausal woman presenting with chest pain  especially following a significant emotional stressor. Early recognition and proper management can prevent unnecessary invasive interventions and lead to improved patient outcomes.

Title: Stress-Induced Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Postmenopausal Woman: A Case Report  Introduction: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome or stress cardiomyopathy  usually occurs in postmenopausal women and is often precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress. Its major presenting symptoms mirror those of acute coronary syndrome  including chest pain and EKG changes  but without significant coronary artery obstruction. This report presents a case of takotsubo cardiomyopathy in a 68-year-old woman.  Patient information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe chest pain after receiving news of her brother's unexpected death. She is a non-smoker  with a medical history significant for hypertension  well-controlled with lisinopril  and hypercholesterolemia  managed with atorvastatin. She had no past history of coronary artery disease  myocardial infarction or heart failure.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient appeared anxious with a blood pressure of 165/90 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 102 beats per minute. Initial EKG showed ST segment elevation in the anterior-lateral leads  suggesting possible acute myocardial infarction. However  her troponin levels were only slightly elevated. An emergency coronary angiogram revealed no significant occlusive lesions in her coronary arteries.  Timeline: The patient's symptoms started approximately 3 hours prior to her presentation to the ER. Within 24 hours of her admission  an echocardiogram was done which showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal function  a characteristic finding in takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Diagnostic Assessment: Based on her symptoms  EKG findings  slightly elevated troponin levels  the absence of significant coronary artery disease on coronary angiogram and the echocardiographic findings  the patient was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initially treated with aspirin  clopidogrel  and heparin due to suspicion of acute coronary syndrome. After confirmation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  she was started on a beta-blocker (metoprolol) and the anticoagulant was stopped. Her angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor for hypertension was continued.  Follow-up and Outcome: The patient showed significant symptom improvement within 72 hours of admission and was discharged on the fifth hospital day. A follow-up echocardiogram after 4 weeks demonstrated complete resolution of the left ventricular dysfunction. The patient was advised to continue with the beta-blocker and engage in stress management techniques.  Discussion: This case underscores the prevalence of takotsubo cardiomyopathy in postmenopausal women under severe stress. Despite mimicking myocardial infarction  the key to diagnosing takotsubo cardiomyopathy is identifying the characteristic apical ballooning of the left ventricle in the absence of significant coronary artery disease. Early diagnosis followed by appropriate treatment can lead to complete recovery.

Title: Acute Stress-Induced (Takotsubo) Cardiomyopathy in a 60-Year-Old Female Following Orthopedic Surgery  Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian woman presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset chest pain  shortness of breath and nausea.  Demographics: The patient is a non-smoker  does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies. She lives alone in semi-urban Minnesota  United States and is an office worker by profession. The only significant past medical history includes controlled hypertension and osteoporosis.   Case Description: This patient was recently managed in hospital after undergoing total hip replacement surgery for severe osteoarthritis. She was discharged in stable conditions three days before the current presentation.   In the ED  she appeared diaphoretic and in distress. Initial vital signs observed were: BP 165/95mm Hg  pulse 110/min  respiratory rate 20/min  and temperature 98.6°F. Cardiac examination demonstrated regular rhythm  no murmurs or extra sounds. Lung sounds were clear to auscultation bilaterally.   The EKG showed minimal ST elevations in leads V1-V4 without reciprocal changes and no dynamic T-wave inversions. Blood test results showed elevation of cardiac enzymes: troponin level was 0.9 ng/mL (reference range <0.4 ng/mL).   The patient was diagnosed with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) and was immediately started on a standard regimen of dual antiplatelet therapy  high-intensity statin  and beta-blockers.   However  an emergently obtained coronary angiography revealed no evidence of significant obstruction or clot burden in the coronary arteries. Further left ventriculography showed apical ballooning with hyperkinesis of the basal segments  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Discussion:  The patient was extensively counseled about the diagnosis of TCM  known also as broken-heart syndrome  often triggered by acute emotional or physical stress. The recent surgery she underwent was considered as a plausible trigger for her TCM.   Management and Follow-up:  The patient was managed empathetically with supportive therapy  including a period of observation  angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and beta-blockers.   Her symptoms progressively improved over the course of a week  and she was discharged on low-dose aspirin  ACE inhibitor  beta-blocker  and statin  which helped to control her hypertension as well. At a 3 month follow-up  she reported no chest pain or shortness of breath. A repeat echocardiogram showed normalization of her left ventricular function without any wall motion abnormalities.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes that TCM should be considered in differential diagnosis in postmenopausal women presenting with symptoms suggestive of acute coronary syndrome  particularly in context with a recent stressful event. Prompt recognition and appropriate management of TCM can lead to a favorable outcome in these patients.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy: Presentation and Management of a 68-year-old female subject  Introduction: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TC)  also known as broken heart syndrome  is a transient left ventricular dysfunction often triggered by acute emotional or physical stress. The condition presents similarly to Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) but without significant coronary lesions.  Case Presentation: The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She lives in Midwest  is widowed  and retired from teaching. Relevant past medical history includes controlled hypertension  hypothyroidism  and anxiety. She denied smoking or alcohol consumption and has a negative family history of heart diseases. The symptoms seemed to have occurred following a distressing argument with her son.  Upon physical examination  the patient seemed anxious and in obvious respiratory distress. Heart rate was elevated at 115 bpm  blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  respiratory rate was 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  suggestive of a ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  The patient was immediately treated with aspirin  nitroglycerin and high flow oxygen  and she was rushed to the cath lab for urgent coronary angiography. Surprisingly  there was no evidence of significant coronary artery disease.  Meanwhile  her cardiac markers started to elevate; initial troponin I was 0.3 ng/mL (normal: < 0.04 ng/mL) which then peaked at 3.0 ng/mL. Interestingly  an echocardiogram demonstrated left ventricular apical ballooning with basal hypercontractility  findings suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Treatment & Follow-up: The patient was managed with beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI)  aspirin  and therapeutic doses of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). She was also started on a short-term anxiolytic. With this treatment  her symptoms improved gradually  and the patient was discharged after 7 days.   At 1 month follow-up  a repeat echocardiogram demonstrated complete resolution of the left ventricular function and she returned to her completely independent baseline status.  Discussion: This case illustrates that TC can present exactly like ACS and highlights the associated increased prevalence in postmenopausal women and association with emotional stress. The absence of significant CAD on angiography  presence of emotional triggers  and characteristic wall motion abnormalities suggest Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. Early recognition and appropriate management of this condition are pivotal to ensure a favorable outcome.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Postmenopausal Female: A Case Study  Introduction:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC)  also known as broken heart syndrome  is a transient and reversible condition characterized by acute left ventricular dysfunction  typically triggered by severe stress. While the exact mechanism remains unclear  it is often associated with excessive catecholamine release.   Demographics: The patient in this case report is a 68-year-old Caucasian female. She is a retired teacher  widowed  living with her daughter and grandchildren. She has no history of smoking or alcohol consumption. The patient spends her time gardening  reading  and assisting with her grandchildren's care. She appears well-groomed and denies any illicit substance usage.  Medical history: She has a past medical history of hypertension  controlled with medications (losartan and hydrochlorothiazide)  and hypothyroidism under control with levothyroxine. She had her last check-up 4 months ago  where her blood pressure and thyroid function tests were normal. Her surgical history includes hysterectomy for benign reasons at age 45. She has no known allergies.  Case presentation: The patient was brought to the emergency department (ED) with severe chest pain that began just after hearing the news about her brother's sudden death. She described pain as 'crushing' and 'squeezing ' radiating to her left arm  associated with shortness of breath. She denied any symptoms like fever  cough  or palpitations.  Investigations: Initial electrocardiogram demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  and troponin levels were significantly elevated  suggestive of myocardial ischemia. However  an emergency coronary angiography revealed no significant coronary artery stenosis. Left ventriculography depicted a typical apical ballooning with basal hypercontractility  a distinctive feature of TTC.  Management and outcome: The patient was admitted to the ICU under the impression of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She was managed with aspirin  beta-blockers (metoprolol)  and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (lisinopril). She showed marked symptom improvement within 3 days  at which point she was transferred from the ICU to a regular bed. A repeat echocardiogram after ten days revealed normalization of left ventricular function. She was successfully discharged with outpatient cardiology follow-up.  Conclusion:  This report exemplifies the high prevalence of TTC in postmenopausal women  often triggered by extreme stress. Of significance  healthcare providers should be aware of the distinctive characteristics of this syndrome to differentiate it from acute coronary syndrome  since the management varies considerably. Further studies are needed to understand the pathophysiology and long-term prognosis of this intriguing medical condition.

Title: An Atypical Case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Middle-aged Male Patient   Introduction:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as 'broken heart syndrome'  predominantly affects postmenopausal women. Reports of takotsubo cardiomyopathy in middle-aged males are relatively uncommon. This report documents the case of a 55-year-old male patient with no significant medical history who presented with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Case Description: The patient  Mr. X  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. He reported the onset of symptoms to be sudden  occurring after receiving emotionally distressing news. He was an occasional smoker but had quit five years ago. There was no history of alcohol or illicit drug use.  His past medical history was unremarkable  with no prior diagnosis of any cardiovascular diseases or other chronic ailments. The family history was also insignificant for any cardiovascular diseases.  On physical examination  the patient exhibited signs of acute distress. Vitals on presentation were as follows: blood pressure 135/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats/min  respiratory rate 18/min  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air.  On 12 lead-EKG  it showed T wave inversions with ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. His laboratory results showed a significant increase in cardiac enzymes  including Troponin-I levels at 5.62 ng/mL (normal value <0.04 ng/mL) and Creatine kinase-MB at 53 ng/mL (normal value <7.2 ng/mL). Complete blood count  metabolic profile  liver  and kidney function tests were within normal limits.  An emergency coronary angiogram revealed no significant stenosis in the coronary arteries. A subsequent echocardiogram showed left ventricular apical ballooning with a reduced ejection fraction of 39%  suggesting the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  The patient was treated with a conservative approach  including angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  β-blockers  and aspirin under intensive cardiac care. The patient showed a progressive improvement and was discharged under follow-up surveillance.    Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is typically associated with a sudden release of stress hormones induced by emotional or physical stress events. The patient’s symptoms were triggered by a stressful incident  emphasizing the 'emotional stress' aspect of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The fact that it occurred in a middle-aged male  usually less affected by this condition  makes this case atypical.   Conclusion: This case illustrates that while takotsubo cardiomyopathy primarily affects post-menopausal women  it can still occur in individuals who do not fit the typical patient profile. Physicians must consider takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome  regardless of the patient's gender or age.   Note: The patient's information is entirely fictional and created for the purpose of the case report; any resemblance to actual individuals would be coincidental.

Title: An Uncommon Presentation of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Metastatic Breast Cancer Patient  Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female residing in Sydney  Australia. She is a retired school teacher  a non-smoker  and leads a moderately active lifestyle. The patient consumes alcohol occasionally and doesn't have a history of drug abuse.   Past Medical History: The patient has no known history of cardiovascular disease. However  she was diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive  HER2-negative  Stage IIb breast cancer six years ago for which she underwent a mastectomy followed by chemotherapy and hormonal therapy. The patient has controlled hypertension for over a decade. She takes regular medications - tamoxifen for breast cancer  and ramipril for hypertension. No history of early-onset coronary artery disease is found in her family.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with sudden severe chest pain  dizziness  and associated shortness of breath. The onset was while she was attending a family gathering  approximately 30 minutes prior to arrival at the hospital.   Clinical Findings: On examination  she was anxious  diaphoretic with heart rate 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  temperature 37.1C  respiratory rate 24 breaths/minute  and saturation of 94% on room air. Her chest exam was unremarkable with no crackles or wheezes. No apparent breast masses were found on breast examination. Her cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia  but no murmurs or gallops were noted.   Investigations: An electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. Troponin levels were elevated at 11ng/mL(normal: less than 0.04ng/mL). A transthoracic echocardiogram suggested apical ballooning  consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiogram showed no significant coronary artery disease.  Case Management: The patient was managed supportively with beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and aspirin. She was transferred to the cardiac care unit for monitoring. After three days  her symptoms resolved  and repeat echocardiogram showed improvement in apical contractility.  Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  most often occurs in postmenopausal women and can be triggered by intense emotional or physical stress. Our patient's presentation is unusual because of her history of metastatic breast cancer. There are multiple case reports linking the use of chemotherapeutic agents like fluorouracil and epirubicin to takotsubo cardiomyopathy. However  the association of tamoxifen and takotsubo is scarcely reported.   Conclusion: The case highlights the need for clinicians to consider takotsubo cardiomyopathy in patients presenting with acute chest pain  especially in patients with a history of cancer and chemotherapy  even if they don't fall into the classic category of postmenopausal women under severe stress.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Female Following Emotional Distress: A Case Report  Introduction:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ''broken heart syndrome "" is typically a transient cardiac syndrome presenting with chest pain  mimicking an acute myocardial infarction  but without coronary artery occlusion. This condition was first described in Japan and is characterized by transient apical ballooning of the left ventricle.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presenting to the emergency department (ED) with severe chest pain and shortness of breath which began suddenly while she was attending her husband's funeral. She lives independently and is a retired schoolteacher. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. She reported no recent illnesses or travels. Her past medical history includes hypertension and hypothyroidism  for which she is on regular medication—losartan and levothyroxine  respectively. She has no history of cardiac disease or family history of heart diseases.  Examination highlighted an elevated blood pressure of 150/90mmHg and pulse rate of 110 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation identified a normal S1  S2 heart sound without the presence of murmurs. Chest radiograph was unremarkable  and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads indicating possible myocardial infarction.  However  her cardiac enzyme levels showed a slight elevation above normal reference range. She immediately underwent a coronary angiography assuming a diagnostic hypothesis of acute coronary syndrome. However  it revealed normal coronary arteries without any signs of atherosclerotic plaques or obstruction.  Nevertheless  the left ventriculography revealed a distinct pattern of apical ballooning with hyperkinesia of the basal walls  consistent with a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient was then admitted to Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for close monitoring.  Upon further examination  her Troponin levels were moderately increased  which is consistent with the mild myocardial injury often seen in TCM. She was managed by continuing her antihypertensive treatment and initiating supportive therapy  including beta-blockers to reduce sympathetic overdrive. As she had significant emotional distress  she was referred to a psychologist who initiated coping methods and stress reduction techniques.  The follow-up echocardiogram after four weeks showed complete resolution of the left ventricular dysfunction  confirming the diagnosis of TCM. The patient showed improvement  and the chest pain resolved.  Conclusion:  This case highlights that TCM  though rare  should be considered in the differential diagnosis in post-menopausal women with chest pain especially in the setting of recent emotional stress. The characteristic feature of normal coronary angiogram with apical ballooning can help to differentiate this condition from acute myocardial infarction  thus avoiding unnecessary invasive procedures. It also underlines the importance of managing psychological distress in patients with TCM.

Case Report: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 68-year-old Asian Female Patient  **Patient Information**  Demographics: 68-year-old Asian female patient.  Main Complaint: Substernal chest pain  lasting for approximately 3 hours accompanied by dyspnea and palpitations.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports the onset of these symptoms following the sudden death of her spouse two weeks previously.  Past Medical History: The patient was previously diagnosed with hypertension  for which she is being managed with medication. She has no history of any cardiac or pulmonary disorders. The patient is a non-smoker  does not consume alcohol  and has no known history of recreational drug use. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease.  **Clinical Findings**  Physical examination: She appeared moderately distressed  primarily due to pain and dyspnea. Initial blood pressure reading was 160/100 mmHg  heart rate was 100 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation level was at 94%. Auscultation revealed regular heart rhythm without murmurs or rubs  and lungs were clear to auscultate.  Investigations: Laboratory results indicated significantly increased Troponin I levels at 5.2 ng/mL and elevated Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) and Creatinine levels. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  suggesting an acute coronary event. However  the coronary angiogram showed no significant occlusive disease.  Considering the patient's emotional trauma  her clinical presentation  ECG findings  and the absence of significant obstructive coronary disease on angiography  a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TTC)  commonly known as ""broken-heart syndrome "" was made.  Echocardiography revealed apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hyperkinesis of the basal walls  typical for TTC. Left ventricular ejection fraction was measured to be reduced at 35%.  **Therapeutic Intervention**  The patient was managed with supportive therapy including β-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics to relieve cardiac strain and ease symptoms. Psychiatrists were involved in dealing with the acute emotional stress she was under after the sudden loss of her spouse.  **Follow-up and Outcome**  On follow-up after 2 months  she appeared lot calmer and reported no chest pain or dyspnea at rest or on exertion. A repeat echocardiogram showed improvement in left ventricular function with resolved apical ballooning- ejection fraction measured at 60%  indicating normalization of cardiac function.  **Clinical Lesson**  This case presents a typical example of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in the context of emotional distress. The situation underscores the importance of considering such diagnosis in older patients with recent emotional stress presenting with symptoms of acute coronary syndrome. Timely diagnosis can lead to appropriate management and reduction in complications associated with this reversible but serious cardiac condition.  **Patient Consent** Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report and accompanying images.

Title: Case Report on a 67-year-old Caucasian Female with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Post Bereavement  Patient Information: The patient  referred to as Mrs. A for confidentiality reasons  is a 67-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher from Cincinnati Ohio. She presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of expressing severe chest discomfort  reported as resembling severe pressure spreading to her left arm. The patient reports that she has been in her usual health until her symptoms started ten days after the death of her spouse.  Past Medical History: Mrs. A is a non-smoker with a BMI of 30 and a past medical history of hypertension controlled with drugs (Losartan 50mg daily) but no known history of coronary artery disease  diabetes mellitus  or hyperlipidemia. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with her father dying of a myocardial infarction at the age of 69.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  Mrs. A was slightly tachycardic (heart rate of 98 beats per minute) with a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg. She had an unremarkable physical examination except for slight discomfort on palpation of the chest wall.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Electrocardiography (ECG) showed marked T-wave inversions in the anterior leads  but no ST-segment elevations. Troponin levels were slightly elevated at 0.12 mg/L (normal < 0.04 mg/L)  patient underwent cardiac catheterization to rule out acute coronary syndrome. Coronary angiography was performed  revealing no obstructive coronary artery disease.   Further assessment of the left ventricular function reported a reduced ejection fraction of 40% with apical akinesis and relatively preserved basal function - a feature frequently associated with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).   Therapeutic Intervention:  Mrs. A was managed initially as a case of suspected acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with Aspirin  Clopidogrel  subcutaneous Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)  and high-dose statins (Atorvastatin 80mg). Following the catheterization results  the aspirin and clopidogrel were discontinued  while LMWH and statins were continued for VTE prophylaxis and LDL operations  respectively.   Given the diagnosis of TCM  it was decided to relieve the patient's emotional stress; and as such  a psychiatrist was involved in her care. Medications were optimized  including beta-blockers (Metoprolol) and ACE inhibitors (Ramipril).  Follow up and Outcomes: On follow-up after eight weeks  the patient reported a significant reduction in her symptoms  her ECG returned to baseline  and her ejection fraction had improved to 55% on repeat echocardiography. Her bereavement and stress levels were managed effectively with the help of psychological therapy.  Informed Consent: The patient had given her informed consent in compliance with the ethical principles of confidentiality and patient privacy.  Discussion: This case report showcases the relevance of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often misdiagnosed as acute coronary syndrome  particularly in post-menopausal women exposed to significant emotional stress. This case report highlights the importance of the psychosocial aspect in the management of such conditions and the effectiveness of supportive therapy for TCM recovery.

Title: Late-Onset Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-Menopausal Caucasian Female: A Case Report  Introduction: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ‘broken heart syndrome’  is characterized by transient left ventricular apical ballooning syndrome  often mimicking acute myocardial infarction. It predominantly affects postmenopausal women and is typically triggered by severe emotional or physical stress.  Case Report:  Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian female presented to the hospital emergency department with sudden onset chest pain radiating to the left arm  sweating  and difficulty breathing after hearing about her son's severe accident. She resides in a rural region in Idaho  is a former smoker  and has no previous history of psychiatric disorders.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  she was pale and diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 140/90mmHg  pulse rate 110/min  and respiratory rate 28/min. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia but was otherwise normal.  Diagnosis Assessment: Her electrocardiogram (ECG) showed T wave inversion in leads V1-V4 with QTc prolongation. Serum troponins were elevated  and echocardiogram demonstrated left ventricular apical hypokinesis with mid-ventricular segment hyperkinesis. However  coronary angiography showed no significant stenosis. Given her manifestations  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was managed with supportive pharmacotherapy  including aspirin  a beta-blocker  an ACE inhibitor  and a statin. She also received psychological support to help manage the emotional distress caused by her son's accident.  Follow Up and Outcome: On follow-up after eight weeks  the patient reported alleviation of her symptoms. The echocardiogram demonstrated resolution of the previous wall motion abnormalities and the return of the left ventricular function to normal.  Conclusion: This case elucidates the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome  notably in postmenopausal women with a recent history of intense emotional stress. Despite its benign nature  early recognition and appropriate treatment of this condition are essential to preventing potential complications.  Patient Consent: Informed consent for the publication of this case report was taken from the patient.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Post-menopausal woman: A Case Report  Patient Information:  A 68-year-old African American woman presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain and discomfort in her upper body.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Other than these two conditions  the patient has maintained a moderate lifestyle participating in routine exercise and balanced diet. She is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. She underwent menopause at the age of 51  following which hypertension was diagnosed.  Present Condition and Symptoms: On admission  she was conscious but appeared anxious and complained of a severe crushing chest pain radiating to her left arm and neck which had started a couple of hours earlier while she was attending a funeral. She reported feeling extremely stressed emotionally during the event. She also reported occasional episodes of shortness of breath but denied having any fever  cough  or cold.   Physical Evaluation and Diagnostic Assessment: On physical examination  her blood pressure was recorded as 165/90 mmHg  and her heart rate was 112/minute. The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads consistent with acute myocardial infarction. Initial lab reports showed elevated troponin levels. However  a subsequent coronary angiography did not reveal any significant coronary artery disease.  To evaluate the reason for her symptoms  left ventriculography was performed  which showed apical ballooning with hyperkinesis of the base - a characteristic feature consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC). An echocardiogram further confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was also evaluated for pheochromocytoma  given her persistent hypertension  but testing was negative.  Treatment: The patient was managed with supportive care along with standard heart failure medical therapies including β-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and diuretics. Her condition improved significantly over the course of her hospital stay.  Conclusion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome "" is more frequently observed in post-menopausal women and is often precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress. This case emphasizes the importance of considering TTC in the differential diagnosis of post-menopausal women presenting with features of acute coronary syndrome  especially in the setting of severe emotional stress  even with co-existing other cardiovascular risk factors.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 68-year-old Female Post Emotional Stress  Introduction:  This case report documents the presentation  diagnosis  treatment  and recovery of Mrs. G  a 68-year-old Caucasian female who developed Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC)  commonly known as broken heart syndrome  following a significant emotional event.   Case Presentation:  Mrs. G  a retired teacher with a past medical history of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain  nausea  and shortness of breath. She reported that these symptoms developed suddenly soon after she received news of her son’s unexpected death.   Findings:  Physical examination revealed a distressed and anxious female  slightly obese with a BMI of 32. She was tachycardic  with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and mildly hypertensive with a blood pressure of 150/80mmHg. Lung examination was normal. Initial labs showed an elevated troponin level of 2.8ng/ml. Her electrocardiogram demonstrated ST segment elevation in the precordial leads.   Intervention:  A presumptive diagnosis of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) was made  and she was urgently transferred to the catheterization lab for coronary angiography. Surprisingly  the study revealed no significant coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography  however  showed apical ballooning with preserved basal function  a pattern consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Echocardiography confirmed these findings with a reduced ejection fraction of 30%.  The patient was admitted to the Cardiac Care Unit (CCU) for further management. She was placed on an ACE inhibitor for heart failure  a beta-blocker for blood pressure and heart rate control  and a statin as secondary prevention  given her transiently raised troponins.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Emotional support was provided to Mrs. G  who found it comforting to understand her physical symptoms in the context of her profound grief. She was discharged home on day 5 with outpatient cardiology follow up scheduled. On her four-week follow-up visit  her symptoms had completely resolved. A repeat echocardiogram now demonstrated the ejection fraction had returned to normal (55%).  Discussion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  occurs most often in post-menopausal women and can be triggered by severe emotional stress. In Mrs. G’s case  the unexpected death of her son was identified as the likely trigger. Despite presentation similar to an acute coronary syndrome  coronary angiography is typically normal or near-normal in TTC making it a diagnosis of exclusion. Treatment focuses on the symptomatic management and addressing the root cause of stress  with nearly all patients experiencing a complete recovery.  While the pathophysiology of takotsubo cardiomyopathy is not entirely clear  it is thought to involve an excessive surge of catecholamines that stun the myocardium leading to characteristic left ventricular apical ballooning. This case highlights the importance of considering TTC in older women who present with symptoms of acute coronary syndrome  especially in the context of emotional stressors.

Title: A Case of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy In a 65-Year-Old African American Female  Introduction: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as 'broken heart syndrome ' is a transient left ventricular dysfunction often associated with emotional or physical stress. TCM predominantly affects post-menopausal women. This case report presents a 65-year-old African American female who developed TCM following the sudden loss of her husband.   Case Description:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American woman  widow  retired teacher  with a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. She presented to the hospital with crushing chest pain associated with dyspnea and diaphoresis  which started acutely after hearing the news of her husband's sudden passing. She denied any history of tobacco or alcohol use.  On arrival  she was tachycardic (heart rate 110 beats/min) and hypertensive (blood pressure 170/105 mmHg). The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-elevation in precordial leads suggestive of acute myocardial infarction. Her troponin levels were elevated  confirming myocardial injury.  She was immediately moved to the catheterization lab for possible percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). Surprisingly  coronary angiography showed normal coronary arteries  ruling out coronary artery disease as the cause of her symptoms. Left ventriculography then revealed apical ballooning with preserved basal function  a classic finding observed in TCM.  The patient was managed with beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics. She responded well to the treatment  with resolution of her heart failure symptoms over a few days. A repeat echocardiogram after four weeks showed complete resolution of the wall motion abnormality. Repeated ECG also normalized  and troponin levels returned to normal limits.   Discussion:  This case illuminates the significant impact of emotional stress on cardiovascular health. TCM is more prevalent in postmenopausal women  particularly among Asians  but it can occur in any ethnic group  as in our patient. The patient's quick regression of symptoms was typical for TCM. It underlines the significance of considering TCM in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with chest pain  especially when there is a recent history of severe emotional stress.  Conclusion:   Management of TCM is mainly supportive  with most patients exhibiting complete recovery. This case serves as a reminder for physicians to consider takotsubo cardiomyopathy in older women presenting with chest pain following emotional stress  irrespective of their race or ethnicity. The relationship between emotional stress and heart health should be explored further in future medical research.

Title: Recurrent Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a Postmenopausal Woman: A Case Report  Patient Information: Mrs. X  a 68-year-old African-American widow  presented at the hospital with a 3-day history of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She is a retired school teacher who lives alone but is well engaged socially. Her BMI is within the normal range  with no history of smoking  alcohol consumption  or illicit drug use.   Medical History: Her past medical history is remarkable for a similar episode of chest pain three years ago  subsequent cardiology evaluation was suggestive of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TTC). She has been on regular follow-up with cardiology since then and is compliant with her daily aspirin 75mg  a low salt diet  and structured exercise. She has no history of hypertension  diabetes  or familial premature heart disease. She reached menopause at age 52 and never took hormone replacement therapy.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination on admission revealed tachycardia with a heart rate of 102 beats per minute and blood pressure of 165/95mmHg. The cardiovascular exam showed an S4 gallop but no murmur or rub. Lungs were clear  and the rest of the examination was unremarkable. EKG showed ST-elevation in anterolateral leads indicating possible acute coronary syndrome.   Diagnostic Assessment: Hospital labs revealed elevated cardiac enzymes: Troponin T of 0.78ng/ml (normal range up to 0.1ng/ml). An echocardiogram showed left ventricular dysfunction with apical ballooning and preserved function at the base  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiography ruled out the presence of coronary artery disease.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was managed with beta-blockers (Metoprolol 25 mg twice daily) to control the heart rate and blood pressure  mild sedation to alleviate her anxiety  and supportive care for her heart failure. Over 48 hours  her symptoms gradually improved  and repeat echocardiogram revealed normalized contractility.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Upon discharge  the patient was advised to have a follow-up every six months with the cardiology team. She was prescribed daily aspirin and metoprolol. The patient was also referred to the psychiatric team for stress management and coping strategies.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief at knowing that her condition was not a heart attack and committed to routine check-ups and medications.  Informed Consent: Verbal informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.  Concluding Remarks: This case is a vivid reminder that Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  often related to intense physical or emotional stress  can recur in susceptible individuals. Ongoing follow up with cardiology and stress management strategies are important for such patients.

Title: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy in a 67-year-old Female Post Bereavement: A Case Report   Case Presentation:  A 67-year-old African-American female patient presented to the emergency department with severe central chest pain radiating to the left arm  accompanied by dyspnea which began approximately 2 hours prior to her visit. The patient noted that her symptoms started suddenly while she was at her spouse's funeral. She has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol only on social occasions. She does not have any known allergies. There is a family history of coronary artery disease  though no known history of cardiomyopathy or other heart conditions.  The patient's vital signs upon presentation were as follows: Blood pressure 155/98 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Neurologically  the patient was alert and oriented.  Investigations:  ECG performed on arrival revealed ST segment elevation in anterior leads (V2-V4)  suggestive of anterior wall myocardial infarction. Lab results showed a slightly elevated Troponin-I level of 1.56 ng/mL(normal range <0.04 ng/mL). Complete blood count  renal function  liver function  electrolytes  and lipid profile were within normal ranges.  Due to the findings  the patient was taken to the catheterization lab for an emergent angiogram to rule out an acute coronary syndrome. Surprisingly  the coronary angiogram showed no significant obstructive coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography showed ""apical ballooning"" with impairment of the left ventricular systolic function  suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was admitted to the cardiac care unit and started on heart failure management  including angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta-blockers  and diuretics. Over the following few days  the patient's chest pain resolved and her cardiac enzymes normalized. An echocardiogram repeated one week later showed resolution of the apical hypokinesis  and near normalization of the left ventricular function.  Discussion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken-heart syndrome  often presents like an acute coronary syndrome. It is more common in postmenopausal women and can be triggered by emotional stress  as in our patient who was recently bereaved. Despite her African-American descent (as takotsubo is more common in Caucasians)  her clinical presentation  investigative findings  and subsequent recovery fit well with the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Conclusion:  This case report serves as a reminder that patients presenting with acute chest pain with ECG changes suggestive of myocardial infarction may not always have coronary artery disease. It is important to consider takotsubo cardiomyopathy in such patients  particularly if there is a recent history of severe emotional stress.
