Genetic influence on TTC remains largely speculative  but given her mother's history of heart disease  her TTC might have some genetic factors.  Diagnosis and Investigations: Her initial diagnostic tests suggested an Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI)  however  subsequent coronary angiography showed no significant coronary artery disease. An echocardiogram was performed which displayed hypokinesia of the left ventricle with apical ballooning  typical of TTC. Cardiac MRI also confirmed the absence of significant atherosclerosis or evidence of myocardial infarction.  Treatment: Jane was initiated on oral beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. She was also advised to limit stress  as extreme emotional stress is often linked to the onset of TTC  suggesting that a stress management plan should be incorporated into her health management strategies.  Social History: She is a widow living alone since her husband passed away 3 years ago. Her two adult children visit regularly. As a retired teacher  Jane is well-educated and possesses good health literacy  which will aid in her understanding and management of her condition.   Conclusion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  is increasingly recognized as an important differential diagnosis in women presenting with chest pain and ECG changes suggestive of an anterior myocardial infarction. Jane’s case is typical as the majority of people diagnosed with TTC are postmenopausal women. Jane's case highlights the necessity of considering TTC as a potential diagnosis in similar patients  and illustrates the important role of non-invasive imaging in diagnosing and managing this condition.

Patient Profile: Ms. A  a 67-year-old Caucasian female from Denver  CO comes to the hospital complaining of chest pain  similar to that of a heart attack. She's a retired school teacher  divorced  living with her adult daughter and her family. She's a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. However  she's been dealing with noticeable emotional stress for the last few months due to the recent death of her eldest son.   Past Medical History: Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  well-controlled under medication for the past ten years. She has no past history of heart disease or any other serious chronic illnesses. Regular follow-ups were maintained.   Presenting Complaints: Ms. A was experiencing severe chest pain  accompanied by shortness of breath and lightheadedness. Her symptoms had suddenly worsened over the past few hours.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Upon electrocardiogram (EKG)  ST-segment elevation was noticed but blood tests showed no hardened blockages typically seen in heart attacks. An echocardiogram showed a significant reduction in left ventricular function with apical ballooning  a typical feature suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""Broken Heart Syndrome"". Coronary Angiography done afterward confirmed the absence of any significant coronary artery disease  solidifying the diagnosis further.   Family History: She has a paternal family history of coronary artery disease. Her father passed away at the age of 73 due to a myocardial infarction. Her mother  now deceased  had diabetes. Ms. A's only sibling  a 69-year-old brother  has a history of hypertension.  Social History: Ms. A is divorced with 3 children. Her eldest son died recently in a car accident  which has had a profound emotional impact on Ms. A. She's a non-smoker and drinks alcohol only occasionally. She leads an active lifestyle  regularly going for walks with her dog.  Treatment and Response: Ms. A was administered beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors to reduce the load on her heart and to improve her ventricular function. Emotional support and counseling were recommended considering her recent emotional trauma.   Uniqueness of the Case: The case brings into light the unique correlation between emotional stress and heart health. Ms. A's recent emotional distress appears to have translated into physical disease  demonstrating the rare  but real  occurrence of 'Broken Heart Syndrome'.  Follow-up: Regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor her cardiac function  check her blood pressure  and evaluate her response to medications. Ms. A was advised to continue her current medications for her hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Prognosis: While takotsubo cardiomyopathy can potentially be life-threatening  most people recover completely with appropriate medical treatment and stress management. The overall prognosis for Ms. A appears to be good considering her previously controlled comorbid conditions and her active lifestyle.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Identity: Mrs. Rebecca Jones  a 58-year-old African American female.  Demographic Information: She is a widower residing in Detroit  with two adult children. She is a retired school teacher and is occasionally engaged in volunteering activities at a local community center.  Reason for visit: The patient presented at the emergency department with acute chest pain and shortness of breath  mimicking heart attack symptoms.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Jones has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. She keeps up with her appointments and takes prescribed medications consistently. She has no history of heart disease but has experienced periodic bouts of depression since her husband's death two years ago.  Family History: Her mother suffered from hypertension and myocardial infarction  leading to her death at 70. Her father was diabetic and died at the age of 76 due to complications of diabetes. Her older brother  aged 63  is currently living with a diagnosis of heart failure.  Symptoms: Mrs. Jones was experiencing severe chest pain  shortness of breath  sweatiness  and a sense of impending doom. The event occurred after she received news of her best friend's sudden death. Separate from these symptoms  she reported episodes of lightheadedness in the past two weeks. She denies any history of substance abuse  addiction  or harmful behavioral tendencies.  Clinical Examination: On physical exam  she was found to be tachycardic and hypertensive. An ECG showed ST-segment elevation  which initially suggested a myocardial infarction. However  a coronary angiogram showed no significant coronary artery disease which could explain her symptoms.  Diagnosis: Taken together  her symptoms  the immediate temporal link with an emotionally stressful event  and findings of apical ballooning on cardiac echocardiogram led to a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.  Plan:  Considering her diagnosis  Mrs. Jones was initiated on ACE inhibitors to manage her blood pressure and beta-blockers to address her tachycardia. She was also referred to a psychologist to help manage her emotional stressors. Patient education is planned to outline the need for stress management in preventing future events.  This case outlines a classic presentation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which is commonly triggered by significant psychosocial stress and often mimics an acute coronary syndrome event. The condition is more common in postmenopausal women and may have a higher incidence in patients with a history of neurologic or psychiatric illness.

Subject: Male Patient Age 62  suffering from Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy   Demographics: Our patient  Mr. J  is a Caucasian male  aged 62  a retired high-school teacher who resides in suburban USA. He lives alone  is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. J. was admitted to the emergency department (ED) reporting acute chest pain and breathlessness following a heated confrontation during a local community meeting. He described the pain as severe  crushing  and radiating to his left arm.  Past Medical History: Mr. J’s past medical history includes mild hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been managing these conditions through diet modification  exercise regime and medication (Lisinopril 10mg once a day for Hypertension; Simvastatin 20mg at nights for Hyperlipidemia).  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his mother had a history of stroke. He has one older sibling who is healthy.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  his blood pressure was elevated (160/95mmHg) and his heart rate was slightly increased (110 beats per minute). There were no significant findings on lung or abdominal examination. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevations in the precordial leads and his troponin levels were slightly elevated.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Due to ECG changes and troponin elevation  acute coronary syndrome was suspected  and he was sent for an emergent coronary angiography  which surprisingly was normal. Echocardiogram revealed a reduced ejection fraction with apical ballooning and basal hyperkinesis  findings consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as “broken heart syndrome”. These investigations led to the diagnosis of TCM  which was confirmed by running a Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Stress and anxiety due to the confrontation likely acted as a trigger for the TCM.  Treatment and Prognosis: Mr. J was treated with aspirin  beta-blockers  and ACE inhibitors  coupled with close observation in the cardiac care unit. As is typical with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  complete recovery of left ventricular function was expected within weeks following appropriate medical management and stress reduction.  The plan includes close outpatient follow-up with his primary care provider and a referral for psychological interventions aimed at stress management. In addition  reiteration of the importance of adherence to his hypertension and hyperlipidemia medications  a low-sodium diet  and routine exercise was undertaken.  This case is typical for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which predominantly affects postmenopausal women but can also occur in men  particularly during periods of extreme emotional stress.

Patient Case Presentation: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Background: The patient  a 68-year-old Asian female  presented complaints of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. This was her first instance of such a complaint. She is a law-abiding citizen  retired  living alone in suburban area with adequate social support. She is a widow and has two adult children with no history of cardiac diseases.   Her past medical history was significant for hypertension and hypothyroidism  which were well controlled with antihypertensives and thyroid hormone replacement therapy. She denied alcohol  tobacco  or illicit drug use. She has a family history of hypertension but no diagnosed cardiac diseases.  Clinical Presentation: The patient presented with symptoms typical of acute myocardial infarction  including acute  severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  alongside shortness of breath. On exam  BP was 150/90 mmHg  pulse 105 bpm  and she appeared in mild distress.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed an ST-segment elevation suggestive of anterolateral myocardial ischemia without Q waves. Cardiac bio-markers were elevated - Troponin-T was 2.5 ng/mL (normal limits = 0-0.1 ng/mL).  On hospital Day 2  a coronary angiogram revealed no significant coronary artery disease. The diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was pointed out on further evaluation by echocardiogram that demonstrated hypokinesis of the mid and apical segments with hyperkinesis of the basal segments typical of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (‘octopus pot’ sign).  Management: She was treated conservatively with ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  diuretics to relieve congestive symptoms  and reassurance. On Day 5  the patient's symptomatology had much improved. She was discharged with caution to avoid severe emotional stress and with the direction to continue her regimen of medications and regular follow-ups.  Prognosis and Follow-up: Given the lack of recurrent chest pain and the beneficial effect of early conservative management  her prognosis is generally good.  She was monitored closely with a 2-week follow-up to ensure regression of cardiographic changes and again after 3 months. She was advised on the potential complications such as arrhythmia  heart failure and rupture and told to take immediate help if symptoms recur.   Summary: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy often presents similarly to an acute coronary syndrome  but it is an entirely different condition usually induced by extreme stress  more common in post-menopausal women. Despite its dramatic onset  this syndrome generally has a good prognosis  provided it is identified and managed in a timely manner.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Ms. A is a 65-year-old African American female who presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. She is a long-standing resident of Washington  DC  living alone after being widowed 5 years ago. She has two living children who also reside in other states. She's a retired teacher and has an active lifestyle consisting of frequent walks and yoga sessions.  Past Medical History: Ms. A was previously healthy with no chronic conditions such as hypertension  diabetes or asthma. She had a full menopause at 50 years with no postmenopausal complication or hormone replacement therapy. Ms. A is a lifelong non-smoker and she consumes alcohol occasionally.   Family History: Her mother died at an older age due to Alzheimer’s disease  and her father died from a stroke at the age of 70. One of her siblings was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 55. There is no documented history of cardiac disease in the immediate family.  Presenting Complaints: Ms. A experienced sudden and intense chest pain radiating to the back and described it to be like 'a heavy vest'. Accompanying shortness of breath exacerbated the panic she was in.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  Ms. A appeared distressed but her vital signs on admission were stable: blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  heart rate 95 beats per min  temperature 37.0°C  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Heart and lung examinations were unremarkable. There was no palpable peripheral oedema.  Investigations: Her electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in anterior leads suggesting an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. Her initial troponin level was significantly elevated. However  coronary angiogram revealed normal coronary arteries  not typical of myocardial infarction.  Diagnosis and Progress: Given her presenting symptoms  ECG changes  elevated cardiac enzymes  and the lack of coronary artery disease on angiogram  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM) or 'broken-heart syndrome'. She was also having an anniversary of her husband's death  pointing towards the psychological stress event that precipitated the TCM.  Management and Follow-up: Ms. A was started on a conservative heart failure regimen  including beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. She responded well to the medication  and her symptoms started to improve within a week. Three months follow-up echocardiography showed completely normal left ventricular function.  This case highlights the importance of considering Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy when treating postmenopausal women with sudden-onset chest pain and stress. It also emphasizes the need for a high degree of suspicion and a comprehensive diagnostic approach  considering that this condition can easily be mistaken for acute coronary syndrome.

Patient Presentation: Ms. Santiago  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the Emergency Department with a chief complaint of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She reported the sudden onset of these symptoms while attending her husband's funeral earlier in the day  with radiating left arm pain and feelings of faintness.  Past Medical History: In evaluation of her past medical history  we note that Ms. Santiago had been previously diagnosed with hypertension. However  she has been showing compliance to prescribed antihypertensives. She has no history of diabetes  stroke  or ischemic heart disease. She has a documented allergic reaction to penicillin where she broke out in a rash.  Family History: Her family history reveals that her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 72 and her father had a stroke at 76. She has a younger sister who has type 2 diabetes. There is no reported incidence of cardiomyopathies in her close family circle.  Social History: Ms. Santiago is retired. She quit smoking 20 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. She lives alone  as her only child is out of state.  Physical Examination & Investigation Findings: Upon examination  Ms. Santiago was in distress. Risk factors comprised her age  female gender  post-menopause state  and the intense psychological stress due to her husband’s sudden demise. Physical exam showed a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  and she was afebrile. ECG revealed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Lab results showed marginally elevated troponin levels and normal cholesterol levels. Echocardiogram showed left ventricular apical ballooning with a low ejection fraction of 45%. Coronary angiography did not reveal any significant blockages that would validate ischemic heart disease.  Diagnosis: Combining the information given by the patient's history  physical examination and investigations  Ms. Santiago was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome.""  Management and Patient Education: Ms. Santiago was admitted to the cardiology unit. Management included an ACE inhibitor  beta-blocker  and aspirin. Psychotherapy was also advised to manage stress.   She was educated about her condition  the significance of medication adherence  and scheduled for follow-ups. She was further educated about early recognition of heart failure symptoms and advised to revise her lifestyle  incorporating a balanced diet  regular exercise  and stress management.  Ms. Santiago was referred to a local support group for individuals having lost loved ones  and arrangements were made for her son to be more involved in her care. She was scheduled for follow-up in a cardiomyopathy clinic in 3-6 months to assess the regression of her cardiac changes.

Patient Profile: Ms. MG  is a 69-year-old African American woman who resides in Miami  Florida. She works as a retired school teacher and lives alone  with regular contact to her close family who live in the same area.  Presenting Complaint and Past Medical History: Ms. MG presented to the Emergency Department (ER) with acute chest pain and fainting spells that began earlier that morning. She has a history of hypertension  and is currently managing it with Amlodipine. Apart from that  she has remained in good health and reports no previous history of cardiac problems. Relative to lifestyle factors  she is a non-smoker and drinks a moderate amount of alcohol.  Family History:  Her family history is significant with her father  who had an ischemic heart disease and died in his late 50s  and her mother who passed of cancer in her 70s. She has two brothers  one of whom has type 2 diabetes while the other enjoys good health.  Hospital Course and Diagnosis: Upon admission to the ER  her blood pressure was slightly elevated  and blood tests showed a mild increase in cardiac biomarkers. The initial diagnosis was acute coronary syndrome (ACS)  but subsequent coronary angiography did not reveal any significant obstructions in her coronary arteries. An electrocardiogram (EKG) was carried out  which showed ST-segment elevation  and an echocardiogram indicated reduced left ventricular function with apical ballooning  suggesting the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).  Background: This condition  also known as broken-heart syndrome or stress cardiomyopathy  is characteristically seen in postmenopausal women and often triggered by intense emotional or physiological stress. Interestingly  Ms. MG had recently lost her best friend  which had caused her significant distress.  Treatment:  She was treated with beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and emotional counseling.   Outcome: Ms. MG's chest pain resolved following treatment  and she was discharged from the hospital after two weeks. During re-evaluation after six weeks  her left ventricular function had returned to normal. She was advised to continue with medication and regular follow-ups with her cardiologist. Psychological counseling was also suggested due to the stress-related nature of TCM to support her mental health.  This case shows how emotional stress can lead to significant physiological impact  underscoring the importance of managing both physical and emotional health in patients.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African American female presenting with acute onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and feelings of intense anxiety. These symptoms began suddenly following the death of her husband  approximately two weeks prior to her presentation. The patient doesn’t have any past medical history of any chronic illnesses  such as hypertension  diabetes mellitus  or any cardiovascular disease. However  she admits to living a highly stressful lifestyle due to her recent widowhood. She denies tobacco  alcohol  or any substance abuse.  Physically  she appears anxious and distressed. Vital signs on presentation include: heart rate of 105 beats/minute  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 21 breaths/minute  temperature of 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air.  Complete Demographics:  Her social history includes being a widow with no children and she is a retired teacher. She lives alone with her dog in Boca Raton  Florida  USA. The patient mentions she has a limited social network  with her primary companion being her late husband. She reports her ethnicity as African American and her primary language as English.  Family History:  The patient’s father died at 70 from what she reports as 'heart trouble.' Her mother is still living  at 85  diagnosed with type-2 diabetes. In terms of siblings  she has an older sister who  aged 68  has been diagnosed with breast cancer and hypertension  and a younger brother  aged 60  with no significant medical issues.  Clinical Condition:  On further examination  an ECG shows ST elevation in anterior leads  and Troponin levels are mildly elevated. Based on the patient's symptoms  ECG and biomarker findings  the initial suspicion is the diagnosis of an acute myocardial infarction. However  an emergency angiogram reveals no significant coronary artery disease that could have been responsible for her presenting symptoms.  Subsequently  an echocardiogram demonstrates apical ballooning of the left ventricle  consistent with ‘Takotsubo cardiomyopathy’ or ‘broken heart syndrome ' a condition commonly precipitated by severe emotional stress. This diagnosis is problematically uncommon in African-American women  as it has been predominantly noticed in postmenopausal white women. However  no demographic background is immune  and this case illustrates that emotional stress can potentially induce drastic cardiovascular events in any individual  irrespective of their ethnicity or social background.  Patient Management:  She was managed conservatively with beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and a brief course of diuretics for her mild pulmonary congestion. Additionally  she was referred for bereavement counselling and stress management therapy to cope with her loss and minimize further episodes. On four-week follow-up  her recovery was uneventful with a noticeable improvement in her symptoms and echocardiographic appearance.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the significance of incorporating emotional stress in the differential diagnoses of acute coronary syndrome  especially in patients with recent stressful events. It emphasizes the need for a comprehensive management plan that includes addressing psychosocial stressors to prevent recurrence of such episodes.

Patient Presentation: The patient is Ms. K  a 72-year-old Asian female  presenting with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. Ms. K. is a retired school teacher living alone  widowed  with no children. She has a history of hypertension  well-controlled with lisinopril  but no other significant past medical history. She neither smokes  drinks  nor uses any illicit substances. Her family history includes a mother with diabetes  a father with coronary artery disease  and a sister with breast cancer.   Admission: Ms. K was initially admitted during the weekend when she experienced an intensely stressful event  her house got burgled. The sudden onset of chest pain while watching her property being stolen  and the following exacerbating dyspnea  quickly prompted her to seek medical attention.  Clinical Presentation: On examination  Ms. K appeared distressed but conscious. Her blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg  heart rate was 110 bpm  temperature of 37.2°C  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Elevated heart rate and blood pressure were indicative of her overall distress and anxiety.  Investigations: Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST elevation  and blood tests revealed slightly elevated cardiac enzymes. However  coronary angiography performed to determine presence of ischemic heart disease revealed no substantial disease or blockages that would explain the ST elevation. Apical ballooning of the left ventricle  as shown on echocardiogram  with hyperkinesia at the base and hypokinesia at the apex  raised suspicion for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy. The patient's levels of Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) were also noticeably higher than the normal range.  Diagnosis: Considering her pre-existing hypertension  elderly age  post-menopausal status  and the intensely stressful trigger incident  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  or stress-induced cardiomyopathy  was diagnosed.   Treatment: Ms. K was treated with standard heart failure medications (ACE inhibitors  Beta Blockers)  and her hypertension was managed accordingly. A consult with a psychiatrist was arranged for stress management counselling.   Health Follow-up:  Fortunately  with appropriate management  her condition improved drastically. Two months following her initial presentation  her follow-up echocardiography showed improvement in left ventricular function. Ms. K has been symptom-free since then and her latest ECG and cardiac enzyme levels are within normal limits. Strongly suggested lifestyle modifications and ongoing psychic therapy sessions to manage stress are part of her long-term follow-up program.

Patient Presentation:   Name: Maria Fernandes Age: 68 years Sex: Female Origin: Hispanic Occupation: Retired Nurse  Presenting Problem: Ms. Fernandes presented at the hospital with central chest pain radiating to the left arm  nausea  and faintness. She reported that these symptoms began after getting news that her brother had passed away suddenly.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is experiencing well-controlled diabetes with metformin (first-line therapy) and has been on antihypertensive medication (ACE inhibitors) for the last 10 years. There is no history of prior heart disease  stroke  major surgeries  or other significant medical conditions. She quit smoking 10 years ago and drinks alcohol only socially. Her glycemic control has been good  and her last HbA1c was 6.8%.   Family History: There is a family history of cardiovascular disease. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at 72 years  and her mother had a stroke at 75 but survived. None of her siblings have a known history of cardiac syndromes.  Clinical Examination and Diagnosis: An electrocardiogram was performed and showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads but no pathological Q waves. The initial troponin I level was slightly elevated. Urgent coronary angiography showed no obstructive coronary artery disease  but left ventriculogram revealed midventricular and apical akinesia along with hypercontractility of the basal walls. Echocardiographic images demonstrated reduced ejection fraction with regional wall motion abnormalities and apical ballooning. This  along with the patient's presentation and examination findings  led to the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM).   Note: Contrary to common perception  TCM is seen not only in post-menopausal women but also affects a significant proportion of the Hispanic/LatinX population albeit with no clear reason. It is often precipitated by emotional or physical stress (like bereavement in this case) and has a clinical presentation resembling acute coronary syndrome. It tends to manifest more commonly in individuals with a type A (stress-prone) personality and those with psychiatric and neurologic disorders.  Treatment Plan: As she was hemodynamically stable  conservative management was implemented that included ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and aspirin. Counseling to deal with her emotional stress was also executed.  Prognosis: Tako-tsubo cardiomyopathy has a generally favorable prognosis  but patients require close follow-up as there is a risk of complications such as heart failure  arrhythmias  and stroke. The reversible nature of this cardiomyopathy means that recovery of ventricular function can be expected within weeks to months. However  emotional support and effective stress management are crucial due to the strong correlation with emotional stress.

Case Presentation: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old African American female  named M.B. She is a retired school teacher  living in New York. She is divorced with two adult children  and she lives alone.  Presenting Chief Complaint: M.B. presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left side of her neck and arm. She complained of sudden difficulty breathing  mild nausea and fainting episodes.  Vital Signs and Physical Examination: On examination  her blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  pulse rate irregular 90 beats/min  temperature 98.6°F  and respiratory rate was 22 breaths/min. M.B. was anxious and diaphoretic  but she was pain-free during the examination.  Past Medical History: M.B. has no prior history of cardiovascular disease. However  she is hypertensive and has been on antihypertensive medications for seven years. M.B. also has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus for ten years  which has been managed with diet and oral hypoglycemic medications. She does not smoke but consumes alcohol socially.  Family History: Her mother died of stroke at 78 years and her father died of myocardial infarction at 72 years.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrated ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V4. Her troponin levels were elevated  indicative of heart muscle damage. Coronary angiography revealed no significant coronary artery disease ruling out myocardial infarction. Left ventriculogram done revealed typical ballooning of the apex with good basal contraction suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. M.B. was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  based on the combination of clinical presentation and imaging findings.  Management and Follow-up: M.B. was treated with beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors and aspirin  which relieved her symptoms of chest pain. She was advised to reduce stress and incorporate relaxation practices into her daily routine. On her follow-up appointment after 2 months  she reported no further chest pain or difficulty breathing. Repeat echocardiography demonstrated resolution of previous LV dysfunction  confirming the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Conclusion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  commonly known as broken heart syndrome  typically affects postmenopausal women and is often triggered by severe mental or physical stress. M.B. is a typical patient with takotsubo cardiomyopathy given her profile as a postmenopausal woman exposed to stress. With appropriate management and stress reduction techniques  she has made a good recovery.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. L.T. is a 67-year-old  Asian female  living in an urban dwelling  who is currently retired. Her occupation had previously been of a high-stress environment  being a senior lawyer in a demanding firm.  Past Medical History:   Ms. L.T. has a history of well-managed hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  for which she takes Lisinopril. She is non-diabetic; she doesn't smoke and only uses alcohol minimally. Her last mammogram was normal. Three months back  she had an abnormal thyroid function test but the repeating test returned to normal.  Family History:   She has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. Her father fell victim to a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 60  and her mother passed away following a stroke at age 79. She has two siblings with hypertension and one with coronary artery disease after the age of 50.  Presenting Complaint:   Ms. L.T. presented to the emergency department with acute onset crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm. It was associated with nausea and weaknees which began after she heard the sudden news of her only daughter's fatal car accident far away from home.   Investigations:  Her ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads and her troponin I level was raised. However  her coronary angiogram did not reveal any significant obstructive coronary artery disease that would explain the ECG findings. Echocardiogram exhibited dyskinesis in the mid-apical segments but preserved systolic function in the basal segments resulting in a balloon-like appearance of the left ventricle during systole; a characteristic finding in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Diagnosis:  Based on her sudden onset stress-induced symptoms  normal coronary angiogram  characteristic ECG and echocardiogram findings  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome"".  Management:  She was managed with aspirin  beta-blockers  and ACE inhibitors. She was also recommended for emotional support and psychological therapies to deal with her grief and prescribed selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for her acute emotional distress.  Discussion:  The exact prevalence of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is unclear  but it is observed that this condition is more common in postmenopausal women and it may often be underdiagnosed. Increased awareness and understanding of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is essential to ensure patients like Ms. L.T. receive prompt and appropriate treatment.  Follow-up:  Ms. L.T. was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in 1 month and referred for grief counseling. Regular echocardiography is planned to monitor the progression of her ventricle recovery.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Y  a 65 year-old male of Caucasian descent  was admitted to the hospital with primary complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations which started after a major stressful event. The patient is a retired military serviceman who recently lost his wife. He has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also exhibits moderate alcohol use and has a 20-year history of smoking. He denies prior heart ailments but had been under treatment for anxiety disorders for 5 years. He lives alone and does not have any immediate family but informs that his father had succumbed to a heart attack at age 70.  Clinical Presentation:  On examination  Mr. Y appeared in acute distress with a blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg  pulse 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate 24 breaths/minute and SAT 92%. He complained of severe chest pain that was radiating to his left arm. Electrocardiography revealed ST-segment elevation in the anterior and lateral leads.  Hospital Course:  Under the impression of acute coronary syndrome (ACS)  he was transferred to the coronary care unit. Emergency coronary angiography was performed which showed no relevant stenoses. However  the left ventriculogram revealed apical ballooning with reduced ejection fraction (~35%) which indicated Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM). Blood tests further confirmed the diagnosis by revealing elevated levels of Troponin I and brain natriuretic peptide but normal CPK–MB levels.  Management:  He was treated with supportive therapy for heart failure: ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and diuretics. Due to his elevated anxiety levels and subsequent stress  psychiatric consultation was taken  and anxiolytics were started. After a week of treatment  there was a significant improvement in his condition with normalization of Ejection Fraction with lessened wall motion abnormalities  as seen in the echocardiogram.  Conclusion:  This case of Mr. Y highlights the fact that Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy can also present with typical ACS symptoms and must be considered in differential diagnosis  notably in postmenopausal women and older men experiencing severe stress. It also throws light on the essential incorporation of mental health management in the therapeutic plan of such patients dealing with recurrent severe stress and anxiety.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Smith  a 57-year-old Asian male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain and shortness of breath  which developed suddenly after hearing about the unexpected death of a close family friend. The pain was described as squeezing in character  radiating to his left arm  and was rated as 8/10 in intensity. Other associated symptoms included profuse sweating  palpitations  and mild nausea.  Past Medical History  Mr. Smith is known to have Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension  for which he is on oral metformin and calcium channel blockers  respectively. He quit smoking 12 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. His last annual check-up was six months ago  and his diabetes and blood pressure were well under control. He had no previous cardiac-related issues.  Family History  His family history revealed that his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 63 and his mother is living with osteoporosis. His eldest brother  aged 65  is also hypertensive.   Upon admission  his vitals were: BP-150/90 mmHg  HR- 105 bpm  RR-22 breaths/min  and SpO2-94% on room air. Physical examination was generally unremarkable.   Investigation and Diagnosis  His ECG revealed ST-segment elevation in anterior leads  initially raising suspicion for an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). However  his cardiac enzyme levels were only slightly elevated  which is unusual for a typical STEMI. An immediate transthoracic echocardiogram showed left ventricular (LV) apical akinesis with hyperkinesis of the basal segments  a finding consistent with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM).   Further workup  including a coronary angiogram  ruled out occlusive coronary artery disease. All findings  clinical presentation  and preceding emotional stress confirmed the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also commonly known as Broken Heart Syndrome.  Treatment and Follow-ups  He was treated with supportive measures – beta-adrenergic blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and a short course of diuretics to optimise his cardiac function. Due to the transient nature of TCM  Mr. Smith gradually improved over the next few weeks.  In the subsequent follow-ups  his chest pain completely resolved  and an echocardiogram undertaken three months later showed reversal of the previous wall-motion abnormalities  confirming the transient nature of the illness.  This case illustrates the importance of identifying the unique characteristics of TCM as a differential diagnosis in patients  especially postmenopausal women or older men experiencing stress-induced acute chest pain. It emphasizes the need to rule out obstructive coronary arterial disease in such situations  considering the implications for treatment and prognosis. Importantly  the transient nature of TCM requires careful patient education about prognosis and follow-up.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American female named Mrs. Johnson  residing in the urban heart of Detroit  Michigan. She is a widow with no children and lives alone in her apartment  with occasional visits from her younger sister and niece. Mrs. Johnson  an elementary school teacher before statutory retirement  has a vivacious social life involving the local church and volunteer organizations. She experienced significant stress due to the loss of her close friend to COVID-19 recently.  Medical History:  Mrs. Johnson's past medical history includes hypertension  managed with amlodipine  and osteoarthritis. She also has a history of major depressive disorder  which has been controlled with medication and psychotherapy over the past decade. Additionally  she suffers from chronic low back pain  for which she takes ibuprofen occasionally. She does not smoke or consume alcohol regularly. There is no history of substance abuse.  Recent Presentation and Symptoms:  Mrs. Johnson presented with acute onset chest pain and difficulty in breathing after learning about her friend's death. EKG abnormalities were noted  showing ST elevations in the anterior leads. Her initial troponin levels were also elevated.   Diagnostic Findings:   Upon evaluation at the hospital  an echocardiogram showed apical ballooning of the heart with preserved basal function  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (also known as broken heart syndrome). The coronary angiogram did not show any significant obstructions. Together these findings confirmed the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.  Treatment and Outcome:  Mrs. Johnson was managed professionally with supportive care  including beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors to manage her heart health situation. Mental health services were also consulted due to the significant stressful event that may have triggered her symptoms. She was discharged home in stable condition on her previously mentioned hypertensive medications  newly prescribed beta-blockers  and intensive counseling to help her cope with her friend's death.  Family and Social History:  There's no known family history of cardiovascular diseases. Her parents are deceased; her father died from colon cancer at the age of 70  and her mother had Alzheimer's disease and lived up to 79. Her younger sister  age 62  is healthy. Mrs. Johnson leads a rather sedentary lifestyle but has been working towards incorporating regular walks in her daily routine. She is mostly independent and copes well with activities of daily living but has been reporting feelings of loneliness and sadness post her friend's demise.  In a nutshell  stress cardiomyopathy or Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a condition that primarily affects postmenopausal women and can be triggered by severe emotional stress. Mrs. Johnson's case underscores the significance of psychological stress contributing to physical ailments and emphasizes the importance of comprehensive care  intertwining physical health management with psychological counseling.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Susan G.  a 65-year-old Asian female  presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm and jaw after hearing about her son's sudden accidental death.   History:  Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and she is currently under medication with antihypertensives. She denies diabetes and any past incidents of myocardial infarctions. Her father had a history of heart failure at the age of 70.  Presenting Condition:  Upon admission  she was tachycardic with a heart rate of 115 beats per minute  and her blood pressure was 150/95 mm Hg. The physical examination was only significant for cardiac-related irregularities including an S4 gallop and a non-radiating pain in the midst chest area during palpation. She also reported associated shortness of breath. She does not smoke cigarettes  does not take illicit drugs and consumed alcohol socially.   Diagnostic Testing:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevations in the anterolateral leads consistent with acute myocardial ischemia  but her coronary angiogram results were negative for occlusions or stenosis. Troponin levels were mildly elevated at 2.0 ng/mL  unusual for an acute coronary event.   An echocardiogram showed reduced left ventricular function (LVEF 35%) and apical ballooning consistent with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM).   Diagnosis:  Given her recent significant emotional stress and characteristic cardiac findings  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as Broken Heart Syndrome.   Treatment:  She was treated with supportive care  including beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. Given the short duration of onset  she was managed conservatively.  Prognosis:  While Ms. Susan's emotional status improved  her cardiac function is in the process of monitored recovery. The prognosis seems favorable as TCM is typically reversible  however  this depends on her emotional coping and her cardiac condition's response to the medications.   A psychiatric evaluation was recommended for help in dealing with the grief of her son's sudden death to avoid further complications.  This presentation mirrors the typical patient population diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  with a predilection for postmenopausal women  often triggered by extreme emotional or physical stress. TCM prevalence is particularly significant in women over the age of 55 with various studies indicating 90% of the cases occurring in women. Furthermore  genetic predisposition may play a role in TCM. Ethnic-wise  literature shows a high degree of underrepresentation  although limited data suggests potential underdiagnosis in the Asian population.                                       References: Kurowski  V. et al. (2007). Apical and midventricular transient left ventricular dysfunction syndrome (tako-tsubo cardiomyopathy): frequency  mechanisms  and prognosis. Chest  132(3)  809-816.

Patient Case Presentation:  Demographics:  The patient is a 72-year-old Asian female.  Presenting Complaints:  She was brought to the emergency department with complaints of acute chest pain radiating to the left arm  associated with shortness of breath and significant emotional stress arising from the recent passing of her husband.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known case of well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has no history of ischemic heart disease nor does she smoke or drink alcohol.  Family History:  Her parents were both non-smokers and lived into their late 80s without any significant cardiac diseases. She has three siblings  one of whom has coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination:  On examination  she appeared anxious and was sweaty. Her blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 90 beats/minute  and breath sounds were reduced bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation did not reveal any murmurs or irregular rhythm.  Investigations: Her lab results demonstrated raised troponin levels and ECG showed ST-segment elevation suggestive of a myocardial infarction. However  her coronary angiography did not reveal any significant obstruction in the coronary arteries  which would typically be seen in a classic myocardial infarction. An echocardiography revealed apical ballooning of the left ventricle  which is not typical for myocardial infarction but suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Diagnosis: Based on the echocardiographic findings coupled with the patient's symptoms  an elevated troponin level  the emotional stress event  and normal angiography findings  a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was made.  Plan:  The patient was managed with supportive care  including ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and psychological support to cope with her recent loss. Since her symptoms did not resolve completely  she was referred to a cardiologist for long-term follow-up care and management.  Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as “broken-heart syndrome ” predominantly affects postmenopausal women and can be triggered by severe emotional stress. Manifesting with acute chest pain and signs similar to myocardial infarction  it is differentiated by a lack of obstructive coronary artery disease on angiography and unique apical ballooning of the left ventricle. Though the mechanism is not entirely clear  excessive release of stress hormones leading to myocardial stunning is considered to be the pathophysiology. Like in this patient  treatment is usually supportive.  References: Prasad  A.  et al. (2008). Apical ballooning syndrome (Tako-Tsubo or stress cardiomyopathy): a mimic of acute myocardial infarction. American Heart Journal  155(3)  408-417.

Patient Presentation  Female Patient: Bailey T.  Age: 71  Race: Caucasian   Bailey is a retired schoolteacher who presented complaining of sudden  severe chest discomfort and shortness of breath  following the sudden passing of her husband a week ago. She has a history of well-controlled hypertension and a mild case of type II diabetes. She does not smoke or drink alcohol excessively  and she maintains a relatively balanced diet and moderate physical activity.  Past Medical History  Bailey was diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago and has been on regular antihypertensive medication. Her diabetes was diagnosed five years ago  and she effectively manages it with oral hypoglycemic agents and lifestyle changes.  Family History  No history of cardiovascular disease was reported in her immediate family. Her father suffered from type II diabetes  and her mother had hypothyroidism.  Clinical Assessment and Diagnosis  On admission  Bailey had an elevated blood pressure of 155/100 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  and respiratory rate of 20 bpm. She appeared anxious and distressed. Electrocardiogram displayed ST-segment elevation  indicating myocardial ischemia.   Laboratory findings included significantly increased levels of cardiac troponin and Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP)  suggesting acute heart stress. The coronary angiogram showed no substantial evidence of coronary artery disease  which indicated no risk of a heart attack.  However  an echocardiogram and left ventriculogram showed that her heart's left ventricle had an abnormal contraction pattern  which is recognized as ""apical ballooning."" This finding led to the diagnosis of ""Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy"" (TC)  also known as ""broken heart syndrome.""  Treatment & Progress  Bailey was treated with beta-blockers to decrease her heart rate and blood pressure  and angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors to enhance her heart's function and prevent further heart damage. The emotional stress induced by her husband's passing  causing TC was also addressed  placing her under counselling and providing support groups.  Follow-up   Bailey was scheduled for regular follow-ups every two weeks for cardiac function assessment. After three months  the echocardiogram showed that her left ventricle's function had significantly improved and was back to normal.  Discussion  Around 90% of reported Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy cases are in post-menopausal women aged between 58 and 75. Precipitating stressors frequently include sudden emotional or physical distress. Although Bailey had hypertension and type II diabetes  her major risk factor appeared to be the emotional stress from her husband's death. Close monitoring and supportive care are integral to her recovery  along with addressing her emotional wellbeing.

Patient Introduction: The patient under discussion is a 68-year-old female  single  retired school teacher  and of Hispanic descent. She was previously diagnosed with hypertension and primary osteoporosis  controlled with medication: Amlodipine (5mg OD) and Alendronate (70mg weekly).  Presenting Complaint: The patient arrived in the emergency department (ED) complaining of a sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain onset was shortly after receiving news of her brother's sudden death.  Medical History: She has a known history of essential hypertension for the past nine years and primary osteoporosis diagnosed two years ago. She is allergic to Penicillin  which causes a rash. The patient denies any history of diabetes mellitus  dyslipidemia  or any thyroid disorders. She has also never smoked or consumed alcohol.  Family History: Her father had died at the age of 76 due to acute myocardial infarction  and her mother had passed away at 81 from complications of Alzheimer's disease. She also had a younger brother who recently passed away at 65 due to a car accident. None of her close family members had any history of heart failure  stroke  or cancer.  Physical Examination: On examination in the ED  her blood pressure was elevated (155/90 mmHg)  pulse rate was 110 beats per minute  and her respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute. Her body mass index was noted to be within the normal range. She appeared anxious and was in obvious distress due to pain.  Investigations: The initial ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Cardiac enzymes were elevated  with Troponin at 1.0 ng/mL  clearly surpassing the upper reference limit. In the ED  emergent catheterization was performed which did not show any significant coronary artery disease.  Diagnosis & Management:  Given her symptoms  ECG changes  and catheterization findings  a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was suspected. This was later confirmed by a transthoracic echocardiogram  which showed apical ballooning and hyperkinesis of the basal segments of the left ventricle  reminiscent of the 'Octopus Pot' sign. The patient was managed with supportive therapy  including Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  Beta-blockers  and Aspirin. The emotional stress of bereavement was addressed by referring her to a clinical psychologist.  Conclusion: The patient illustrates several risk factors associated with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  such as postmenopausal status  hypertension  and severe emotional stress. This case underscores the crucial importance of considering Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in older women presenting with acute chest pain  especially in the context of emotional stress.

Patient Presentation: Name: Mrs. Ava Johnson Age: 68 years Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Marital Status: Widow Location: Boston  Massachusetts   Presenting Complaints:  Mrs. Johnson presented to the emergency department with anxiety  chest pain  and shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  She is known to have hypertension controlled with medication  and is overweight with a BMI of 31 kg/m2. She has no history of ischemic heart disease  diabetes mellitus  or any other chronic illnesses. There is no history of mental illness  but intense chronic stress due to the death of her husband four months ago. She quit smoking 5 years ago after a 30-year history of cigarette use.  Family History:  Her father died of a myocardial infarction at age 76; her mother had stroke at age 79  and has sibling with hypertension.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed mild pallor and anxiety. Breathing sounded normal but her heart sounds were a bit louder on auscultation. Her blood pressure was 149/89 mmHg  and heart rate was 98 bpm. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation and T-wave inversion. Troponin I level was high (0.8 ng/ml).  Investigations and Diagnosis: She was suspected with acute coronary syndrome and admitted to the cardiac care unit. Coronary angiography showed no significant coronary artery disease  but left ventriculography indicated apical ballooning. This  combined with her emotional trigger  led to the diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Treatment and Outcome: Mrs. Johnson was managed conservatively with supportive care: beta blockers (metoprolol)  ACE inhibitors (lisinopril)  aspirin  and a statin (atorvastatin). Her chest pain resolved in next 48 hours  and improvement in cardiac function was seen on echocardiogram after 1 week. She was referred to a dietician and psychologist for continued support in managing her weight and stress levels.  Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  or broken heart syndrome  predominantly affects postmenopausal women and can be triggered by emotional stress. Clinically  it may mimic acute coronary syndrome but shows characteristic findings on ventriculography or echocardiogram in the absence of obstructive coronary artery disease. Although the prognosis in most cases is excellent  supportive care  prevention of complications  and emotional support are key to management.

Patient Presentation:   Mrs. T  a 67-year-old  African-American single retired nurse  presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset severe chest pain radiating to her left arm and shortness of breath occurring for approximately six hours. In terms of past medical history  she has hypertension that is relatively well-controlled with lisinopril. Her other significant past medical history includes generalized anxiety disorder treated with sertraline.   Social history revealed increased stress due to the recent death of her only son a week ago. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. She lives independently. The family history was slim; she mentioned that her mother passed away from stroke at age 75  and her father died at age 82 from coronary artery disease.   On physical examination  Mrs. T was alert but moderately distressed due to pain. Her oxygen saturation was 90% on room air. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-elevation mimicking myocardial infarction. However  upon further diagnostics via cardiac enzymes  echocardiogram  and coronary angiography  she was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  which generally presents as a sudden apparent heart attack triggered by severe stress.  Management and Outcome:  She was managed with supportive care for heart failure  including oxygen therapy  furosemide  and angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI). Mrs. T's condition gradually improved over the course of one week. She was discharged with close outpatient follow-up and a recommendation to a grief counselor to help manage the psychological stress she has been experiencing.   Discussion:  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy  is relatively rare  diagnosing an estimated 1-2% of patients presenting with acute coronary syndrome. It's more common in postmenopausal women and those exposed to significant emotional or physical stress. This case helps shed light on the diverse paths through which stress can cause physical harm. It also emphasizes the importance of an appropriate diagnostic approach to patients presenting with symptoms suggesting acute coronary syndrome.   Reference sources used: Lee VH  Oh JK  Mulvagh SL  Wijdicks EF. Mechanisms in neurogenic stress cardiomyopathy after aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage. Neurocrit Care. 2006;5(3):243-249. Madhavan M  Rihal CS  Lerman A  Prasad A. Acute heart failure in apical ballooning syndrome (TakoTsubo/stress cardiomyopathy): clinical correlates and Mayo Clinic risk score. J Am Coll Cardiol. March 29  2011;57(12):1400-1401. Wittstein IS  Thiemann DR  Lima JA  et al. Neurohumoral features of myocardial stunning due to sudden emotional stress. N Engl J Med. February 10  2005;352(6):539-548.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Hispanic female from Arizona  USA  who presented herself to the emergency department with severe chest pain that began suddenly while she was at home. The onset of symptoms began after the patient learned about the sudden death of her older son. Her past medical history includes controlled hypertension and her socio-economic status is middle class. The patient denies any alcohol or drug use but acknowledges being a former smoker  having quit about 15 years ago.  Medical History:  The patient is medically managed for hypertension and takes a daily dose of Lisinopril 10mg. She also has a history of osteoarthritis and depression  for which she takes Celecoxib 200mg and Sertraline 50mg respectively. She does not have a history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  asthma or any respiratory disease. The patient's last physical examination was six months ago and the results were normal with a BMI within the normal range. She has never had surgery and her immunizations are up to date.  Family History:  Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with her father having died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. Her mother is 89 years old and has diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. One brother  aged 70  has a history of coronary artery disease and had a stent placed a year ago. Her oldest son  recently deceased  had been healthy. Her daughter is healthy.   Clinical Findings:  Initial examination reveals the patient to be in extreme distress  with excessive sweating and shaking. Her blood pressure was elevated at 180/96 mmHg  heart rate was rapid at 102 beats per minute  and respiratory rate at 26 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was 97% on room air. There appears to be no obvious respiratory or abdominal findings  even though the patient seems slightly pale.  Diagnosis:  The clinical presentation and subsequent ECG which demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads made it rather conducive for a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome. However  a coronary angiogram showed no significant stenosis or blockage. Based on her presentation – acute/recent strong emotional stressor  characteristic symptoms  ECG changes  and angiogram results – the patient was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (also known as 'Broken Heart Syndrome').  Plan:  The treatment plan involved managing the patient's symptoms by monitoring in a Cardiac Intensive Care Unit (CICU)  supportive therapy  and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors (to lower blood pressure)  and beta-blockers (to reduce potential for further heart damage). Psychological support to help her cope with her emotional stress was also part of the treatment plan.  Prognosis:  With appropriate supportive treatment  improvement in the patient's cardiac function is usually seen within weeks. The patient was advised to follow up closely with her primary care physician and cardiologist to monitor for recurrence  given that there's an estimated 5-10% recurrence rate.

Subject: 65-year-old Asian Female  Diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Overview: Ms. Y  an Asian female  is a 65-year-old retired teacher from California. She is divorced and lives alone  with two adult children living out of state. She was presented to the emergency department after experiencing tightness in her chest and shortness of breath.   Past Medical History: Ms. Y has a history of diabetes mellitus and hyperthyroidism  but no known cardiac anomalies. She was diagnosed with Type II diabetes five years ago and has been managing it with medication and diet. She was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism last year. She is currently taking Metformin for her diabetes and Methimazole for her hyperthyroidism. She is a non-smoker and occasional drinker.  Family History: Her mother  who died at the age of 79  had a history of congestive cardiac failure. Her father died at 83 due to lung cancer with no known cardiac complications. Her older brother  currently 68 years old  was diagnosed with coronary artery disease at age 62.  Clinical Exam & Tests: Physical examination and vitals were taken  showing an irregular heart rate. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads. Blood tests revealed elevated levels of cardiac enzymes consistent with myocardial injury. Echocardiography suggested reduced heart contractility with apical ballooning  which are typical features of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Assessment: Ms. Y's symptoms  physical examination  ECG  and Echocardiography results were all indicative of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken-heart syndrome. Given her profile of an older  post-menopausal woman  this diagnosis aligns with literature findings  as Asian women over 55 years old are commonly susceptible to takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Care plan: The patient was admitted to the hospital for monitoring and management  and she was given a beta-blocker  Carvedilol  to manage her irregular heart rate. She responded well to the treatment  with a reduction in chest pain. Her irregular heart rate was monitored closely. The patient is scheduled for regular follow-ups to monitor her heart function. She has also been referred to a counselor for stress management  given the strong emotional triggers associated with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Follow-up: Ms. Y has been advised to maintain regular check-ups with her primary caregiver. Her family members have been informed of the situation and will be providing additional support. An increase in physical activity and a balanced diet were also prescribed. She will also follow up with a cardiologist regularly to monitor her heart function.   Conclusion: This patient's case of takotsubo cardiomyopathy aligns with common demographic and etiological patterns studied in medical literature. The ongoing management plan aims to maintain cardiovascular stability whilst addressing potential emotional triggers. Extensive family support and stress management strategies form an integral part of her healthcare plan.

Patient Case Presentation: Narrative:  Mrs. L is a 65-year-old Asian woman who presented to the emergency room complaining of severe chest pain radiating to her left arm. The pain  according to Mrs. L  came on suddenly after a heated argument with her neighbor. She was brought in by her daughter who revealed that Mrs. L has a history of hypertension managed with medication and she recently lost her husband  which has caused her significant emotional stress.  On examination  she appeared diaphoretic with a heart rate of 100 beats per minute and blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Her BMI was calculated to be 27.9  which indicates that Mrs. L is overweight. Her initial EKG showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads. Her Troponins were elevated on admission  setting off concerns of an Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI).  However  her cardiac catheterization showed no significant coronary artery disease. Instead  on the left ventriculogram  the characteristic heart shape of takotsubo cardiomyopathy was observed - a rounded bottom and narrow neck  akin to a Japanese octopus trap  hence the name. Further  her echocardiogram showed apical ballooning and basal hyperkinesis  both characteristic findings in Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TTC)  thereby ruling out AMI.  At admission  her medications included amlodipine 5 mg and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg. Her only surgical history involved a cholecystectomy at age 45. She is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol. She has two children who are both healthy; her elder brother has a history of coronary artery disease.   Her blood cholesterol  triglycerides  liver enzymes  kidney function were all within normal limits. Further investigation revealed no signs of pheochromocytoma  an endocrine disease sometimes associated with TTC.  Discussion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken-heart syndrome "" is a transient cardiac syndrome that involves left ventricular apical akinesis  often seen in post-menopausal women following severe emotional stress. The pathophysiology is uncertain but is thought to involve high circulating catecholamines released during times of stress that stun the myocardium.  Management: Mrs. L was conservatively managed with just medication adjustments. She was started on a beta-blocker  with monitoring of cardiac enzymes  along with a repeat echocardiogram. Her symptoms and cardiac structure improved without the need for any surgical intervention.   She was recommended to continue her beta blocker and an ACE inhibitor was introduced. In addition  she was referred to bereavement counseling to manage her emotional stress and was advised on lifestyle modifications including weight management  a balanced diet  and regular exercise.  Follow-up:  A one-month follow-up after discharge showed that Mrs. L was doing well without any recent episodes of chest pain. Her repeat echocardiogram showed a return to normal heart function and her blood pressure is now more adequately controlled.   Conclusion:  This case demonstrates how intense emotional stress  such as grief  can result in severe cardiac symptoms related to takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The absence of significant coronary artery disease  the occurrence of a severe psychological stressor  and characteristic findings on echocardiogram secured the diagnosis for Mrs. L. Her case is consistent with the demographic representation frequently seen in the disease: middle-aged to elder women post a stressful event.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman named Ms. Wilson  living in Queens  New York. She is a retired school teacher and lives alone. The patient's primary language is English  and she perceives her health status as fair.  Medical History: Ms. Wilson has a known history of hypertension for which she has been on Lisinopril 10mg Daily for the past 10 years. She also suffers from obesity  with a BMI of 30.4  and has reported a history of chronic stress and anxiety for which she takes a low-dose Sertraline. Her history also shows that she smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years. She does not have a history of excessive alcohol drinking and denies any illicit drug use. She went through menopause at age 55 and is not on any hormonal replacement therapy.  Family History: Ms. Wilson has a family history of cardiovascular disease. Her father died of a heart attack at age 72  and her mother suffered from congestive heart failure and died at age 80. There's no known family history of malignancies or other inheritable disease.  Presenting Issue: Ms. Wilson presented to the Emergency Department complaining of acute chest pain and shortness of breath following a heated argument with her neighbor. The pain was described as severe  radiating to the left arm and associated with nausea.   Evaluation and Diagnosis: Considering the intense nature of the patient's symptoms  a myocardial infarction was initially suspected. However  the troponin levels were moderately elevated  not suggestive of a typical heart attack. An EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  further leading to suspecting a cardiac event.  An emergency coronary angiogram ruled out significant coronary artery disease. However  an echocardiogram showed significant left ventricular dysfunction with balloon-like dilation of the apex  akin to takotsubo cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome.""  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was managed with beta-blockers (Metoprolol)  ACE inhibitors (continued on Lisinopril)  and Aspirin. Her anxiety and stress symptoms were managed by increasing the Sertraline dosage. She also started counseling for emotional support and stress management techniques.  The patient was discharged after stabilizing her symptoms. During subsequent follow-up visits  her symptoms had resolved  and an echocardiogram confirmed improved cardiac function.   Future Concerns: Given her high stress level  Ms. Wilson is at risk of recurrence of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Patient education on stress management  smoking cessation  weight management  and regular mental health counseling are necessary as part of her ongoing care.

Case Presentation:  Patient Details: 'Mrs. A'  a 72 years old Asian woman  presented at the Emergency Department (ED).   Chief Complaint: She reported intense  sudden onset chest pain  and shortness of breath while facing a highly stressful family disagreement.   Past Medical History: Mrs. A is a nonsmoker and nondrinker with a history of well-controlled hypertension  and no history of coronary artery disease or any significant cardiac diseases. She has a record of hyperthyroidism under treatment with Levothyroxine.  Home Meds: Levothyroxine  and Losartan for hypertension.  Physical Examination: Her BP was 170/95 mmHg  heart rate was irregular at 110 bpm  and SaO2 was 95% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed a regular rhythm  with no murmurs or gallops; lung auscultation revealed clear and equal bilateral air entry.  Family History: No reported family history of ischemic heart diseases or other major health disorders reported. She is a widow for eight years and has two healthy adult children.  Investigation: Initial ECG performed in ED indicated ST-elevation in the precordial leads. The lab tests showed a slightly raised level of cardiac enzyme creatine kinase-MB (CK-MB) but a significantly higher troponin I level. Quick bedside echo detected a reduced ejection fraction (EF 40%) with left ventricular (LV) apical ballooning and hyperkinesis of the basal regions  an image compatible with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.   Diagnosis: Considering the clinical presentation  ECG findings  and echocardiography  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC)  also known as “broken heart syndrome”.  Treatment: She was admitted to CCU. Initial management included Oxygen therapy  aspirin  beta-blockers  and IV nitrates as well as Lorazepam for anxiety control.  Progress: After five days  her symptoms improved. Repeat echo showed improved LV function with EF 55%. The attending doctor arranged follow-up appointments and psychological counseling emphasizing stress management techniques post-discharge.  This case presentation reiterates that Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often linked to sudden intense emotional or physical stress  is not uncommon in elderly women. The disease can mimic myocardial infarction  both clinically and electrocardiographically  creating diagnostic challenges. It is a critical reminder for professionals to bear in mind the significance of the psychosocial aspects in the management of such conditions.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Ramirez  a 75-year-old Hispanic male with history of hypertension  diabetes type II  acid reflux disease  and no family history of heart disease  presented with severe chest pain following the unexpected death of his wife.  Clinical History: His vitals on arrival - BP - 150/90 mmHg  heart rate - 110/min  respiratory rate - 17/min and temperature - 98.4F. Recent hepatitis panel was unremarkable. No history of alcohol or tobacco use. He has been compliant with his medications that include metformin  lisinopril and omeprazole. Mr. Ramirez reports increased stress and anxiety since his wife's passing 2 weeks ago.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Ramirez appeared anxious and in discomfort. Heart examination revealed tachycardia with no additional heart sounds or murmurs. His lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally and his abdomen was soft and non-tender. His lower extremities showed no signs of edema. The rest of his physical examination results were within normal limits.  Investigations: An ECG was immediately ordered and displayed a ST elevation but a subsequent Troponin I level was within normal limits  contradicting a typical myocardial infarction. An emergency cardiac catheterization was performed  which displayed no critical coronary blockage  but ventriculography showed apical akinesia and basal hypercontractility suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM) or ""broken heart syndrome"". TCM was confirmed by transthoracic echocardiogram. Further blood work revealed normal lipids and an HbA1c of 6.5 indicating good control of his diabetes.  Treatment  Progress and Prognosis: Mr. Ramirez was managed conservatively with continuation of his current medications including ACE inhibitors and beta blockers along with new prescriptions for short-term anxiolytics. Cardiology follow-up was arranged to closely monitor his condition.  Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM) is a transient heart condition often triggered by stressful situations  such as the loss of a loved one. TCM typically manifests with chest pain and shortness of breath and initially appears like a heart attack. However  unlike a heart attack  there's no evidence of blocked heart arteries in takotsubo cardiomyopathy and it is not lethal. It usually reverses itself in days or weeks. Nevertheless  patients with TCM require careful monitoring and supportive care. Stress management and control of risk factors are important in preventing recurrent episodes. This case portrays that the psychological and physiological stress can cause significant cardiac impact  importantly when other risk factors like age  hypertension and diabetes are present.

Case Presentation  Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Asian female named Mrs. K. On statistical grounds  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TC) predominantly impacts postmenopausal women  with Asians having a relatively higher prevalence.    Chief Complaint: Mrs. K was admitted to the emergency room (ER) presenting with severe chest pain radiating to her left arm  and shortness of breath. The symptoms had started suddenly two hours prior while hearing shocking news about the death of a close friend.  Past Medical History: Mrs. K has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. She's on Metformin  Lisinopril  and a daily aspirin regimen. She had a cholecystectomy ten years ago and occasional anxiety managed by a psychotherapist. There was no previous record of any cardiovascular disease.  Family History: There's no history of heart disease in the family. Her parents are deceased due to unrelated causes (mother-dementia  father-CA lung)  and she has a younger brother managing hypertension.  Social History: She's a retired school teacher  widowed for 5 years. Mrs. K has never smoked  has occasional alcohol consumption  and has been largely sedentary since retirement.  Clinical Examination:  In the ER  Mrs. K appeared anxious. Her blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg  pulse rate 110 bpm  regular  and respiratory rate 24 breaths/minute. An ECG was performed  which showed ST elevations in the anterior leads and T wave inversions with QT prolongation  mimicking the appearance of an acute myocardial infarction.  Laboratory Tests and Diagnosis: Considering the symptoms and ECG changes  Myocardial Infarction (MI) was suspected  so cardiac enzymes were sent immediately. Surprisingly  Troponin I levels were only slightly elevated. Echocardiography demonstrated apical ballooning of the left ventricle with reduced ejection fraction (about 35%)  which didn't correlate with any single coronary artery territory. Coronary angiography was performed to rule out atherosclerotic coronary disease  but all arteries were found to be clean.   Based on her symptoms  ECG changes  echocardiogram findings  negligible elevation in cardiac enzymes  and clean coronary angiogram findings  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or broken heart syndrome.  Treatment & Management: She was started on selective beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and anxiolytics  along with supportive therapy. Her post-admission course was uneventful  and her chest pain and dyspnea improved over 48 hours. Upon a repeat echo prior to discharge  there was marked improvement in left ventricular function. Mrs. K was referred to a structured cardiac rehabilitation program and psychiatric consultation to better cope with stress.
