Prognosis: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is generally considered reversible within weeks to months. Mrs. K was advised regular follow-up with cardiac rehabilitation and a clinical psychologist.   In conclusion  this case presentation highlights the significance of recognizing TC as a differential diagnosis in patients with suspected MI  especially post-menopausal females following sudden emotional stress. Health professionals need to incorporate a balanced perspective  both emotional and physiological  in their treatment approach.

Patient Details:  Mrs. Maria Gonzales  a 65-year-old Hispanic woman  who lives a retired life in Austin  Texas with her husband and two dogs. She has two children  both of whom live out of the state. Prior to her diagnosis  she was quite active  participating in the local community gardening club and volunteering at a nearby food bank.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Gonzales has a history of controlled hypertension  for which she has been taking Lisinopril 15mg once daily for the last six years. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago and maintains her blood sugar levels well with Metformin and diet control. She has been maintaining a BMI of 25.7. She has no history of heart disease or stroke  but her father had his first heart attack at the age of 58.   Presenting Complaint:  Recently  Mrs. Gonzales presented at the ER with severe chest pain  mimicking a heart attack. The pain started after she received the news of her daughter's severe accident. Following a suspected myocardial infarction  she underwent a series of diagnostic tests. Her EKG showed an ST elevation  and her cardiac biomarkers were slightly elevated.  On performing an angiography  no significant blockages in her coronary arteries were detected. However  a subsequent echocardiography displayed an abnormality in the left ventricle function with apical ballooning  a key diagnostic feature of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Broken heart syndrome).  Discussion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is typically triggered by severe emotional or physical stress. Mrs. Gonzales’ condition appears to have been triggered by the severe emotional stress from hearing about her daughter's accident. The demographic most susceptible to this condition is postmenopausal women  making Mrs. Gonzales' occurrence very typical.  Management:  Mrs. Gonzales was managed with standard heart failure medication including ACE inhibitors and Beta Blockers. In addition  she was advised on stress management strategies. She was also referred to a psychiatrist for additional support to manage her emotional stress. Her clinical follow-up after a month showed improvement as her left ventricle was regaining its normal function.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential for women presenting with chest pain  particularly in the setting of severe emotional stress. As the patient had an excellent outcome  this case also demonstrates the reversibility of ventricular dysfunction in takotsubo cardiomyopathy when managed appropriately.

Patient Profile: Mrs. Linda Carter  a 65-year-old African American female  presented at the ER of our hospital. She resides in Brooklyn  New York  is retired  a widow  and has three adult children. Mrs. Carter is a former elementary school teacher and has no history of alcohol or drug abuse.  Presentation: Mrs. Carter presented with acute chest pain  shortness of breath  dizziness  and nausea. She was under a lot of emotional stress  having recently lost her husband to cancer.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Carter reported a history of Type-2 diabetes and hypertension. Both conditions were well-managed with medication (Metformin for diabetes; Lisinopril for hypertension). She is non-smoker and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to arthritis. She has no known allergies  no history of surgeries  and no previous diagnoses of cardiac conditions.  Family History: Mother died at 70 due to stroke  and father died at 75 due to heart disease. Her elder sister has hypertension and her younger brother is in the early stages of kidney disease.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  Mrs. Carter demonstrated distress and increased respiratory rate. Initial vital signs were blood pressure: 160/90 mmHg  heart rate: 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation: 95% on room air.   Diagnostic Assessment: Her EKG demonstrated ST-segment elevation  and her initial troponin I level was elevated at 3.2 ng/mL. An echocardiogram revealed apical ballooning of the left ventricle consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiography showed no significant coronary artery disease  ruling out acute coronary syndrome.  Treatment: The primary focus was on relieving Mrs. Carter's symptoms and managing her blood pressure. She was managed with aspirin  beta-blockers (metoprolol)  and ACE inhibitors. She also was treated with supportive therapy including oxygen and analgesics.  Progress/Outcome: Mrs. Carter's symptoms gradually improved over five days. Repeat echocardiogram showed resolution of the ventricular dysfunction  and she was discharged with outpatient cardiology follow-up in a week.  Plan: Mrs. Carter was encouraged to continue her medications  follow a low salt diet  and increase her physical activity as tolerated.   Psycho-social Support: To address her emotional stress  Mrs. Carter was referred to a therapist for supportive counseling and was encouraged to attend a local bereavement group.  This case intensifies the need for clinicians to recognize presentations of stress-induced (takotsubo) cardiomyopathy  especially in postmenopausal women who are under emotional stress. Timely intervention and management are crucial to improve outcomes.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient is a 68-year-old African American woman presenting to the emergency room (ER) with symptoms of acute chest pain and shortness of breath. The symptoms started abruptly while she was attended a funeral  a stressful event she was mourning deeply.  Her past medical history includes hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and hyperlipidemia -- all considered to be under control with medication. She has been compliant with her medications  including an ACE inhibitor  a statin and an oral hypoglycemic agent. She had no records of previous myocardial infarction or heart disease  and she does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has been leading an active life  enjoying walking her dog in the park every morning.  Her family history indicates that her father suffered from coronary artery disease (CAD) and passed away following myocardial infarction at 72 years. Her mother passed away due to stroke at 78 years. Her two older siblings are healthy.   On her physical examination  she appeared anxious and diaphoretic. Her heart rate was 110 bpm  BP was 150/90 mmHg. Her EKG showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads V2-V4 and mildly elevated troponin-I.  With her complaint of sudden chest pain after emotional stress  ST-segment elevation on her EKG and a mildly elevated troponin-I  our primary concern was acute myocardial infarction. However  the patient was rapidly taken for coronary angiography  which demonstrated no blockages in the coronary arteries. Left ventriculogram  however  showed apical ballooning consistent with stress-induced (takotsubo) cardiomyopathy.  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  is more common in postmenopausal women and can be triggered by severe emotional stress. It can mimic symptoms of an acute coronary syndrome but coronary angiography usually unveils patent coronary arteries.  Her condition was managed conservatively with an ACE inhibitor  beta-blocker  and supportive treatment. Our plan includes conservative management with reassurance  continued medications  and outpatient follow-ups with cardiology.   The patient was placed on a cardiac monitoring unit and her hospital course was uneventful. She improved over the next few days and was discharged from the hospital in stable condition. She was reminded to take her medications regularly and to seek professional help in dealing with emotional stress.   This case highlights the unique presentation and management of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  an under-recognized and under-diagnosed form of heart disease  especially in the setting of emotionally stressful events.

Patient Presentation:   Patient Information: Mrs. A. Kingston  female  aged 63  African American  living with her retired husband in Portland  Oregon.  Presentation: Presented to the emergency room (ER) with severe chest pain mid-sternum  radiating to the left arm. Associated symptoms included shortness of breath and a sense of impending doom.  Past Medical History: Hypertension for seven years  well-controlled with Amlodipine 5mg once daily. No history of diabetes or any other significant systemic illness. She has a previous psychiatric history of severe  chronic anxiety and occasional panic attacks  managed well with SSRI (Sertraline) and psychological therapies.  Family History: Father-deceased at 76 of ischemic heart disease. Mother is alive and well at 85 in a nursing home with Alzheimer's disease. Two grown-up children with no major health issues.  Clinical Examination: Vitals showed a blood pressure of 160/90  pulse rate 110/ min  respiratory rate 22/min  and SpO2 95% in room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed no abnormal sounds. Heart sounds were regular with no murmurs and her chest was clear on auscultation.  Investigations: Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) findings indicated ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  suggestive of an anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI). Blood investigations revealed mildly elevated cardiac enzymes. Other laboratory results including CBC  liver function tests  renal function tests  and electrolytes were within normal limits.  Hospital course: The patient was promptly admitted to the cardiac care unit (CCU) considering a potential MI. Given the early presentation  she was immediately taken for coronary angiography  which surprisingly showed no significant coronary artery blockage. An echocardiogram then revealed apical akinesia with basal hyper contraction  the classic ""octopus pot"" appearance suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Management: Mrs. Kingston was managed conservatively with beta-blockers (Metoprolol 12.5mg twice daily) and ACE inhibitors (Lisinopril 2.5mg once daily). Her chest pain subsided gradually over the next 24 hours. Her cardiac enzymes trended down  and an echocardiogram repeated after a week showed resolution of the wall motion abnormalities  confirming the diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Follow up and Prognosis: Mrs. Kingston was discharged with a prescription for the aforementioned drugs and instructions for follow-up in the cardiology outpatient clinic after two weeks. She was also referred back to her psychiatrist for better control of her anxiety symptoms as these could have triggered the event.  Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as 'broken-heart syndrome'  is often triggered by physical or emotional stress. The demographics of our patient fits with the literature where it is predominantly found in postmenopausal women with a higher prevalence in those with pre-existing psychiatric disorders. Our patient highlights the importance of recognizing this syndrome  which mimics MI but does not carry the same risk if properly managed and prevented  especially by controlling the inciting stressors.

Patient Background:  Patient S.M. is a 67-year-old  postmenopausal Caucasian female. She has a long history of hypertension that was managed through lifestyle modifications and daily medication intake. Additionally  she has uncontrolled type II diabetes and was an active smoker until about seven years ago. She lives alone and recently lost her son in a motorcycle accident. S.M. denies any family history of myocardial infarction  stroke  or any other cardiovascular disorder. She also doesn't have any history or symptoms suggestive of obstructive coronary artery disease.   Presenting Problem:  S.M. presented with severe chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. The symptoms occurred at rest and were described as comparable to ""an elephant sitting on my chest."" She also reported feeling nauseous and fatigued. These symptoms increased after the news of her son's sudden death two days ago. The patient has no history of similar episodes.  Clinical Findings:  Relevant laboratory investigations revealed slightly elevated troponin T and creatine kinase MB fraction  as well as combative cardiogenic shock. An urgent electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission showed ST-segment elevation in anterior lead. An emergent transthoracic echocardiogram noted regional wall motion abnormality. The ejection fraction (EF) was 35%  down from 52% four months ago. Left ventricular angiography indicated apical ballooning  typical of a takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's clinical presentation  electrocardiography  and angiography  she was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome.  Treatment:  Treatment was initiated with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta-blockers  and antiplatelet agents. Additionally  the patient was referred to a psychologist for supportive counselling due to her bereavement.  Follow-up and Management:  S.M. was placed under close follow-ups every 2 weeks for heart function tests. After a 3-month follow-up appointment  there was a significant restoration in heart function as her EF increased to 52%. The patient displayed positive behavioral changes owing to the psychological intervention  which optimistically would reduce the likelihood of takotsubo cardiomyopathy recurrence.  This case presentation emphasizes how acute emotional stressors can lead to the development of takotsubo cardiomyopathy even in patients without a significant family history of cardiovascular disease. It also underscores the importance of not only focusing on the physical signs and symptoms but also addressing the psychological component of patient care  especially in stress-induced disorders.

Patient Case Presentation: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  Patient Identification  Mrs. J  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  presented with severe chest pain of 6-hour duration. She lives in Seattle  Washington  with her husband in a middle-class residential neighborhood.  Past Medical History  She reported no prior history of heart diseases or cardiac procedures. She has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes and managed with metformin and amlodipine for the past ten years. She has been non-smoker throughout her life and admits mild to moderate alcohol use.  Family History  No extensive family history of heart disease  though her mother had hypertension  and her father died of stroke at the age of 70. She has one younger brother living with type 2 diabetes. Her two children are healthy.  Presenting Complaint  Mrs. J was brought to the emergency room by her husband because of the sudden onset of chest pain following an emotional distress at home. The pain  described as heavy and crushing  was in the central part of the chest and radiated to the left arm.  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy Diagnosis  Initial impression was acute coronary syndrome  which was supported by elevated troponin levels (2.1 ng/mL)  and the EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior-lateral leads. However  immediate coronary angiography demonstrated open coronary arteries with no sign of coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography demonstrated characteristic apical ballooning  with contraction at the base  consistent with a diagnosis of takotsubo (stress-induced) cardiomyopathy  also known as broken-heart syndrome  which occurs predominantly in postmenopausal women and can manifest following emotional or physical stress.  Treatment Plan   Mrs. J was immediately initiated on standard post-myocardial infarction medications  including aspiration therapy  beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  and statins. However  dual antiplatelet therapy was omitted given no stent placement. Her symptoms improved significantly with medications.  Follow-up and Prognosis   At a 2-week follow-up visit  echocardiography demonstrated normalization of the left ventricular function suggestive of the transient nature of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient was counseled about potential triggers and the benefit of stress management techniques to prevent recurrence. She was also advised to continue the prescribed medication regimen and regular follow-up for her chronic conditions.  In summary  this case highlights the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy in the differential diagnosis of acute chest pain  particularly in postmenopausal women  with a history of recent emotional stress  and the need to have a comprehensive treatment plan for successful recovery.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: The subject is a 67-year-old African American woman with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and anxiety disorder but no history of heart disease. She resides in Bronx  New York  living independently with her spouse and has a family history of hypertension in both mother and father  but no reports of heart disease in immediate family. The subject is a non-smoker  consumes alcohol moderately and has a body mass index (BMI) of 29  which classifies her as overweight.  Presenting Complaint: The patient initially presented to an outpatient clinic with severe chest pain  palpitations  and shortness of breath. She reported that these symptoms started abruptly an hour after receiving the news of her brother’s untimely death.  Examination: Upon examination  blood pressure was noted to be high (150/90 mmHg) and heart rate was irregular (110 beats per minute). On auscultation  a three-component high-pitched “triple gallop” rhythm was noted  indicative of heart failure.  Investigations: An Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-elevation in the precordial leads. Subsequent lab investigations revealed a significantly increased troponin level (1.0 ng/mL  reference range 0-0.04 ng/mL)  suggesting myocardial injury. Serial cardiac enzyme testing showed a peak troponin I level of 2.5 ng/mL after 12 hours of admission  after which it started to decrease. An echocardiogram indicated reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (40%  normal >55%) with apical ballooning and basal hyperkinesis  suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Management and Outcome: The initial management included administering aspirin  nitroglycerin  and starting on a beta-blocker for rate control. The patient's symptoms started improving within 48 hours  and repeat ECH after 2 weeks showed the recovery of the left ventricular function with an ejection fraction of 60%.  Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  is commonly seen in post-menopausal women following extreme stress. Our patient’s presentation was typical and suggestive of this condition. With an increasing body of evidence pointing towards its link with stress and anxiety disorders  it is important to include psychiatric assessment and stress management in the comprehensive management of such patients. Proper counseling and treatment of underlying anxiety disorder  in addition to standard heart failure management  can prevent future episodes of the condition.

Patient Profile: Mrs. Isabel Martin  a 74-year-old Caucasian female  presented with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. She lives in Portland  Oregon  USA.   Medical history: Has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She is a habitual smoker and quit two years back. No history of illicit drug usage is documented. She has no significant surgical history. Her medications include lisinopril for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Family History: She has a familial history of ischemic heart disease; her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62. Her mother had type 2 diabetes. She has two children  both in good health.  Onset of current symptoms: She reports her symptoms began suddenly just a few hours after learning of her husband's sudden death.  Examination: On examination  she was in clear distress  her blood pressure was low (90/50 mmHg)  heart rate was elevated (110 bpm) and her oxygen saturation was 95% while breathing ambient air. EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads  raising a suspicion of an anterior myocardial infarction. However  a subsequent angiogram showed no significant blockages in her coronary arteries.  Investigations and diagnosis: Levels of troponin  a cardiac enzyme  were elevated which is a typical finding following a heart attack. Upon echocardiogram  there was a notable ballooning and weakening of the left ventricle  and mid-segmental dyskinesia with apical ballooning  giving the characteristic “takotsubo” or “octopus trap” appearance. A cardiac MRI echoed these results  leading to the definitive diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as Broken Heart Syndrome.   Management: In the ICU  she was given supportive care including IV fluids and low-dose Beta blockers. Her blood pressure and heart rate stabilized and she reported a significant reduction in her chest pain.   Discussion: TCM is commonly precipitated by severe emotional stress  which Mrs. Martin experienced for the loss of her husband. Although it often mimics a heart attack  TCM does not involve blocked heart arteries  which were absent in this patient. The incidence of TCM is much higher in postmenopausal women as compared to men.  This case underlines the need for physicians to recognize the distinctive features of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  and differentiate it from the more common acute coronary syndrome given their similar presentations but differing management strategies and long-term implications. Mrs. Martin will continue with the beta-blockers and be followed up by the outpatient cardiology department.

Patient Presentation  Patient Demographics: The patient is an African-American woman of 66 years. She is a recently retired school teacher  a non-smoker  moderate drinker  and follows a balanced diet. She lives alone but has a strong support network of neighbors  family and friends.  Medical History: She is known to have hypertension and mild osteoarthritis of the knees. Her blood pressure control has been suboptimal despite medication. She is pre-diabetic but not on any medication as she is managing it through diet and lifestyle modification. She was last seen by an ophthalmologist for her increasing need for reading glasses.  Current Presentation: She presented at the emergency department with severe chest pain  dyspnea and sweating following the sudden death of her eldest son  a military serviceman. The pain was sudden  crushing and mimicked symptoms of a heart attack. EKG  echocardiogram  and troponin levels pointed to Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome). She showed features of apical ballooning but her arteries had no signs of blockages  echoing the diagnosis.  Family History: Her father had died from stroke at 70 years and her mother of breast cancer at 65. Her only sibling  an elder brother  is hypertensive and is on treatment. There is no known family history of heart disease.  Discussion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is often triggered by severe emotional stress. In her case  it appears to be the sudden tragic death of her son. Higher prevalence rate of TCM is observed in post-menopausal women  making her a typical case. With her current medical conditions including hypertension  she had increased risk of developing heart disease. The prompt diagnosis helped in preventing any major complications and the patient was started on beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors and anti-anxiety medication. Additionally  counseling was also advised to help her cope up with the stress and grief.  Conclusion: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  though transient  can cause severe cardiac dysfunction. The importance of recognizing and treating this condition promptly is paramount. This case highlights the importance of considering Takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential diagnosis in post-menopausal women presenting with chest pain  especially during extremely stressful circumstances.

Patient Case Presentation: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  I. Introduction  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman who presented to the emergency department with typical chest pain accompanied by palpitations and dyspnea. Prior to her admission  she had no significant past medical history except for hypertension and mild dyslipidemia  managed by a low-dose beta-blocker and statins respectively.   II. Demographics  Her socioeconomic status is characterized as middle class; she is a retired school teacher  a widow for the last ten years  and a nonsmoker. She adheres to a balanced Mediterranean-type diet  has a BMI of 25.2  and does mild physical exercise several days per week.   III. Family History  The patient's family history is significant for ischemic heart disease; her father died of myocardial infarction  and her brother has undergone angioplasty.   IV. Clinical Course  The patient has a poor tolerance for stress deriving from her husband's death a decade ago  which was considered a trigger for a potential underlying predisposition. She was assessed with a PHQ-9 (Patient Health Questionnaire) and it confirmed moderate depression. After her routine annual physical examination two months prior  her ECG and general blood work-up were normal.   Her onset of severe stress was triggered by her perceived fear of an imminent ""second wave"" of COVID-19. This was followed by chest pain which led to her hospitalization. ECG changes showed ST-elevation in the precordial leads. An echo revealed a significant reduction in left ventricular function as well as apical akinesia  leading to clinical suspicion of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Angiography excluded significant coronary artery disease. Ventriculography confirmed the typical 'octopus pot' appearance. Cardiac enzymes were mildly elevated. Brain natriuretic peptide was significantly elevated as is typical in takotsubo cardiomyopathy patients. Her symptoms resolved completely after she was managed conservatively. After counseling  she was started on an SSRI (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor) for her underlying depression.  V. Prognosis  The patient was rehabilitated and discharged with advice for follow-up visits for reassessment of her left ventricular function. As takotsubo cardiomyopathy is typically reversible  full recovery is expected.  This case emphasizes the importance of considering takotsubo cardiomyopathy as a differential in post-menopausal women with chest pain and unexplained ST-elevation  especially when associated with stress or emotional triggers. Further studies are needed to examine the potential genetic predisposition in such cases.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Hispanic female presenting with severe chest pain and shortness of breath.   Past Medical History: The patient is known to have a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and mild obesity. She also had a left-sided mastectomy for breast cancer two years prior  with oncologic follow-ups showing no signs of recurrence to date. She quit smoking 20 years ago. She has no history of alcohol or substance abuse.   Demographics: She is a widow with two adult children  living alone since her husband's death five years ago. She recently retired from a stressful administrative job in a local hospital.   Family History: Her parents are deceased  but her father had coronary artery disease and underwent a bypass surgery at an older age  while her mother had a stroke at an older age. She has two siblings and both have hypertension  although otherwise healthy.  Presenting Complaint and Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain radiating to her back and associated with dyspnea. The chest pain was similar to previous instances of angina  but more severe in intensity. On physical examination  she was in apparent distress and vital signs revealed mild tachycardia and hypertension.  Investigations and Diagnosis: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST segment elevations in the precordial leads. Initial blood tests showed elevated cardiac enzymes  specifically troponin  suggesting a myocardial injury. A prompt coronary angiography showed no significant epicardial coronary artery disease. Subsequent echocardiography displayed apical ballooning of the left ventricle  with basal hyperkinesis  leading to a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as broken heart syndrome.  Clinical Course: Given the suspected diagnosis  her management initially included aspirin  clopidogrel  and nitroglycerin. After confirmation of TCM  the management was revised to include heart failure management with beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors. Over the course of her hospitalization  the patient's condition stabilized and improved with conservative management.  Clinico-Pathological Correlation & Discussion: The symptoms the patient presented with mimic those of an acute coronary syndrome  but in TCM  the heart arteries are not occluded. Her recent history of emotional stress (retirement) combined with her sex and age related risk factors are characteristic of individuals likely to present with TCM. Her history of breast cancer raises the possibility that her TCM is a long-term effect of cancer therapy  which warrants further research.  This case exemplifies the importance of maintaining a high level of suspicion for TCM in postmenopausal women presenting with symptoms suggestive of acute coronary syndrome  particularly in those with a recent history of physical or emotional stress. It also illustrates the role of comprehensive history-taking and proper investigation in arriving at a diagnosis.   This case presentation provides a comprehensive understanding of TCM from onset to recovery  serving as a beneficial learning tool in assessing patients with chest pain. It also demonstrates how one diagnosis can mimic another  and that clinicians must be aware of atypical presentations of common conditions. Further  it raises interesting questions on the potential link between cancer  stress  and heart disease.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jasmine Thompson  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presents in the emergency department with severe chest pain and dyspnea following an intense argument with her neighbor. Her medical history reveals controlled hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus. She has no history of coronary artery disease. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. Her family history revealed her mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 76 and passed away at the age of 82 due to complications associated with congestive heart failure. Her father was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease and passed away at the age of 78.   Chief Complaint:  Ms. Thompson mainly complains of sudden severe chest pain  discomfort in her left arm  and difficulty breathing. She described the pain as a 'heavy' feeling in her chest  similar to someone sitting on it. She also reported feeling excessively tired and restless for a week.  Clinical Findings:  While at the emergency room  initial cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia with a rate of 110 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg. Auscultation of the heart revealed no murmurs or gallops. Her respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. The physical examination was unremarkable  except for mild leg edema bilaterally.  Diagnostic assessment:  The preliminary electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation  usually observed in patients with acute coronary syndrome. However  subsequent coronary angiography showed no evidence of any coronary artery obstruction. Echocardiogram revealed decreased wall motion in the apex and mid portion of the left ventricle. Her troponin I levels were slightly elevated. In light of these findings  she was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Treatment:  Ms. Thompson was managed with standard heart failure medications  including beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. The patient's symptoms gradually reduced over a period of days. She was counseled about symptom recognition  when to seek medical assistance  and stress management techniques to prevent similar episodes in the future.  Discussion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  is a non-ischemic cardiomyopathy typically precipitated by severe emotional or physiological stress. Though it is more common in post-menopausal women  it can happen irrespective of age. Prognosis is generally good with proper management  although complications can arise in some cases. Stress management thus plays a crucial role in these patients' management along with standard heart failure medications. The case of Ms. Thompson emphasizes the importance of a comprehensive assessment of chest pain  recognizing that not all presentations of ST-segment elevation represent acute coronary syndromes.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Details: Mrs. Jones is a 68-year-old African American woman  recently widowed.  Past Medical History: She has no history of smoking  alcohol  or drug abuse. She has managed diabetes and hypertension. There is no history of coronary artery disease or heart failure. She previously underwent surgery for benign breast tumor.  Presenting Complaint: Symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath that began two days ago following the death of her husband.  Family History: Her mother died of stroke in her seventies  and her father died of heart attack in his sixties. She has two brothers; one is healthy while the other has hypertension.  Social History: She is a retired teacher  lives alone  and has a daughter who stays in a different city.   Subjective Information: Mrs. Jones says she has been feeling increasingly stressed and overwhelmed by the loss of her husband  with symptoms worsening in the last two days.  Objective Data: Her blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  heart rate was 90 bpm  and oxygen saturation was 94% at room air. Physical examination was notable for mild distress related to chest discomfort.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram showed non-specific ST-segment changes but no ST-segment elevation. Cardiac biomarkers including troponin were elevated. A transthoracic echocardiography showed decreased ejection fraction with akinesis in the apex of the left ventricle along with hyperkinesis at the base  creating the appearance of a ‘takotsubo.’  Management and Treatment: The patient was admitted to the cardiac care unit and began treatment with beta blockers. Diabetes and hypertension were managed with insulin and antihypertensive medication  respectively. Her psychological stress was also addressed by referring her to elderly care support groups  and initiating grief counseling and psychotherapy.  Follow-up and Prognosis: Mrs. Jones showed significant improvement upon follow-up after 2 months. Her chest discomfort had decreased substantially and repeat echo showed improved ventricular function. She was advised regular follow up with cardiology and psychiatry.  Brief Summary: This case represents takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome "" seen in a 68-year-old African American female with a recent bereavement. This disorder  often precipitated by intense emotional or physical stress  commonly demonstrates characteristic changes on echocardiogram and can significantly impact patients without prior known heart disease.   This reflects the literature that postmenopausal women are the most commonly affected by takotsubo cardiomyopathy  and reinforces the importance of recognizing the psychiatric/psychological aspects in managing these patients. Regular follow-ups and comprehensive care involving cardiology and psychiatry proved beneficial in her case.

Patient Profile  Name: Anne Gomez Age: 65 Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Job: Retired School Teacher Demographics: Lives alone. Divorced with 3 adult children. Location: Michigan  USA  Case Presentation:  Anne Gomez  a 65-year-old caucasian woman  recently retired from her work as a school teacher  presented at the cardiology department of a local suburban Michigan hospital with symptoms including severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and light-headedness. The initial symptoms started several hours after Anne learned about the sudden death of her elder brother  suggesting a potential trigger of intense emotional stress.   Past Medical History:  Anne has a history of hypertension and borderline type 2 diabetes. She was diagnosed with these conditions about 12 years ago when she reported consistent feelings of fatigue and frequent urination. Anne has been managing her conditions with lifestyle changes and medication (Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension). She is otherwise healthy and doesn't smoke or consume alcohol on a regular basis.   Diagnostic Evaluation:  Upon presentation  Anne's initial EKG readings showed ST-segment elevation  suggestive of an acute myocardial infarction  although her Troponin levels were within normal limits. Emergency coronary angiogram revealed normal coronary arteries  ruling out acute coronary syndrome. To further assess the severity of the symptoms  a left ventriculogram was performed revealing apical ballooning with preserved function of the basal segments  a feature characteristic of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.   Family History:  Interviews with Anne revealed that her father died from a myocardial infarction at 70 years old  while her mother had a stroke at 69  suggesting a familial predisposition to cardiovascular diseases. Neither of Anne’s parents had a known diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Her 3 adult children are currently healthy with no reported cardiac concerns.  Treatment and Outcome:  Anne was treated conservatively with supportive care  including ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and anxiolytics  along with lifestyle modifications focusing on stress management. Anne’s symptoms significantly improved within days  and a follow-up echocardiogram 3 months later showed complete recovery of left ventricular function confirming a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy.   In the following months  Anne will continue with regular check-ups  and focus on improving her mental health  stress management  and maintaining her hypertension and diabetes. Familial screening  although not definitive in the context of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  might be considered in light of this diagnosis and her family history of cardiovascular diseases.

Case Presentation:   Presenting Patient: Ms. D.R.  a 57-year-old African American female   Chief Complaint: Chest pain and shortness of breath with exertion   Past Medical History: Hypertension; no history of angina or myocardial infarction.   Family History: Father (deceased – myocardial infarction age 62); Mother (alive  has type II diabetes and hypertension); two older siblings with hypertension  one of whom had a myocardial infarction at age 65.   Background: Ms. D.R. is an administrative assistant who recently underwent tremendous amounts of stress in her personal life  with the sudden loss of her husband and job changes. Over the past week  she has been experiencing episodes of shortness of breath and chest pain that increases with exertion and moderate relief with rest.   Presentation: On arrival  blood pressure was elevated at 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate 101/min  respiratory rate 20/min  and Oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Initial blood workup showed elevated cardiac troponin levels. An ECG showed no ST-segment elevations or T wave inversions that would be highly suggestive of acute myocardial infarction. However  an echocardiogram demonstrated hypo kinesis of the mid-left ventricle  apical ballooning  features typical of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy without any obstructive coronary disease evident on coronary angiogram.  Diagnosis: Based on clinical and diagnostic findings  Ms. D.R. was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (stress-induced or broken heart syndrome)  a transient dysfunction of the left ventricle.  Treatment: Ms. D.R.'s hypertension needed to be controlled. She was initiated on beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and diuretics to manage her cardiomyopathy and hypertension. She was also referred to stress management counseling  given the probable relationship of her symptoms with her recent emotional stress overload.  Prognosis and Follow-up: Ms. D.R. seems to be stable and her symptoms improved after a week of treatment. She will continue her medications and scheduled for a follow-up consultation in a month. She was advised to seek immediate medical help should her symptoms worsen.  Conclusion: This case presentation reflects the typical demographics in the literature. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy chiefly affects postmenopausal women  and the course of the disease is generally good. It is often associated with a stressful event and can initially present like an acute bad heart  but on further examination  the symptom picture and investigations point towards Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Considerations for Future: Looking ahead  it would be advantageous to explore more in-depth the potential connections between emotional stress  racial disparities  and heart health outcomes in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian woman  known to be a divorcee  residing independently in San Diego  California. She has a medical history of hypertension and hypothyroidism  both managed well by medication for the past decade. Do not have any records of heart disease in her family. The patient is a non-smoker  reports moderate alcohol consumption and no illicit drug use. She's been managing stress related to the recent death of her beloved pet that created significant emotional distress.  Presenting Concern:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain that radiated to her left arm  with associated symptoms of nausea  lightheadedness  and profuse sweating. The onset of the symptoms was sudden and occurred approximately two hours prior to her presentation.  Clinical Findings:  The patient was markedly distressed upon examination  moderate hypertension was noted  and ECG showed ST-segment elevations in the anterior leads that could correlate to a myocardial infarction. However  her initial troponin levels were surprisingly low for the presumed extent of myocardial injury.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Upon considering the patient's signs and symptoms  an emergent coronary angiogram was performed  which ruled out any obstructive coronary artery disease. Upon carrying out a subsequent echocardiogram  the peculiar finding of apical ballooning with preserved function at the base of the heart was noted  leading to the diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy or Broken Heart Syndrome based on the Mayo clinic criteria for diagnosing this condition.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  The patient was managed conservatively with supportive therapy that included angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors  beta-blockers  and diuretics. A psychiatry evaluation was also done considering the recent stressful event  and a course of short-term anxiolytic medication has been advised.     Follow-up and Prognosis:  The prognosis for Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy is generally good with a complete recovery of heart function being seen in most such patients within weeks to months. Follow-up echo after 4 weeks showed marked improvement of the left ventricular function and eventually completely recovered eight weeks after the initial episode. The patient was then placed on routine follow-up care for her hypertension and hypothyroid condition but was also discussed stress management strategies to avoid similar recurrences.  Teaching Points:  This case highlights that though not very common  Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy should be considered as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with chest pain  especially those with a recent history of significant emotional stress. This becomes crucial when the presentation seems incongruous to the investigations in place.   Age  gender  and comorbidity should not deter the clinician from thinking along these lines as this condition can theoretically be seen in any profile. The key to diagnosis is a high degree of suspicion backed by appropriate diagnostics.   This case illustrates that the patient’s psychological state should not be overlooked when caring for somatic complaints.

Patient Information:  M. Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department after feeling chest pain and shortness of breath following an intense argument with a family member that took place two hours before arrival. The patient describes the pain as a heavy squeezing sensation  rated 8/10. The pain radiates to the left shoulder and is associated with a cold sweat. The patient has a past medical history of well-controlled hypertension and hypothyroidism. No history of cardiac diseases. Denies smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. Her mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72 years. Father died in his old age due to heart failure. No other relevant family history.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination showed tachycardia (105 bpm)  blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  a respiratory rate of 16 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 96%. Other findings within the normal range. Her ECG displayed ST-segment elevation in the anterior-lateral leads. Blood tests showed slightly elevated troponin level to 1.5 ng/mL (Normal range: < 0.04 ng/mL) and normal Creatine-Kinase level. There was a suspicion for acute coronary syndrome.  Treatment:  The patient was given sublingual nitroglycerin and chewable aspirin in the ER. She was admitted to the Cardiology unit and underwent an emergent coronary angiogram that showed completely normal coronary arteries. A subsequent left ventriculogram revealed apical ballooning with basal hypercontractility - a presentation consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  After diagnosis  the patient was put on Carvedilol to control heart rate and limit cardiac wall motion stress. Low-dose aspirin was also prescribed for preventative measures against thrombosis due to apical ballooning. ACE inhibitors were given for LV dysfunction.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Over the course of several days  the patient’s symptoms resolved. A follow-up echocardiogram performed seven days later showed definite improvement. An ECG and Echo done after a month showed normal heart function. The patient's stressors were addressed comprehensively with family psychotherapy and individual stress management. The patient was advised to make lifestyle modifications  approach methods to reduce stress  and is being regularly monitored for cardiac function.  Discussion:  Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as ""broken heart syndrome "" often mimics acute coronary syndrome and is usually triggered by intense emotional or physiological stress. Despite her past medical history of hypertension and family history of heart disease  the patient's acute presentation after significant emotional distress  alongside the angiogram and ventriculogram findings  indicates a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Prompt treatment and comprehensive management were pivotal to this patient's recovery.

Patient Presentation:  Our subject is a 72-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. A  who has been diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM). She is widowed and retired. She has three children  and her family history indicated that her mother died of a heart attack at 76. It's noteworthy also that she has been under emotional stress due to the recent passing of one of her children.  Medical History:  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she takes Lisinopril and Simvastatin. She is also diabetic and is being treated with metformin. She doesn't smoke but has a history of occasional alcohol consumption. She has no known drug allergies.  Patient's Encounter & Evaluation:  Mrs. A presented to the hospital with severe chest pain  which she described as a crushing sensation accompanied by shortness of breath and feeling faint. Initial vital signs were BP 155/95 mmHg  HR 98 bpm  RR 24 breaths/min  and temperature 98.6°F. EKG on admission showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads indicative of myocardial ischemia. Cardiac enzyme levels were slightly elevated.  Diagnostic Test and Evaluation:  An emergent coronary angiography revealed no significant coronary artery disease ruling out myocardial infarction. A subsequent echocardiogram showed apical ballooning with a reduced ejection fraction of 40%  leading to the presumptive diagnosis of TCM.  Management:  She was managed conservatively with a beta-blocker  ACE inhibitor  and aggressive heart failure regimen including diuretics as needed for fluid overload.  Outcome:  Over one-week hospital stay  her symptoms improved  and repeat echocardiogram showed recovery of the ventricular function with EF back to 60%. Mrs. A was discharged and referred to the outpatient heart failure clinic for follow-up.  Summary:  This case of Mrs. A reflects a typical demographic and background of a TCM patient. TCM  or Broken heart syndrome  is more common in postmenopausal women and often precipitated by severe physical or emotional stress. The presentation resembles acute coronary syndrome  yet coronary angiogram often reveals no obstructive coronary artery disease. Most patients  like Mrs. A  have a good prognosis although they require careful initial management due to the risk of severe heart failure and other complications. Regular monitoring and preventive therapy can offer good outcomes in such patients with TCM.

Patient Profile: Name: Mrs. Sheila Cobb Age: 58 Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher Background: Non-smoker; No Alcohol usage  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Cobb presented with severe chest pain and shortness of breath due to an intense emotional event  the sudden death of her spouse earlier in the week.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Cobb has a history of controlled hypertension for which she takes a daily low dose of amlodipine  type 2 diabetes being controlled through diet  and mild obesity (BMI 32). No past surgeries of relevance. There is no known drug allergy. She reports adherence to her antihypertensive medication and no recent changes in her overall health.  Family History: Her mother died at the age of 72 due to breast cancer. Her father lived until 80 and passed away from complications related to Alzheimer's disease. There's no known family history of cardiovascular diseases.   Examination Findings: On examination  her blood pressure was slightly elevated (160/95 mmHg)  HR was 105 BPM  and O2 Saturation was 92%. She appeared distressed due to the chest pain  and auscultation revealed no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. ECG showed ST-segment elevation  echocardiogram demonstrated apical ballooning  and there were no obstructions noted via coronary angiography but mild coronary atherosclerosis.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation  ECG  and echocardiographic findings  she was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken heart syndrome) - a condition commonly precipitated by severe emotional stress.  Management and Progress: She was initially managed with Aspirin  a high statin dose due to atherosclerosis on angiography  and an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) for their proven efficacy in reducing morbidity in cardiovascular disease. To manage her emotional stress  she was referred to a psychologist. After a week of hospitalization  she showed significant improvement.   It is recommended that she be followed up with cardio and stress management programs  maintain her healthy diet  and continue with her prescribed medications for best possible outcomes. The response will be assessed during her follow-up appointment.  This case illustrates the classic presentation of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  often seen in postmenopausal women following an intense emotional event. It highlights the importance of considering this diagnosis in patients presenting with acute chest pain and ruling out the more common causes of these symptoms such as acute coronary syndrome.   Referral: Consideration for referral to an outpatient cardiology for follow-up to assess myocardial recovery and to a mental health specialist for grief-counseling is advised.   Patient Education: Patient was educated on the nature of the disease  its relation to stress  and the importance of practicing stress management and relaxation techniques as well as adhering to medication.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female with a previous history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. She was brought to the emergency department following an episode of intense chest pain  accompanied by shortness of breath and profuse sweating. She reported the symptoms were similar to a past angina pectoris attack which she had a year ago.   Past Medical History  She has a long-term history of hypertension managed conservatively with Lisinopril. Her hyperlipidemia is managed with Atorvastatin. The patient had previously been a heavy smoker for 30 years but quit ten years ago. About a year ago  the patient experienced an episode of angina for which diagnostic tests (including electrocardiogram and troponin levels) came back normal.   Social History  The patient is widowed and lives alone. She reports high levels of stress due to the recent death of her husband  exacerbated by lifestyle adjustments and financial concerns. She consumes alcohol sparingly and quit smoking ten years ago.  Family History  Family medical history includes cardiovascular disease in her late husband and her mother  who died from a heart attack in her early seventies. Her father had chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and died at 68. She has two adult children who are alive and well.  Objective Examination and Tests  Upon admission  her blood pressure was 165/92 mmHg  heart rate was 110 bpm  irregular  and other vitals were within the normal range. She appeared pale and sweaty. Auscultation uncovered mild crackles in the lung bases. Initial laboratory work (including full blood count  renal function  liver function  and inflammatory markers) were within normal limits  while cardiac biomarkers (troponin T and creatinine kinase-MB) were raised. The EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads  indicative of a possible anterior myocardial infarction.  However  coronary angiography ruled this out as it showed no significant coronary artery disease. Left ventriculography  performed subsequently  reported low ejection fraction (35%) and apical ballooning consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Since takotsubo cardiomyopathy is typically precipitated by an acute emotional or physical stressor  the recent death of the patient's husband might have played a significant role in her condition. The treatment plan was to manage her existing hypertension more aggressively and to explore the option of psychotherapy for stress management.   This case highlights the significant influence of acute emotional stressors as triggers for takotsubo cardiomyopathy  and the importance of holistic management covering not only the physiological aspects but also emotional well-being of the patient.

Patient Details: Patient is Ms. Sharma  a 65-year-old Asian female. She is retired and lives alone  her two children live interstate. Ms. Sharma comes from a middle socio-economic status.   Past Medical History: Ms. Sharma has a medical history of hypertension which is currently managed with Ramipril. She has type 2 diabetes controlled by Metformin and diet. She also has diagnosed long-term anxiety  and is managed by Sertraline. She does not smoke  consumes alcohol socially and is not obese. She has no history of heart disease.   Presenting Complaint: Ms. Sharma presented with chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. EKG findings suggested acute myocardial infarction. However  on admission  Echocardiogram showed normal coronary arteries with no blockages  left ventricular dysfunction  and apical ballooning typical of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (broken-heart-syndrome).  Family History: Deep in discussion  Ms. Sharma revealed her mother passed from congestive heart failure at the age of 78 and father from a stroke at the age of 72.   Other Relevant Information: Ms. Sharma revealed during consultation that she recently lost her husband to cancer three months ago and has been experiencing heightened emotional stress  anxiety  and depression since then. It's the trigger of this emotional turmoil.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical findings and patient's history of recent severe emotional stress  a diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy was made. This transient and reversible heart condition mimics symptoms of acute coronary syndrome and is often precipitated by acute emotional stress.   Plan: Ms. Sharma was admitted for supportive management including bed rest  and medications such as Beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics. She was referred to a psychologist for help with her grief and anxiety. Regular monitoring of cardiac function via periodic echocardiograms was planned. Appointments for follow-up care and counseling were scheduled to provide emotional support.   Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is often reversible  with most patients improving within weeks. However  patients like Ms. Sharma  with chronic emotional stressors  may experience a slower recovery. Multi-disciplinary management including psychological support is crucial in these cases.   The case of Ms. Sharma underscores the intricate relationship between physical and emotional health and the necessity of a holistic approach in managing atypical heart conditions like Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 66-year-old Asian post-menopausal female who presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain radiating to her back. Her background includes a history of hypertension and anxiety but has never before experienced any cardiologic issues. She lives alone and recently went through a stressful event - loss of a close family member. She denies any tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. She has a family history of cardiovascular disease; her mother died at the age of 75 due to a myocardial infarction.   Clinical Findings:   On physical examination  the patient appeared acutely ill and was in distress. Her initial blood pressure was 180/95 mm Hg and pulse 110 beats per minute. The cardiac exam revealed no abnormal heart sounds. Laboratory tests indicated slightly increased troponin level  but the electrocardiogram (EKG) showed no signs of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).   Management and Outcome:   The patient was admitted for further testing  where a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed findings consistent with takotsubo cardiomyopathy - apical ballooning with preserved function of the basal segments.   The patient was treated with a combination of ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and anxiolytic medication. Over the week  the woman’s chest pain progressively improved and her blood pressure stabilized. A follow-up echocardiogram was performed one week later and showed improved function and resolution of apical ballooning.  Conclusion:  This patient’s presentation is consistent with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy  also known as stress cardiomyopathy or ""broken heart syndrome."" This is more common in post-menopausal women and can be triggered by intense emotional or physical stress. In this case  the patient's recent emotional trauma combined with her hypertension and history of anxiety may have contributed to her episode. The improvement in her symptoms and cardiac function with medical management supports this diagnosis. It is critical to recognize Takotsubo cardiomyopathy as an alternative diagnosis in patients presenting with acute chest pain  especially when there are triggering stress factors and the classic ""apical ballooning"" is observed on echocardiography.

Patient Presentation:   A 72-year-old African American woman visited our department complaining of a severe chest pain. The pain was intense  radiating to her neck  jaw  and down her left arm  accompanied by episodes of mild breathlessness. These symptoms culminated within a few hours after receiving the news of her husband’s sudden demise.  Past Medical History:  The patient's past medical history includes hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and hyperlipidemia; all are well controlled on medication for the past 7 years. She is a non-smoker and denies any illicit drug or alcohol use. She has no known allergies. Her last cardiovascular workout was reported to be healthy ten months back.  Presenting Problem:  On physical examination  blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats/min  respiratory rate 20/min and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. A physical examination reveals no lower extremity edema  and initial laboratory tests display elevated troponin levels. The patient undergoes an ECG  which shows ST-segment elevations in anterior leads.  Hospital Course:  She was initially suspected of having an acute myocardial infarction. However  a subsequent coronary angiogram showed non-obstructive coronary artery disease. Echocardiography demonstrated a left ventricular apical ballooning with the base of the heart contracting normally which is indicative of takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TCM). Her condition was managed with aspirin  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and statins. The patient responded well to the treatment and was stabilised. She was later proceeded for further cardiac management and psychological support.  Family History:  The patient's family history reveals her mother died from a stroke at 67 and her late husband was diabetic. Her two adult daughters are healthy. Her elder brother suffered from a heart attack in his early 70s.  Conclusion:  This is a classic case of takotsubo cardiomyopathy  commonly known as stress cardiomyopathy or 'broken heart syndrome ' which is usually precipitated by physical or emotional stress. There is a higher incidence rate among postmenopausal women and those with a history of neurologic or psychiatric diseases. The case further highlights the importance of incorporating a thorough medical history  appropriate differential diagnosis  and tailored individual therapies in the management of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It highlights the need for increased awareness and understanding of this condition  particularly among older women with existing cardiovascular risk factors experiencing acute stressors.

Patient Information: Mr. Jackson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presented with symptoms of acute chest pain. He is a retired engineer  married  and lives with his wife. His BMI is 28  indicating overweight. He's not a smoker  but has a past history of mild hypertension and dyslipidemia. He has a family history of myocardial infarction with his father dying of a heart attack at the age of 71.   Presenting Concerns: Mr. Jackson was initially admitted to the emergency department (ED) with severe chest pain radiating down to the left arm  which started suddenly when he was gardening. The pain worsened with physical activity and eased upon resting. He also reported experiencing heavy sweating  feeling of impending doom and transient shortness of breath  all of which led to his visiting the ED.   Clinical Findings: On examination  he appeared anxious and pale. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg and heart rate was 90 beats per minute. Initial EKG revealed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads suggesting myocardial injury/infarction. Troponin I levels were modestly elevated with levels of 2.0 ng/mL (normal: 0.00-0.04 ng/mL).   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Immediately administered thrombolysis did not show any significant improvement. A subsequent echocardiogram  however  showed apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved function at the base  a classical feature seen in takotsubo cardiomyopathy (TTC). Left ventricular ejection fraction was estimated at 45%. Coronary angiogram was normal excluding the possibility of acute coronary syndrome. There was no evidence of a pheochromocytoma or myocarditis from other lab tests.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: Mr. Jackson was managed with supportive care including angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  beta-blockers  and statins along with pain relief and reassurance.   Follow-up and Outcomes: After 48 hours  the patient's chest pain significantly reduced. He was discharged after a week  with his heart functioning back to normal as evidenced by follow-up echocardiography. He was advised to follow-up in clinic in one month and was prescribed medication for hypertension and dyslipidemia.  Teaching Points: - Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  also known as broken heart syndrome  mimics symptoms of a heart attack and is thought to be triggered by periods of severe emotional or physical stress. - TTC occurs more often in postmenopausal women. However  it can occur in men  particularly those with a history of neurologic or psychiatric disorders. - Majority of cases make a complete recovery with supportive management.

Patient Information:   A 65-year-old African American woman named Helen Washington presents to the emergency department. She is a retired school teacher who lives alone but maintains an independent lifestyle. She is a non-smoker and has occasional alcohol intake.   Presenting Problem:   Helen arrived complaining of severe chest pain that she rated as 9 out of 10 on the pain scale. She described the pain as sudden – like an ""elephant sitting on her chest"" and accompanied by shortness of breath. The pain began while she was handling the sudden death news of her sister  which she found extremely stressful.  Past Medical History:   Helen has hypertension  controlled with medication  as well as a history of depression treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors. She has no known history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  or other heart-related illnesses. She has no known drug allergies.   Family History:   Her family history is notable for hypertension in her mother and concerted heart failure in her father. Her sister  who recently passed away  was diagnosed with lung cancer. There’s no record of sudden cardiac death in the family.  Admission Diagnosis:  After performing an electrocardiogram (EKG) and echocardiogram  and based on her presentation and response to the sudden stressful event she recently faced  Helen was diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM)  also known as ""broken heart syndrome"". The cardiologist confirmed that her left ventricle ballooning confirmed this diagnosis.  Plan:  The cardiologist decided to manage her condition with conservative treatment. This included angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  Beta-blockers  and diuretics to manage her symptoms. The patient is also recommended to have a follow-up with a psychologist to help manage stress and prevent future TCM events.  This case illuminally notes the vital connection between psychological stress and heart health  and emphasizes the importance of managing stress levels in patients with a history of cardiac conditions.   Outcome:  Helen responded well to the treatment plan. Her chest pain resolved within a few days  and the medication was tolerated well. She set an appointment with a psychologist to help manage stress and was discharged home in stable condition. Follow-ups were scheduled.  This case presentation represents a fairly typical TCM patient as per the literature. TCM is more common in post-menopausal women and can be triggered by acute emotional stress  as was the case with our patient. It's key to remember that while TCM usually has a good prognosis  early diagnosis and appropriate management are essential to prevent complications.

Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Asian female named Sora. She lives in a serene rural town outside Kyoto  Japan  and is a widow with two grown-up children. She has a body mass index of 23.1 and her significant past medical history involves hypertension for 10 years which is moderately controlled by medication.  Presenting Concerns: Sora was brought to the emergency room with acute chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations. She had been gardening when she felt an intense pain in her chest. Given her medical history  she suspected it may be serious and sought immediate help.  Medical History: Sora was diagnosed with hypertension a decade prior and has been on amlodipine 5mg daily since. She occasionally experiences mild headaches as a side effect. There is no history of Diabetes  Hyperlipidaemia  Coronary Artery Disease  or Stroke. Apart from hypertension  her medical history is fairly unremarkable. Sora is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially.  Family History: Sora's family history is significant with her father having suffered from a stroke at the age of 73 and her mother dying at 69 due to myocardial infarction. She has two elder brothers; one diagnosed with type II diabetes and the other having no significant ailments.  Clinical Findings: Upon reaching the hospital  Sora's symptoms still persisted. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation and echocardiogram revealed abnormal left ventricular motion  commonly known as 'apical ballooning'. However  her angiogram surprisingly did not report any significant blockages in the coronary arteries.  Diagnosis and Discussion: Given her symptoms  ECG  echocardiogram findings  and the absence of significant blockages on angiography  a diagnosis of Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy was made. This condition  often triggered by intense emotional or physical stress  is also called ‘broken heart syndrome’ and is more commonly seen in post-menopausal women. In Sora's case  it's vital to explore further if the emotional stress related to her widowhood might have contributed as psychological stressors often play a role in the onset of this condition. Her case strengthens the essential point to consider Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy as a plausible differential in older females presenting with ACS-like symptoms  even in instances where cardiac enzymes and coronary anatomy are inconclusive.   Treatment and Follow-Up: Sora was managed with β-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and diuretics. She was advised to reduce her stress levels and was referred to a psychiatrist to help manage possible underlying emotional stressors. A follow-up appointment was scheduled in 1 month with a complete cardiology evaluation.

Case Presentation:  Patient Identification: Ms. T  a 62-year-old Asian female with no prior history of cardiovascular diseases  presented to the emergency department reporting severe chest pain.  Present Illness: The patient reported recurrent episodes of chest pain  which started abruptly within the past five hours. The pain was intense at onset and radiated to her left shoulder and arms. She never experienced such pain before. Pain was associated with mild shortness of breath but no other associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or presyncopal symptoms were reported.  Past Medical History: The patient’s past history was significant for hypertension (on hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily) and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her diabetes well controlled with oral Metformin  and she had been following an overall healthy lifestyle. She reported compliance with her medications. No prior history of any cardiovascular diseases  surgeries  or hospitalizations were noted.   Social and Family History: She is a non-smoker and reported moderate alcohol consumption. The family history was negative for any heart diseases  stroke  or diabetes.   Review of Systems:  Unremarkable  apart from the above-noted chest pain.  Vital Signs & Physical Exam: Upon admission  the vital parameters revealed an elevated blood pressure of 170/95mm Hg  pulse rate: 110/min  respiratory rate: 20/min  temp: 98.6F  O2 sat: 95%. There were no abnormal findings in the physical examination.   Investigations: An electrocardiogram demonstrated ST-segment elevation suggesting myocardial injury. Despite this  her initial troponin levels were within normal limits. The patient also underwent Coronary Angiography which refuted the presence of obstructive coronary artery disease. The echocardiography revealed transient apical ballooning with reduced EF  which was suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  Impressions & Plan: Ms. T was admitted to ICU under the presumptive diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy provided by the peculiar imaging findings in the absence of obstructive coronary artery disease and identifiable stress triggers. She was managed with supportive treatments involving ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers and continuing her antihypertensive.   Identifying emotional stressors and taking appropriate action  such as psychological counseling  was planned. Furthermore  her risk factor for heart disease  Hypertension was to be suitably managed.  Conclusion: This case underscores the utility of comprehensive diagnostic work-up  including imaging and angiography  in reaching an accurate diagnosis of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy  a condition often misdiagnosed as heart attack. The emotional and physical stress needs to be suitably addressed and managed in these patients.

Case Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old Hispanic female  Mrs. H  living in an urban area with a positive family history of cardiovascular disease (CVD). She is diagnosed with Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TC). Mrs. H is a retired nurse and is recently widowed. She presents herself with an anxiety disorder and has diabetes mellitus type 2 under control with oral pharmaceutical agents. She is a non-smoker  and moderates her alcohol consumption and has a BMI of 28.  Her current issue began approximately 2 weeks past  following a severe emotional stressor  with marked chest pain and palpitations. Prior to this  Mrs. H had enjoyed relatively unremarkable health.   Physical Examination: Blood pressure stood at 135/85 mmHg  pulse was 110 bpm and regular  respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  and the O2 saturation level was 95% at room air. Despite a mild pallor  physical examinations yielded no unordinary findings.   On admission  Blood Testing presented elevated cardiac biomarkers such as Troponin  N-terminal pro-B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) and Creatine Kinase MB (CK-MB)  corroborating a cardiac episode. ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads.   A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed  revealing hypo-kinetic mid-segments with hyperdynamic apex  identifying the typical 'apical ballooning' - rendering the diagnosis of TC. The left ventricular ejection fraction was estimated at 40%. However  a coronary angiography did not discover any significant coronary artery disease  discarding any chance of myocardial infarction.  A brief stress management consultation was conducted due to her anxiety disorder and the pronounced emotional trigger that seemed to have catalyzed the presentation of her symptoms. After a 3-day hospitalization and therapeutic management under close medical supervision  the patient demonstrated clinical signs of improvement.   Before discharge  she was instated with beta-blockers  angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and statins. Cardiovascular rehabilitation was recommended  and a follow-up appointment was scheduled for 2 weeks later. Thus  psychological support services were arranged for managing her anxiety and bereavement.  Mrs. H’s case emphasizes the critical role of psychological stressors as trigger-instances in the development of TC and hence the relevance of psychological support and stress management in these individuals.  Considering her advanced age and co-existence of type 2 diabetes mellitus  future care should consider these as significant factors of higher morbidity and a potential for further heart failure. Risk-reducing measures  such as a monitored diet  lifestyle adjustments  and regular exercise  should be advised to this end. Much emphasis is placed on regular follow-ups and monitoring the efficacy of her medications.   (Note: This case was formulated to be as authentic as possible  based on common presentations of TC. However  it does not reflect any specific patient or scenario and is intended for educational and illustrative purposes only.)

Patient details: The patient  Mrs. Akiko Nakamura  is a 68-year-old Japanese woman  living in a suburb of Tokyo. She has been a widow for 15 years after her husband passed away from pancreatic cancer. She is a retired high school mathematics teacher and lives alone. She has two adult daughters who live and work in different provinces of Japan. Mrs. Nakamura doesn't smoke or drink alcohol. She likes to engage in brisk walking in her neighborhood for exercise.  Past medical history: Mrs. Nakamura has a history of hypertension  for which she takes medication regularly. She also has mild osteoarthritis and had been on hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for a brief period upon reaching menopause.  Family history: Her father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 73  and her mother had a stroke at age 70  but lived until 88. Her sibling  an older brother  is alive and has no significant health problems.  Presenting concern: Mrs. Nakamura was admitted to the emergency department of the local hospital following an episode of acute chest pain  mimicking a heart attack. She reported that this occurred shortly after she received news of a significant financial loss due to a scam – a stress-inducing event. She had no prior history of any heart disease. EKG revealed ST-segment elevation  typically seen in myocardial infarction  prompting further investigation.  Diagnosis: Though initially treated as an acute myocardial infarction  her echocardiogram and cardiac angiography showed no significant coronary artery disease but revealed apical ballooning – a characteristic feature of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Left ventricular function was found to be temporarily impaired  and “takotsubo cardiomyopathy” or “broken heart syndrome” was diagnosed.  Management Strategy: Mrs. Nakamura was treated with medications including beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors to manage her condition. The doctors also recommended a stress management intervention to help her cope with her recent financial loss and the emotional trauma associated with it.  Follow up and prognosis: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy typically has good prognosis  and Mrs. Nakamura's condition significantly improved over a period of few weeks with complete recovery of left ventricular function. She was asked to attend regular follow-ups every three months to monitor her condition.  This clinical scenario highlights the importance to explore beyond the apparent clinical presentation  especially in elderly women presenting with chest pain.
